Pint on tap pours hazy pale yellow with a white head and an orange slice.  Aromas of citrus some spice like clove and a bit of wheat.  Flavor is sweet and crisp, very light with some flavors of fruit.  Body is light and finish leaves barley and flavor.  Better with the orange slice then without

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2012 Poured from a bottle into a stange.  From notes.  First reviewed 12/2/208.

Following the directions on the bottle: Pour, swirl, and add yeast. Very pale and cloudy yellow, with a strong head that hangs around and leaves a nice lace on the glass.

A strong and soothing aroma of spices and citrus, particularly nutmeg, cinnamon, and orange peel. 

The flavor is bold for a witbier, first the nutmeg and cinnamon control my palate, combining with the yeast to form a unique flavor. The malt slowly comes out along with the citrus flavors, adding a nice complexity to the flavor.  The complex flavors make this a beer worth savoring, but it is also light and refreshing.

Initially it is very crisp; the strong carbonation is the first thing I notice. The wheat and yeast allow it to be very smooth as well. 

Overall a fantastic witbier. Very drinkable, and the blend of citrus and spices with have me drinking this one again very soon. I am impressed enough to start moving through the other Allagash products.
355ml bottle. Cloudy with some yeast sediment and a good strong sweet aroma. Good head of white foam with a taste of spice and some light fruitiness. A good solid witbier.

Pours a pale yellow with a big white head, lots of lacing. Smells like yeast, citrus and light spices. Taste is very light and delicate, with a good wheat back bone and notes of lemon and spice. Aftertaste is very clean and pleasant. This is a pretty light beer, but very well crafted.

Bottle. Pours cloudy yellow with a lively large white head. Lots of lacing. Lots of soft lemon,floral notes and spice on the nose. Coriander and yeast follow as usual for the style. Very nice aroma. Flavors of wheat,spice,coriander,lemon,orange peel and some mild spice. Very refreshing. Probably the best example of the style i have had yet.

"Tasted this beer at the Three Penny Taproom in Montpelier Vermont. Served in an Allagash pilsner glass.
A - Golden beer. Theyre not lying about being unfiltered. Its very full of wheat. Two finger head but could have been a lot more. The head stuck around for a while.
S - Semi-Sweet Chocolate, Wheat, Flowers and a bit of sugar.
T - Very classic wheat beer flavor. Explosive sweetness which was a nice surprise. This is a delicious beer.
M - Light body, sticks around way after you swallow. Super great mouthfeel. Cant wait to have it again.
O - A great wheat beer. Im not big on wheat beers. My girlfriend keeps ordering wheat beers despite being allergic to them so I get to watch her drink a wheat beer and then stop up and get all puffy faced. Its weird but she loves wheat beer. Im sure shell order it again."
pours a cloudy light golden color with a bubbly head. Delicate and crisp with a little banana and spice.

Pours a light cloudy yellow with a short lived soapy white head.The aroma is of a strong banana sent.The flavor was a nasty banana flavor.The body was medium with a funky aftertaste.Overall not a good beer at all.

Poured in to a Bruery tulip glass. Pours a cloudy lemony color with a moderate head that dissipates and leaves some lacing. Aroma is of citrus, coriander and slight hint of pepper and cracker. Taste is orange, coriander, and yeast. Clean mouthfeel makes for a refreshing beer.
Cloudy yellow with small white head.  Citrus/lemon aroma with floral background.  Medium-light body.  Wheat and spice and pleasantly sour flavors.  Crisp and easy to drink yet flavorful.

12oz bottle from Armanettis. Pours a cloudy yellow colored body with a finger-width, dense and frothy, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is slightly sweet wheat with lots of soft lemon. Coriander, doughy yeast, florals, orange peel, and a light pepper spice. Flavor is similar. Crisp wheats up front with lots of florals, doughy yeast, lemon and orange peel, and coriander. A light spice and herbal hopping comes out towards the end and helps this finish pretty dry and crisp with a light bitterness. Medium length aftertaste following a light, somewhat watery body and a moderate, soft, fizzy, carbonation. Overall, a pretty solid witbier. This is definitely not my favorite style, but this beer is flavorful, crisp, and refreshing with a solid balance. Not bad.
Floral, as a good Belgium style beer should be. A very good, inexpensive version of a Farmhouse white. If you like Belgium beer, youll like this one too.
Hazy orange pour with a foamy head.  Smells a lot of orange and lemon, coriander, nutmeg and citrus.  Tastes pretty standard for a wit, lemony and sweet.  Really good witbier!
Terrific Belgian white beer.  A very crisp beverage with hints of New England spices.  It has a cloudy yellowish gold color that provides a citrusy flavor and a refreshing yeast aftertaste.
#1189 bottle; nose is banana, hay, weak celery, moldy whiff, feel is watery, carb is heavy, taste is hay, thin rosehip, some very dry lemon

Great wheat beer, any wheat beer lover will like it. It needs little more body for my taste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Growler pours cloudy pale yellow with a white head.  Aromas are floral and bready.  Taste is malty, spicy, and fruity....like lemons.  Body is light with ample carbonation.  Finish is short and sweet.  Very good and true to style.  I liked this a lot.  Probably be great on a hot summer day.
Boring chlorine aroma. Cloudy orange colour. Crappy head. Yeast and slight sourness. Spicy finish.

Hazy golden pour with some cloudiness, small white head. Smells of lemon, grass, spices, coriander. Some light sweetness from the coriander, balanced with the sour lemon and spice flavors. A great Belgian White; very refreshing, especially in the summer months.

Tap, Blind Tiger, Bleecker St, 19/12/11. Orange, mid-hazy, thinning foam. Perfumey aroma; coriander and banana. Thin, weakly peppery esters; not quite a full-on wit or weizen, but tasty. A little rubber and orange rind, lemon barley. Uncomfortably fizzy. Didnt finish a pint.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 Reviewed from notes (2007).

A: Hazy straw yellow body. Small white head. Spotty lacing.

S: citrus hops, orange, coriander and some grassy/foral accents

T: A nicely balanced wibier profile: orange and coriander are most strongly present with more undertones of citrus/floral hops and a nice wheat base

M: Smooth, crisp, relatively dry

O: Refreshing and enjoyable... among the better witbiers

Bottle. Pours cloudy golden thin white lacing. Aroma of orange, clove, banana, nutmeg. Taste is sweet. Light body, smooth texture, lively carbonation, abrupt finish. Very enjoyable belgian white, refreshing and good flavor.

Very nice spicy with somewhat flat-ish body (poured from bottle by the host). White head with expected retention. Good hops presence with a good pine/floral essence. Well balanced and good duration. Clove as expected.
Tap. I remember liking this better. Spicy. Cloudy. A little herbal.  A little sticky in three mouth.
Allagashs Belgian White has a clean and refreshing taste. If you enjoy wheat beers you will enjoy this. The spices are balanced nicely and have a  clean transition.
12 ounce bottle pour.  A nice yellow color with a nice head.  Crisp.  Light clove aroma.  Very good and drinkable.  A standard of the style.  Great beer.

On tap. Pale hazy straw yellow with a white head. Coriander, wheat, orange zest, some malt but too sweet. Smooth, above average carbonation, very dry, great wheat and orange finish but once again a little too sweet.
the look is nothing to write home about.  Average pale swill like in appearance.  Smell is cirtusy and of wheat.  Subdued, smooth and very easy to drink.  Good one

A very solid drinkable beer. Color is a pale watery gold. Nose and taste are of spice, citric hops, slightly lemon grass. Great carbonation. I highly recommend this beer if your looking for a light well balanced easy drinker. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
White pillow like head. Bright yellow hazy yellow. Mild bitterness. Soft yeast taste. A crisp subtle and well balance. Mild banana lemon like aroma.

The Breslin, NYC - 12oz. Smelled of tangerines and honey. Sip was filled with zesty goodness and very smooth. Overtones of coriander and a smidget of mint. Very good offering for a Witbier.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from craft beer outlet.  Pours a hazy golden color, smells and tastes of lemony citrus and spices. Really good.
Bottle.  Pours a cloudy pale yellow with minimal head.  The flavor is spicy and sour with hints of coriander.  The sourness isnt working for me, however.

GABF 2011.  Hazy light gold, nice laceful head.  Great coriander and citrus nose, complex and funky.  Lovely coriander and lemon flavor, slight funk, rich big body that is dry, floral, malty, and balanced.

Pours cloudy gold with a mild white head. Aromas of citrus & spice, yeast, bubblegum, leather. Medium-light body with light carbonation. Mmm... tasty. My mom is from the Allagash. Why didnt she tell me aboot this beer earlier.
Hazy golden with a smaller white head, no real retention, a little lacing... wheaty, lightly spiced easy drinking yeasty, bready... aroma is relatively mild lightly spiced...

5/10/2011 from tap @ Monks, Philly (2011-524)
Cloudy pale yellow milky beer, creamy white head, pretty stable, adhesive and leaving a nice lacing in the glass. Aroma: yeast, citrus, koriander, sweet fruity, raspberry yogurt. MF: little carbon, full body. Taste: fruity start, wheat, citrus touch, spices. Aftertaste: gentle bitter hops, orange peel, grapefruit.

(12oz bottle from Total Wine Hillcrest).  Pours a cloudy yellow color with white head. Aroma has orange, coriander, wheat.  Taste is sweet with orange and coriander being prominent with some light bitterness.  Thin bodied and a chewy mouthfeel.  Smooth.  Tasty wit beer and a good American representation.

12oz. bottle into a wit glass at home. Murky bright yellow, huge head with fine lacing. Aroma is lemon, Belgian yeast, wheat, banana like esters. It has a solid medium body with high carbonation. Big bold wheat flavors - clove, white pepper, coriander, fresh dough, lemon. The carbo and the wheat give it a very smooth and creamy palate. The finish is slightly sweet, wheaty, and spicy. A fine witbier.
Session white ale from allagash.  Good beer but too sweet for multiple consumptions.

Tap. Fluffy pure white head that leaves nice curtains of lace; vibrant sun-golden yellow thats very hazy.  Slight banana, spice, coriander, and fruity yeastiness in the aroma. Catching a bit of white pepper in this batch, light spice, light citrus fruits and white grapes. Lighter chalky body with spritzy carbonation. Always tasty.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy yellow with a white head.  Aroma is citrusy (lemon) with a hint of spice.  Flavor is slightly sweet, lemony, some wheat notes with a mild spicy finish.  Refreshing.  Pretty good for a belgian white.
Tap.  Pours a cloudy gold with a large white head.  Aroma of hay and lemon.  Taste is grassy and a little spicy.  Nice flavor.

cloudy pale straw color. there is a murky, yeasty presence in the glass that I love. super tall head3 fingers of pure white that eventually dissolves to a thin rim around the top, which stays for the rest of the drink.

very strong spice aromatics with an earthy yet fresh mix of citrus, wheat, bitter hops, and bread. slightly sour.

taste starts off with good malt and citrus which is consistent from the the front to back. the back gives good clove/coriander spice and slight dryness with a little hint of bitterness on the sides. clean and refreshing finish. theres little alcohol presence which is expected at 5.2% ABV. mouthfeel is light-bodied with fair carbonation.

Draught at BoHo.
Hazy light yellow with a white head. Aroma moderate malty (wheat, orange, citrusy notes). Flavor light sweet and fruity. Medium body, almost flat. Nice.

12 ounce bottle into tulip, no bottle date or batch number.  Pours hazy golden amber color with a fairly dense 1 finger whilte head with nice retention, that reduces to a fairly thick lacing cap.  Some nice lacing clings to the glass as well, with a steady stream of carbonation coming from the bottom.  Aromas of big banana, clove, bubblegum, spices, citrus peel, and a bit of wheat tang.  Very nice aromas here and are very true to style as well.  Taste of big spices, banana, clove, citrus peel, wheat, and breadiness.  Not much bitterness on the finish, but there are plenty of lingering notes of spice, citrus, bread, and clove.  Medium-high carbonation with medium body; with a great and slightly creamy mouthfeel, that leads to very smooth and enjoyable drink.  Alcohol is well hidden as expected, nothing other than a slight warming after the finish.  Overall an outstanding witbier that is extremely refreshing, and has a great balance of flavors.

Simply the best Belgian white Ive had. A thick pillowy head billows out of the light cloudy straw body. Aroma of orange, wheat crackers and spice meld seemlessly. Mouthfeel is sparkling and bubbly that is nevertheless full. Slightly sweet with a little tartness. Perfection.

Pours cloudy pale yellow.  In some ways "white" would not be a bad description of the appearance.  Aroma/Taste - its a standard interpretation of the style - banana/orange predominate, but neither ever really get pushy.  Simple to drink.  Amplifying the flavours would improve this.
Opaque gold. Flavor is bananas and belgian yeast. Flavor is belgian yeast, wheat, oranges, bananas and spice. Medium bodied. Nice.

12oz bottle in a tumbler.  Pours lightly cloudy golden with a thick, white head.  Aroma of light malts, wheat, light spices, and some floral hops.  Flavor the same.  Average texture.  A decent beer, but not the best of its style.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2011 Poured from a tap into a pint glass at Urbn Coal Fired Pizza in San Diego (North Park). About ¾ inches of head. Lots of film, but light lacing. Color was golden orange.

Smelled orange, cloves and wheat, but fairly balanced. 

Initial taste was orange, followed by a sweet citrus finish. Very smooth.

Best part of the beer was the feel. Just smooth, crisp, clean and refreshing. Mild carbonation.

This was a good beer overall. I had this almost a year ago and had to try it again, not what Im rating. Will certainly have it again.
Nice light.aroma of bread, spices. A bit watery but nice light tang.  Fruity.
Hazy straw pour with quickly disappearing white head. Semi sweet malts, little citrus hops and spices. Lingering sticky finish. Its summer!

Beer formed a small head in the glass with a hazy pale yellow color. It has a slight citrus aroma but starts to open up more with its taste. Very smooth with some pine and grassy notes along with a little spice and some lemon. Good summer beer.
Maybe I just had a bad bottle but the finish was kinda funky. I know its a white beer but something was off.
Appearance is large white head with a hazy yellow color. Aroma is very sweet citrus and spice. Taste is lemon/orange and cinnamon with wheat. Overall a solid witbier.

Bottle.  Pale straw color, cloudy, foamy white head that disappeared right away.  Aroma is a light citrus with a liitle spice.  Taste is a little sweet.  Nice medium body, not at all watery, smooth, and refreshing.  Nicely done overall and I am not usually a big fan of whites.
Nice beer, light and fluffy, lemon flavor, nice yeast flavor as well, bready and nice head on the pour, a very solid summer brew
Bottled from various places.  This is one exceptionally spicy beer.  Gold color on the pour.  Very aromatic.  A standard for the Belgian white.
On daft at Alisons in Kennebunkport, ME.  A perfect choice for a hot July day while in town, served with an orange slice.
UPDATED: AUG 30, 2011 A nice blend of spices, citrus, wheat. Nice complex and balanced beer. Well done.

Draught at the Publick House, Brookline, MA.
Hazy yellow colour with big frothy white head.
Wheat, yeast and coriander in aroma.
Wheat, some coriander, spices and some balancing hoppiness in flavour. Thick and sticky palate. Slightly more Wheat and Witbier. Good for an American Wheat Ale though.

Bottle thx Heather and Frank for that one. App:  hazy pale  white head . A: coriander, Citrusy , a bit of orange.  F: body is medium finish is lightly sour but short.   P: Just enough carbonation to push those lovely aromas. O : excellent wit will gladly drink that one again

12 oz. bottle, pours cloudy blond with a small white head. Aroma is pretty mild - wheat, banana, light citrus and mild spices (coriander). Flavour is also quite light, but well designed, with all the aforementioned in good balance. Decent Belgian white.

Pours a hazy yellow with a good amount of white lacing. Spicy, Belgian yeast aroma, it smells good. Tastes like it smells, cloves and other spices with that Belgian yeast profile. A nice refreshing summer drink.

Have had this a few times but not rated - 12oz bottle - Aroma is clove and coriander spices, yeast and perfume.  Tastes are lemon citrus, spices, wheat and belgian yeast.  Crisp dry finish.  Slightly acidic with medium texture.
12 oz bottle.  Hazy lazy golden pour with medium head and little retention.  Nose and taste of a light saison.  Good summertime beer

Pours a pale cloudy yellow.  I swirled the bottle to get the most yeast out of the bottle.  The aroma is a piney, spicy wheat.  The beer has a spiciness and fruitiness to the flavor.  So its more sweet but its dry on the finish.
Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours a hazy light orange.  Taste is orange and a hint of coriander.
cloudy refreshing citrus taste with subtle hints of spice and a bit banana but not overwhelming.

Aroma: Citrusy, with some coriander and yeast.
 
Appearance: Very cloudy, straw colored, slight head that sticks around.
 
Taste:  Blah. Relatively generic for a Belgian White.  Really not a whole lot different/better than Blue Moon (!).
 
Palate: Somewhat oily texture, light-medium bodied.  Active carbo.
 
Overall:  I really like Belgian Wits.  I do.  But Im just not feeling the love on this one.  The Aroma is as expected, as is appearance.  But the flavor is just... blah.  Complex, yes, but none of the sweetness I expect, just somewhat flavorless.  Some spiciness, but lacking the fruit tones I was expecting.  Based on the rating, I was expecting more.

12 oz bottle pours a milky yellow white with a modest head. Aromas of the typical Belgium yeasts coriandor and orange peels. Tastes of spices yeast citrus fruits and wheat. A slight sourness gives this brew a refreshing quality. Fishing somewhat short and crisp. Overall, another quality brew form Allagash!

Cloudy yellow pour thin white head ... aroma of coriander and orange peel with lemon as well .... taste of wheat, coriander and orange peel with a good amount of lemon ... nice bitter zing to it, smooth and thinner medium bodied .... lovely brew
Pours a lacing white head with a cloudy, straw colored body.  Aromas of dough and some spice.  Flavor has dough, mild banana, some coriander.  Finish is dry and clean.
Pours hazy light golden with a thin white head.  Aroma includes spices, malts, herbs and citrus.  Nice citrus and spices in flavour with a nice clear, malty finish.

probably my favorite wheat beer.  Way less sweet with a much more complicated palate and cleaner (not sugary) finish than most.  Cant believe I havent rated it before.  Light, grassy, and very earthy yet light and very drinkable.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2012 Draft at "Battle of the Brews", Allagash vs. Uinta at Scion in DC June 1st. But I have had this many times before. Still one of my most favorite belgian whites. Highly recommended for the style.

Poured into a snifter. Appearance is hazy copper with a thick, billowy head of white foam speckled lightly with brown flecks. Aroma is spicy, alcohol drenched cloves, nutmeg, and a touch of bread. Taste is quite citrusy for as little as I pick up on the aromatics. Orange in particular comes through. I get hints of clove, nutmeg, and bananas as well as the beer fades away on the back of my tongue. Medium bodied and perfectly carbonated beer. Creamy mouthfeel almost. This would be a nice summer sipper.

Aroma: fresh and citrusy, hints of rain.
Appearance: hazy; color of a dirty canary.
Taste: bergamot, pansy, coriander.  light and crisp with a refreshing finish.
Palate: light body; light, tingling carbonation with a scintillating yet short lived aftertaste.
Overall: its like drinking a picnic.  minus the ants.
Slightly hazy yellow in the glass. Aromas of citrus, spice, and wheat. Light and crisp on the palate with a clean finish. Very enjoyable.

Pours an opaque pale yellow with a lush 2 finger head.  Aroma is big spicy Belgian yeast, wheat, cirtus, coriander, and a hint of fartiness.  Taste is spicy coriander and yeasty wheat with a dry orange peel finish.  Body is medium but the wheat adds viscosity which in turn is offset by the high level of carbonation.  This beer was one of the first Belgian styles Ive ever truly enjoyed and has encouraged me to expand my beer-drinking horizons.  Overall, this is a solid beer that has a refreshing tartness and a wonderful amount of complexity.
banana, bubblegum, citrus, pale, cloudy, white foam, medium sweetness,  lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, fizzy,
12 oz bottle pours a hazy golden color.  Aromas of orange, corriander and spice.  Nice light mouthfeel, and easy to drink a very nice summer beer

Yeah, Allagash White actually does taste pretty good.  I know its easy to hate witbiers in the face of Double IPAs and Impy Stouts and Sours, but Ive always liked their subtle, spicy goodness, their mildness in the face of rampant extremity.  Allagash White is hazy and wheat-filled and modestly sweet, yet the herbs (Coriander?  Lemon Zest?  Flintstones Vitamins?) provide flavor without distracting flair.  (2008)
Pours pale golden with foamy white head. Citrus, coriander, grassy. A bit sweet and moderately bitter. Lively palate. Enjoyed this one quite a bit.
tap at maproom in chicago. pours hazy yellow with buff white head. aroma of grain, stone, coriander, lemon zest. flavor is more sweet with added bread and biscuit. sweet, fruity, light and refreshing
bottle; pale hazy yellow with medium white head; aroma-yeast, spices, faint citrus; taste-light sweetness and bitterness, refreshing but too diluted.
What a great beer! Beautifully refreshing taste, aromas of citrus as expected. Could drink this all day.
Cloudy gold pour, a little off-white head, a little lace, a light hay aroma, a gentle citrus flavor.  Nice, but not too exciting.

Pours a hazy orange tinged yellow with a big white head. Leaves a lot of lacing. Nice spice and banana notes on the nose. More of an orange tinge on the tongue with a bit of carbonation on the finish.
On tap at monks cafe. Pours hazy white. Aroma is faint banana. Flavor is banana and white grape. Okay.

A: The pour is a pale cloudy straw color with a short lived white head.

S: Coriander is almost overpowering on the aroma.  Theres a slight mustiness to the nose, but perhaps thats just from far too much coriander.  Lots of citrus zest and a touch of lemony tartness.

T: Lots of lemon zest flavor.  There is some orange peel in there too.  Maybe a touch too bitter for a witbier.  Lots of floral hop notes with a moderate level of bread and wheat flavor.

M: Medium in body with the carbonation a bit on the high side of medium.

O: Unfortunately this was another fairly underwhelming beer from Allagash.
Admittedly this might have been too late in the night for me but it didnt really work. All citrus and banana, bit of spice at the end. On tap at the Flat Street "brewery" in Brattleboro. Eh.
Very yeasty aroma, moderate white head. Cloudy light golden in appearance. Wheaty flavor, hints of malt. Goes down smooth, pleasant aftertaste. A refreshing brew for summer.
Clove spiced aroma.  Hazey pale yellow.  Spicey clove flavor that dulls out nicely.

12 oz bottle from Monks in Philly....good mild wheat from Allagash....poured kinda cloudy (as near as I could tell in the "light" at Monks....but a distinctive crisp taste....probably would have felt more appropriate if it wasnt 37 degrees outside...more of a summer beer than my usual stouts and porters this time of the year....will try it again then...

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle with no date or lot code. It pours a milky yellow with a small head and busy carbonation. Yeast sediment is clearly swimming in the glass. There is a nice dose of wheat and yeast on the nose. The body falls into the mellow-medium range.  Immediately I get  a tart bite in the flavor but it becomes smoother as some of the unique characteristics of a white beer trickle in. Pleasant and easy to drink.
Draft. Like a belgian wheat beer. Funk flavor. Refreshing with a subtle taste of hops. Excellent

12 fl oz bottle bottle from Lubiere (merci!), served cold in a tulip glass.  Age unknown. 
App.:  Cloudy bright straw with a decent bright white head.
  
Aroma:  Quite yeasty in a way that I havent smelled before, some nice zesty citrus and spiciness, sort of a thick, brothy note but in a wheat ale kind of way (hard to describe), a hint of organic acids, some esters comes out as it warms, the earthy/lemony coriander comes out as it warms too, a nice Wit.
  
Palate:  Medium body, fairly full and velvety effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Really nice coriander notes, very well integrated with the wheat and light malts, some light esters and a little vague fruitiness, some yeast, much less than the nose (more in balance), pretty good Wit.

However old this is, it tastes good.
Pours a pale yellow color with a white foamy head.  Smells of bananas.  Was a bit carbonated with some banana and wheat flavors.  Decent beer.

12 oz bottle.

Pours into my Hoegaarden glass with a small foamy white head. The body is urine/pineapple juice colored.

The nose is a bit citrusy, with the prescience of orange and coriander. Nothing special for a witbier, but it seems a bit stronger than normal wit.

THe spices and orange continue into the taste. There is also some wheat and yeast in the flavor. But this one is light, there is a small bit of aftertaste but this could be downed like water.

The mouthfeel is conducive to massive quaffing. It is light bodied, slightly bubbly and slightly watery.

This is more of a summertime beer, it is easily quaffable. Overall it isnt bad, it is more pedestrian than some of the Belgian Witbiers, more like Hoegaarden, not a bad thing if you want a lawnmower beer in humid weather but in the winter it is rather bland.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-04-2010 04:40:42

12 oz. bottle. Pours a cloudy, pale yellow with a foamy white head. The aroma is classic witbier, with a lemon and grapefruit base and lots of spices, including cloves and allspice. The flavor is very citrusy, with a light fruity sweetness and a crisp tart finish. The palate is light and smooth, and only a little astringent. Overall, this is a very good example of a delicious and difficult style.
It has a terrific appearance. A very complex taste, it says its brewed with spice, and you can actually taste it. Very satisfying beer.

Poured a very hazy yellow with a small white head.  Aroma is pretty skunky with wheat notes.  There are also some citrus notes with floral hops.  Taste has a lot of lemon with grassy notes.  Lots of citrus and wheat as well.  This reminds me of a saison a little bit.  Very good.

Bottle. Pours cloudy light golden with moderate white head, but becomes murky as the yeast settles. nose is citrus, spice and bread.. Tastes of bread and sweet malt, slight spice and citrus notes, and spice lingers through finish.

Poured into a pint glass.

3.5 A: Murky dark yellow color. One finger of thick, creamy head with average retention and moderate lacing.

4.5 S: Lemony citrus and corriander top of the list of aromas. Earthy yeastiness and hay-like wheat. Fresh and clean, very nice.

4.5 T: This is really good. Perfect grassy/hay wheat backbone with lemon zest, corriander, a bit of clove, and residual yeastiness. Not any amazing flavors, but really elegant brew.

4.0 M: Medium body. A bit undercarbonated for the style. A little bit more and this would be perfect.

4.5 D: Very good, one of the best wits out there.

When I had this on-tap it was nowhere near as good.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-18-2009 02:22:24

Huge citrus aroma, doughy yeasts.  Pours clear light golden with a big frothy head, but becomes murky as the yeast settles.  Tastes sweet and salty with medium body, soft carbonation, and creamy texture.
As someone who is partial to wheat beers, I found this beer especially delicious. Simply a pleasant, crisp, and enjoyable beer.

Pours a cloudy golden yellow, with one finger white head. Lots of suspended yeast sediment theres no expiration date but it just got into the store so heres hoping its not too expired. Smell is yeasty, floral, and peppery; pears stand out among some citrus notes. Strong aroma for a witbier; smells like a tripel. Taste brings out coriander and a bit of orange. Lively carbonation, thin body, crisp; extremely smooth and drinkable.

I thought the flavor was very pleasant but not over-powering. As stated in other reviews, the color is straw-yellow and cloudy, with a modicum of white head. Aroma is yeasty, lightly citrus-sweet, with a not-obnoxious amount of cloviness. Flavor is more of the same but with the addition of a nice maltiness that seems to create balance and doesnt seem at all out of place. Mouthfeel is adequate. All-in-all, a very tasty brew. Recommended.

12 oz bottle. Pours a cloudy, hazy yellow with soapy, white head. Aroma of citrus peel, lemon notes, wheat, faint banana and slightly herbal. Flavor of citrus peel, wheat malt, light clove notes and very faint hints of banana and bubblegum. Mouth feel is light body with fizzy carbonation. Overall, pretty tasty and refreshing brew!

Poured a hazy, pale yellow with a lacing, white head.  Aroma of spice, yeast, and citrus.  Taste is very citrusy!  There are also some wheat and spices in there.  Finishes with some banana notes and lemongrass. Very refreshing!  I will have to remember this one in the summer.
Aroma of banana, cloves, maybe orange?  Very pale light yellow color, almost the color of a Bud Light but extremely hazy.  Nice juicy head that dissipated quick. Sweet taste, extremely drinkable.
My first Allagash beer and so far I am impressed.  Not the most powerful or complex, but solid for a wit.  Its easy on the pallette with  decent finish.
UPDATED: MAY 15, 2016  Belgian beer spice and banana light and watery at first this is appreciated as the flavor intensifies as one drinks. some sugar and flavors linger some.

G: Poured into a pint glass. Had this one last summer, and this is part of my quest to bring my old notes in line with the "electronic notebook" that BA so graciously offers all of us.

A: Light and slightly cloudy. Good amount of carbonation, and pretty good lacing.

S: Lots of excellent spicing here. Plenty of citrus and coriander, with a good wheat undertone.

T: Excellent. The perfect balance to the sweetness and the spice--it definitely does not overdo either one. Some floral undertones.

M: Very nice. Soft body and perfect for summer drinking.

D: As stated above, the perfect summer beer--next time youre out in warm weather, see if you can find a small bottle of this; you wont regret it.
dark straw hazy color with frothy white head. the flavor is more pronounced than most of the belgian wits ive tried. lemony and spicy.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2011 12 oz. bottle poured into pint.  My first known experience with craft beer.  I give this beer credit for my search for the best beers.  Creamy golden color.  Sweet flavor all the way through.  Refreshing summer beer.

Big bright orange/ yellowish bright pour, fluffy white head. Smell was yeast sweetness, some cinnamon/ coriander spice. Taste was clean, light, with more spice coming through. Mouthfeel was light, so if you like the lighter style coriander, youll love this. This was a solid beer, very drinkable, will be having this again.
Very light in taste. Little to no after taste left on the back of your tongue. Smooth and easy to drink.

Very pale golden, just a touch hazy. Aroma of yeast, citrus, wheat and spices. Flavor is full, dominated by citrus, with wheaty and spicy flavors as wll. Light bodied and refreshing. Very good interpretation of the style.
Bottle: Pour a cloudy pale yellow with minimal head but decent lacing. Aroma of banana, bubblegum, slight spicyness. Light bodied, very drinkable.

Brown bottle, 12 ounces, purchased at Bangor Wine and Cheese on August 18 2010, savoured on October 18 2010; eye: straw, lightly hazy, minimal effervescence, tiny ring of white head, slight lacing; nose: coriander, orange, wheat, freshness, acidity; mouth: coriander, orange, wheat, acidity, finale with a light acrid presence, mild acidity, a bit thin; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 12 onces, achetée chez Bangor Wine and Cheese le 18 août 2010, savourée le 18 octobre 2010; il : paille, légèrement voilée, effervescence minime, petit anneau de mousse blanche, très légère dentelle; nez : coriandre, orange, blé, frais, acidité; bouche : coriandre, orange, blé, acidité, finale avec légère présence dâcreté, corps moyen-léger, bonne carbonatation, moyennement acide, un peu mince; en résumé : bien

Picked up a 4 pack of Allagash White 12oz bottles.  Belgian style bottle conditioned white beer.  Poured into River Horse pint glass.  Followed instructions on bottle.  
Cloudy straw colored with small white head and great lacing.  Aroma of wheat and orange.  Tasty citrus and spice blend.  Exceptionally drinkable.  Definitely ranks up in the top 5 white beers Ive had.

Draft @ Rattle N HUM NYC

Good Witbier that was the last beer of the night for me. Pours a yellow color with a nice head that doesnt last long. IMO another good session beer!

Cloudy yellow with a strong, creamy cream-white head and very nice lacing. Lemon and spice were strong on the nose, touches of orange as well. Wheat flavor up front, cut by the spiciness, yeast and hops coming through as well. Very smooth, creamy mouthfeel, medium body and carbonation and a very nice crisp citrusy finish.

Bottle. Cloudy lemon yellow in appearance with a half inch of thick white head. The aroma is doughy yeast, cloves and lemon rind. The taste starts with cloves and bready malt followed by honey, banana and cardamom. The mouthfeel is slightly creamy with medium carbonation and a smooth, citrusy finish. The overall flavor has a good balance of yeast, spice and fruit flavors. Fans of Saisons and German Hefeweizens should definitely give this one a try.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The color is a cloudy orange-yellow with a soft, light foamy head.

The smell is very pleasing to the nose it is full of citrus wheat flavor. A big of a sugary zest flavor that is quite sweet.

The taste has a nice citrus, like grapefruit flavor that mixes well with the light wheat flavor. It also has a slight bitterness that is just enough to keep this beer from being too sweet.

This is a great crisp, light, refreshing beer. Is easy drinking and only lightly carbonated.

Tasted from bottle.  Pours a hazy yellow with a huge foamy white head that quickly recedes to light lace.  Nose is wheat with good yeastiness; some banana and spices along with a white bread aroma.  The flavor is very light with wheat, very light banana, and just a hint of spiciness and a bit of bitterness as well.  The body is light with lively carbonation and a short bitter finish.
Nice example of Belgian wit, with pleasant appearance and nice fresh palate w hints of grass and clive spice
On tap at Monks.  What an excellent witbier.  Pours a pale golden color with a white foam head.  Has that clean delicate traditional witbier taste with notes of orange.  Creamy.  Nicely done.
Draught. Mild citric aroma, hint of fat yeast. Cloudy yellow colour. Small white head. The flavour is nicely citric, good refreshing lemon note. Mild clove note.

12 oz bottle poured into a Duvel glass I got a rather large white head that laced out great. Sitting on top of a hazy (yes, I added the yeasties) yellow colored body brew. The brew has tons of Belgian yeast in the aroma with ample amount of spices, coriander stuck out for me. It is very aromatic and I do also use this brew to steam seafood because of it.

The flavor is slightly sweet with enough spicing to keep it in check. It is light and crisp in the mouth and a great beer to complement a lobster in my book. God knows I had a few of these with that type of meal.

I can drink mass quantities of this brew but, sometimes price comes into play so I stick with the 4 pack for me or a couple of glasses at a local restaurant

12 oz bottle.  Pours with a small amount of white head that disappears quicky.  Color is a cloudy golden yellow.  Aroma is of coriander and cloves.  Taste is much of the same with a bit of lemon citrus and spice.  Smooth finish and overall excellent drinkability.
UPDATED: JAN 20, 2015 One of the more rich tasting Witbiers I have had. Spices apparent. Yummy. Serving: Bottle and tap

I thought the flavor was very pleasant but not over-powering. As stated in other reviews, the color is straw-yellow and cloudy, with a modicum of white head. Aroma is yeasty, lightly citrus-sweet, with a not-obnoxious amount of cloviness. Flavor is more of the same but with the addition of a nice maltiness that seems to create balance and doesnt seem at all out of place. Mouthfeel is adequate. All-in-all, a very tasty brew. Recommended.

12 oz bottle at some random restaurant in Burlington.

Appearance : Hazy yellow with a big creamy and fluffy head. Lots of lacing.

Aroma : Lots of wheat. Some herbal notes.

Taste : Spicy and herbal with some wheat. A bit citrusy. Finish is a bit spicy with notes of wheat and herbs.

Overall : Nice and refreshing. Interesting herbal profile. With the yeast it gets much more yeasty and a bit too dusty. It was better without.
12oz bottle.  Full, bubbly head dissipates without lacing.  Aroma is spice and yeast.  Flavor is very nice, but far too light, and not very complex.

Pours a cloudy golden with a small white head. Aroma of citrusy hops, lemon peel, grapefruit. Flavor of citrusy light spicey hops and some yeastiness. Palate is light body with nice carbonation, crisp mouth feel. Finish is citrus, grapefruit, light hops with some spice, yeast, ending in some light bitterness. A nice and refreshing easy drinking brew.

On Tap at Bridge View Tavern.  This is my wifes current favorite beer and I cant blame her as this is delicious especially for the season.  pours a very pretty hazy yellow.  great carbonation and fruity aroma.  taste is of orange peel and wheat and is dry and crisp.  great.
Cloudy yellow in color... Citrus, floral, coriander, wheat and banana aroma... Flavor is suprisingly light... Wheaty taste and kinda watery... Not much on the palate... Not that impressive

Bottle. Very beautiful cloudy yellow pour with solid white head.

Aroma: Powerful orange and coriander along with a perfume of yeast, wheat and clove. Very well done.

Taste: Surprisingly bitter : mostly orange and lemon peel. Herbs, crispy wheat and belgian yeast wraps this one. I would have prefer a little more fruitiness.

Palate: Enjoyable dryness and lively carbonation. Unfortunately, the body is a little thin.

One of my favorite witbeer with Dominus Blanche, The Bruery Orchard White and Jolly Pumpkin Calabaza.

12 oz bottle.  Pours hazy golden with a small, short lived head.  Fruity, yeasty aroma with hints of floral hops.  Medium, crisp body.  Flavor is of citrus fruit, yeast, sweet malt and spicy hops.  Medium, fruity finish.  Nice wit.

Golden, light, slightly hazed pour with a large cap of white foam.  Has a nice, strong aroma on it, lemon zest, a slight creamsicle feel in the background, zippy coriander, toasty wheat, slightly tropical notes.  The flavor has more of the spice and lemon, a slight tang, and not as much of the creamy/tropical notes, though they are still there.  Light, refreshing body.

Pours a hazy gold with a medium white head. Aroma has notes of citrus, coriander, cloves, and yeasty bread.  Tastes of wheat, yeast, some citrus, coriander, and spice. Very crisp and light. A very good Belgian White.

Appearance:  very appetizing--cloudy, creamy gold with a nice smooth head.  Aroma:  light fruit/citrus, sharp pine, lots of cloves.  Taste:  subtle yet bright citrus fruit, pine, coriander, clove, pepper, creamy wheat.  Finish:  medium length and strong, yet fresh, clean and very refreshing.  Notes:  Great wheat beer; creamy yet crisp and very refreshing.  Could drink this every day.  Very complex.
On tap.  Came a cloudy pale yellow.  Average white head.  Aroma of citrus and wheat.  Tastes of wheat with a touch of lemon and spices. Smooth and refreshing.

Pours murky white (duh) with a moderately strong sweet and bitter citrus nose. Flavor is fairly light and malty for a witbier and a bit lower on bitter orange peel than expected as well. It is, however, pretty well balanced, with a big sweet malt and some bittering hops, especially on the finish. A little watery but a very solid beer.

Bottle. Pours bright and hazy straw yellow with moderate white head. Aroma of bubble gum, wheat, and spice. Flavor is wheat, clove, and bubblegum with a soft citrus flavor balancing it out. Moderate body with a light malt finish. True to style and a delightful example of whats good about wheat beers.
Had it in a 12 oz bottle.  Not a big fan of white beers and this one was on par with that. The wife loves em though.

Appearance: Pours a cloudy yellow color with a 1 finger frothy white head which dissipates quickly. Nice lacing throughout.

Smell: Very nice mix of spices and wheat with a bit of lemon and orange peel.

Taste: Nice spicy flavor up front with strong citrus notes. Very similar to the smell, which is a good thing. Slight hoppy bitterness at the finish.

Mouthfeel: Light-to-Medium bodied with a good amount of carbonation. Goes down very smooth.

Drinkability: High drinkability because it is so smooth. I could easily down several of these without any problem. Would be an ideal summer beer.

Overall: I would highly recommend this beer. Very good representation of the style.

12 oz from Total Wine Tampa.  Pours clear yellow with a soapy white head.  Nose is pepper, coriander, sweet citrus, and some sugar.  Flavor picks up some slight bitterness in the finish, but is most notable for its light body, refreshing qualities, and lemon zest, pepper, and coriander.  Pretty good overall, and a summer staple.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2011 Bottle about 1 year old. Slightly cloudy golden color with a touch of lace. Looks more like a blonde. Fruity aroma with honey, apricots, spice like ginger. Pleasant and mild. Light, dry flavor with honey, ginger, apricots. Dry finish with light bitterness. Interesting interpretation of the style. I guess it would be better fresh. Still nice, though.

Its 99 degrees, Im having brunch, and smoked salmon is on the menu. Who could resist this? Perhaps I should have, as wits really arent my thing, but I figured that I should at least sample this flagship offering from one of my favorite American breweries. The National poured this from a tap into a shaker, which was clearly the wrong glassware choice but nonetheless highlighted the ales unfiltered characteristics and lemonade-ish hue. The body was watery, the finish refreshing, and the flavor a mixture of oranges and bananas. In short, this was the perfect accompaniment to my brunch. Essentially, it is the beer version of a mimosa. Would I want another one? Only under similar circumstances. In other words, no matter how much I dislike wits, this beer does have a place ... even its a place that I only rarely visit.

Bottle. Poured a light cloudy yellow with a small creamy white head that was fully diminishing and had fair lacing. The aroma was very mild of grainy malts, light herbal hops and a strong moldy yeast with notes of coriander, pepper and citrus(orange peel I believe). It tasted moderately bitter at first for a wheat ale and ended with a light bitter yeasty flavor that had hints of spices and orange peel with the flavor not lasting long at all. Mouthfeel was light in body and creamy in texture with a nice soft carbonation. Overall a nice creamy wheat ale, actually nicely surprising.

The beer pours a hazy yellow color with a white head. The beer is cloudy but clears up after it has sat for a white. The aroma is coriander and orange peel. The flavor is more of the same with the addition of a little bit of lemon and yeast. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
One of my favorite beers.  It has a crisp flavor, pale orange color, and a fruity aroma.
Draft at the American Craft Beer Fest in Boston.  Poured a white-yellow.  Lots of yeast and spice.  Very well balanced.  Very drinkable.
Flight from Blind Lady Ale House. Very cloudy, light color, fine taste a little yeasty but good.

On tap at Tribes Alehouse. Cloudy golden with a big, frothy white head. Decent lacing. The aroma was mostly yeasty banana and clove. The flavor was the same, good though. Nice carbonation and finish. Solid wit.

On tap at Churchkey, 6/5/2010.  Pours a cloudy, hazy whitish yellow, with a thin white head.  Aroma has some old bitter citrus peel and some wheat, but overall is quite weak.  Flavor has lots of yeast and a bit of bitter citrus, OK but again a bit boring.  Finish has somewhat bitter citrus and wheat.

Pours up a nice cloudy white, and I mean cloudy. There are little trails in it. The head is nice and foamy. Theres not too much aroma.  The flavor is very subtle.  Its almost nonexistent. How can you not like this beer, though? I guess if you like really complex beers, because his one is not. Fortunately I do not like really complex beers. So hooray for Allagash. This is one of the first beers I had on tap that wasnt Miller lite or some other crap. It has a special place in my liver.

Hazy pale straw color; Light to medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, citrus, & coriander; Flavor of wheat, malt, yeast, citrus (notably lemon & orange), coriander, and spice; Nicely balanced; Overall, quite spicy - and very good.

(draught at Meddlesome Moth) opaque very bright yellow, lasting creamy head that is oily and coats the glass quite nicely. Great looking beer. Nose of coriander, fresh ground pepper, grass, and lemon. Taste of huge coriander, ground white pepper, wheat, and subtle lemon zest. Creamy light body that is oily and pretty refreshing. A coriander bomb but aside fro
 that quite drinkable!

pours typical white in appearance. Sweet and "coriander" flavored with the right amount of hops. Clearly one of the best in its category for a reason. Clean finish and the right amount of weight for the style.
Sample. Hazy yellow with white head. Flavour is wheat, yeast, fruit and slight hop.

A-pours a hazy yellow liquid with a tight creamy head.

S-the nose starts with earthy notes and grain.  lemon, banana, corriander fade in at the back.

T-the taste follows the nose with a little more peppery spice.  good grainy tastes up front with earthy notes as well.  the lemon and banana come in next with the peppery spice, clove, and corriander coming in at the back.

M-very smooth and creamy on the palate, medium syrupy body with a fair amount of carbonation but a little lacking for the full syrupy texture of the beer.

D-this is very refreshing and has a solid feel.  earthy and grainy with a good balance of banana and spice.  very solid wheat beer.

Pleasant aroma with biscuit and yeast going with little spice. Pouring into a large wine glass left little of the white head (probably a bad poor on my part). Taste is perfect for me in a white ale. The spice note are very subdued and blend well with biscuity malt and wheat character of it. Im not a fan of zealous use of coriander so this beer really pleases the palate. It has a nice lingering aftertaste to it as well.

Definitely the best white/wit ale I have tried.

Served from a 12 oz bottle via RateBrackets Winnings from aracauna. The appearance is straw yellow with a nice pure white head. Very strong aromas are bready yeasts, coriander, herbs. Flavors are very refreshing with wheat, herbal spice, a touch of orange. Mouth is lighter bodies with a drying finish.

12oz bottle.
Light hazy straw with a small head. 
On the citrus-end of the white beer spectrum. Slightly nutty and a little doughy as well. Clean...lightly sweet (a little too much for my tastes), perhaps a little sour and just a touch of clean bitterness on the finish.  
A good beer, but nothing standout in my opinion -- especially at the price.

12 oz bottle Wegmans. Almost a clear yellow with sediments floating about. Aromas of lemon, slight caramel, slight banana, slightly skunky(may have a bad bottle), spiced ginger. Flavors of light ginger, yeasts, slightly grassy, light lemon. The flavors are all light but well balanced out. Slightly sweet, lightly crisp, balanced, slightly dry, refreshing. For a light belgian, this beer gives a great balance and solid pitch to hit the spot for sessions. Unfortunately its expensive (overpriced), at least where I can buy it.

Very light malt aroma with hints of sulfur.  Appears a radiant yellow with nich thick haze and a thick white crown of foam.  Taste is interestingly tart, sour, acidic.  Didnt not notice any strong citrus notes.  Can taste breadiness of the wheat.  Very prickly and spritzy mouthfeel with a long warm, malty finish.

Cloudy yellow-orange with virtually no head. Citrus flavor, slight hops, and floral notes. Like all Allagash I have tried, a very smooth, balanced beer. This is an excellent beer for a hot Summer day. tasted @ 56.5°F.

Pours a bright, yet very hazy lemon yellow with thick frothy, egg white like head. Aroma is coriander, citrus and pepper. Flavor is citrus and coriander and a spicy finish. Body is creamy yet light with a lot of effervescence.

This was an amazing wit. Very flavorful and drinkable. The citrus really came through on this one with some nice spices. Very well balanced flavors.  The subtleties are very delicate with this beer, and I could drink this all day.
On tap at Armsby Abbey. Very cloudy white with a white head served in an Allagash glass. One of the better white beers I have tasted. Good blend citrus and spice and very refreshing.

12 oz bottle pour. nice murky gold color with a medium frothy pure white head with some light lacing.  aroma is heavy on the wheat with some lemon peel and a fair amount of peppery spice.  good full creamy mouthfeel with a good bit of fizziness.  flavor is mellow wheat with some citrus notes and great pepper spiciness.  lemon peel and biscuit flavors come through.  nice and refreshing on a warm spring day.  not a big fan of wheats but this is one of the best ive had.

A perfect witbier.  Pours a cloudy straw yellow into the glass with a nice white head.  Aroma is slightly spicy with some light coriander and grain.  Flavor is a wonderful balance of coriander and the belgian yeast strain.  I cant stress enough the balance.  To me coriander often dominates the flavor of a witbier, this is superb.  Light and refreshing with a medium body.
Pours a nice murky golden color, medium head.  Had a musty/zesty aroma.  Taste was very lemony, and smooth.

Allagash White Belgian Wheat Beer--1999 12 oz. Bottle.  5.50% ABV.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Very cloudy golden white color.  Light Belgian aroma mixed with delicate spice.  Rich thick yeasty body balances belgian citrus tendancies and carries initial flavor through to light spicy finish.  Sampled 4/7/1999.

12 oz bottle poured into heff glass. Pours a cloudy straw yellow with a beautiful fluffy white head. Yeasty aroma. Mouthfeel is moderate with nice carbonation. Taste is refreshing with a nice banana tone to it from the yeast. Great example of a belgian wit beer
Bottle.  Light malts with a good amount of spice, some doughy yeast.  A good solid brew.  Crisp and refreshing even if it is a bit thin and lacking complexity.
on tap at gman fort worth    hazy straw color in appearance smell of spices citrus. very cabonated kinda left a metalic finish but not to bad everything else was pleasant
Draft at Busboys and Poets in DC. Pours hazy white with a medium sized white head. Flavor is spice, corriander, yeast. Solid wit, but still not much to work with in the style.

Sample pour at a local beer tasting event from a 12 ounce bottle. Cloudy pale yellow, bubbly effervescence with a light white head. Fruity, floral and citrusy aroma. Citrus orange & lemon flavors, but not hoppy. I picked up some spice flavors like coriander and cloves. Highly carbonated, medium bodied. A nice beer to drink, especially in warm weather. Somewhat light and refreshing and what you would expect for the style.

Bought in a bottle at Total Wine in Springfield, VA. Tasted alongside Celis White and two weeks after Hoegaarden. Disappointing compared with both. Much less coriander and orange peel aroma than either Celis or Hoegaarden. More watery.
On tap at the Fort Worth Gingerman.  Pours an opaque yellow thats almost green with a small white head.  Aroma is lemon, banana, and grain.  Taste is yeast, bread, banana, citrus.

Hazy yellow pour with a foamy, white head.  Bright zesty citrus aroma with some distinct pepperyness, some soft bready yeast and a dash of grains of paradise.  The flavor is moderately sweet, with some sticky orange and lemon juice notes, yeasty bread grains in the middle and finishing with grains of paradise, clove, banana and slight honey.  Creamy, medium full body with moderate carbonation.

For me, this is the standard bearer for Belgian white ales. Its a locally produced beer (Portland, ME) with immense popularity that can easily be explained when you taste it. The smooth herby citrus flavor so often associated with this type of beer is at its absolute smoothest and most natural. Perhaps only seconded by the flavor is the wonderful full head and the aroma you can enjoy while waiting for the beautiful golden cloud to simmer down. This is simply an enjoyable experience.

Let me preface this rating by saying I dont care for Wheat / White / Weiss beers, so my opinion is skewed from the get-go.  Low aroma, cloudy straw colored with very little white head.  Flavor is sweet / sour with a little citrus and a lot of cloves.  Thin mouthfeel with too much acid in the aftertaste.  Im not saying its poison, just not my style.

Aromas of banana and clove and a hint of orange. Attractive appearance, a looking white. Taste is smooth and refreshing, again hints of orange and banana, a little spicy on the finish. The carbonation is very nice and lively, a perfect beer for a nice day.

A- amazing. very cloudy pale yellow body. Could see clouds swirling around when I set my glass down. Pours with a thick white head that fades to a thin beautiful head.

S- smells good. Distinctive wheat and yeast smells up front with spices and citrus in the background.

T- similar to smell. wheat and yeast up front with some citrus and spice in the background. very clean but slightly bitter.

P- light carbonation with light body. very smooth.

O- the taste and mouthfeel leave you craving more. very drinkable. easy to enjoy.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-10-2007 00:45:08

Tap at Eureka Burger. Rating #1016. Going off memory here, hazy yellow with a nice white head. Aroma was light citrus and wheat. Flavor was very light, a little orange (citrus), very drinkable but not my thing to often. (1151)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: pours a hazy yellow with small head.  A easy and typical belgian white, reminds me of hoegaarden.

Pours a cloudy, lemony white. Like a light lemonade. Minimal snow white head that recedes quickly with no lacing. Aroma is kind of weak. Hints of lemon and spice. Flavor is very lemony. Crisp flavor with a citrus finish. No bitterness, but a finish of spice. Light mouth feel. Smooth with minimal carbonation. Just enough to tickle the tongue. Overall, an interesting beer. Refreshing and would go down great on a hot day. Not sure if I could session these though, the lemon may get to me.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2010 Strong belgian aroma. Has a strong barnyard belgian scent, some citrus, sweetness. Aroma is impressive. Very nice light yellow hazy color. Standard belgian flavors, but more. Much sweeter than I am used to for this style, but not cloying. Citrus is also strong and lingers. Strong belgian flavor, barnyard? Spicy and cloves. Medium body that coats the tongue well. Overall a good solid beer. Many complex flavors that come together fairly well. 4 pack is just right as you dont hammer these down.

Poured from bottle. Big aromas here; barnyardy, doughy, a touch of tangerine. Pours a cloudy yellow with persistent head; the head sets up in places like meringue and leaves consistent, thick lace. The flavor is excellent; more substance than Im used to from a wit, with savory elements that almost run into the hard cheese territory. Palate is spritzy, but with a heavier overtone that keeps it mellowed out on the finish with just the bare hint of hops bitterness. In short, a good beer, if not a little atypical for the style.

Hazy yellow colour, small white head. Aroma is rather papery and fruity along with some slight notes of wheat. Flavour is wheat, fruits, nectar, cardboard and some mild notes of spices/herbs. OK, but a bit thin for being a really good Witbier.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a yellow cloud with almost no white head.  Smells of wheat, yeast, honey, some spices.  Flavor is crisp and palate cleansing, very drinkable, nice carbonation, spices noticeable.  This beer is good, but i dont understand why it only comes in a 4-pack for the price of a 6er, its not above and beyond hoegaarden, which is a better deal, especially being an import.
Average wit. Good color and aromas of lemon with a little sweetness from the Belgian yeast. Good sessionable beer.
floral, citrusy flavors dominate this outstanding white beer.  Serve with a lemon for maximum effect.
Really solid beer, and Im not a fan of this style. Beer was very well balanced, not too yeasty or sweet, very drinkable.

Bottled at Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm. Pours out in a shady pale golden colour with a  with a rich steady white head. Mild aroma yet quite dry and solid of yeast, coriander and dried oranges. Fairly light-bodied with rounded but still solid notes (for the style) of sweet lemon-pastilles, Seville oranges with a well-rounded coriander bite. Creamy and light mouthfeel. Long rounded refreshing finish of mild lemon, coriander, wheat and yeast. One of the better Wits out there.

Had on tap at Valhalla Table.  Pours with a slight white head, cloudy orange, slight carbonation, little to no lacing.  Smells of oranges, hops, and wheat.  A light, easily drinkable beer.  Tastes of citrus and spice, paired perfectly with my boar sausage and sauerkraut.

Bottle bought to try to convert a Blue Moon (by Coors)  fan. Color is cloudy pale straw color with a thin layer of white dissipating head, spotty lacing. Nose is orange citrus and spices. Flavor is sweet wheat and cereal malts with citrus hop flavors, hints of light spices such as coriander and cinnamon,  finishes slightly sweet. Medium body, mild carbonation, slick texture. A sweet and tasty witbier full of citrus and wheat tones, great gateway craft beer for the style that is smooth and easy drinking, see you later Blue Moon!

I may have simply gotten a bad bottle here. Pale and cloudy with a small head. A white should raise a bigger head, so points off there. Aroma is overwhelmingly sour. Almost like a lambic, but with some yeasty earthiness. Flavor is not too bad. Very mild and drinkable, yet spicy. Very drinkable, but lacking something.
Pours a pale yellow with a slight white head. Aroma is of orange, hops, wheat. Taste is about the same, rather watery, but very drinkable.

Draft at Tellers of Hyde Park, Cincinnati.  Pours a murky golden-brown with almost no head, but whats there is white and leaves a small ring around the edge.  Plenty of sediment floating around.  Not pretty-looking.  Aroma of wheat, orange citrus, coriander, grains, and yeast.  Flavor follows suit well, and the orange citrus notes increase in both as the beer warms.  Also notes of wheat, yeast, spices, malts, and grains.  Medium-bodied with light carbonation and a wheaty mouthfeel.  Quick finish.  Something hints at being tart or sour but is restrained.  Not bad at all for the style.
Slightly hazy yellow in the glass.  Aromas of citrus, spice, and wheat.  Light and crisp on the palate with a clean finish.  Very enjoyable.
pours hazy golden with medium white head. aroma is crisp citrus, some spice, sweet sugars, yeast. drinks light and fruity with some citrus, spices, candied sugars, a bit of sweet malt, and yeast.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a cloudy bright, pale yellow.  Very nice nose.  Strong notes of clover and dandelion.  Overall very reminiscent of wild flowers and early summer.  Definite notes of coriander and orange peel.  Hints of sweet honey in the flavor, though simultaneously surprisingly dry.  Very smooth.  One of my favorites in this style.

Pours a cloudy golden yellow color, decent fluffy but rapidly dissipating head. Nice rich flavors that consist of citrusy lemon and orange.  Aroma has hints of spices (coriander, clove, nutmeg). Crisp, dry mouthfeel and dry finish.  Very drinkable and refreshing.

On tap at Blind Lady. Pours a hazy gold, with a small bubbly white head. Light sour aroma, of yeast, wheat, spices, and lemon. Taste of spices, wheat, and lemony citrus. Lingering spiciness that ends watery. Not bad.

Bottle:  Pours a cloudy, whitish gold color with a massive, fluffy white head.  Not only is a massive blob of fluffy white head, but very persistent and lasting.  Lots of sticky lacing.  Strong aroma is spicy with corriander, orange peel, cloves, and yeast.  First sip reveals a crisp, wheaty flavor with a moderate spicey background.  More cloves, corriander, and faint citrus.  Light yeast.  Very clean and crisp.  Very nice and overall quite enjoyable.
UPDATED: FEB 19, 2011 Citrus-y sweet, wheaty. Straw colored, cloudy, yeasty, crisp. Delicious, a tiny bitter linger after. Classic.
Decent white beer. Nothing to really grab on to though.. Some hints of fruit and wheat. Goes down smooth and isnt heavy. No lingering aftertaste...

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2010 Cold in a pint glass.  Pours very cloudy with little head and not much lacing.  Color is very light and is basically a diluted yellow.  Aroma is mostly grapefruit/citrus, bread, and yeast with some pine in the background.  Taste is wonderful!  Sweet with lemon zest in the front, malt as it sits, and then a very mild hop bitterness.  Its light, thin, crisp, and tremendously refreshing on the plate and works wonderfully with sharp cheese and sweet fruit.  This is one of my personal favorites that I would highly recommend for fans of the style.  I dont think its a ideal example of type but it tastes great - and thats what Im after.
Poured cloudy, and the flavor was of honey with lemon and other citrus flavors.  The finish was slightly tart.  I was surprised by this beer and thought it was great.
Bottled.  Thin white head when poured with a cloudy body.  Aroma of citrus and wheat.  You can taste the spice brewed in the beer with the hints of citrus with the wheat.

Pours a cloudy blond.  Decent head and nice lacing.  Smell is light citrus, hay, and yeast.  There is a slight metallic aroma but Im guessing its from the bottle cap.  The taste is light and crisp.  There is a nice balance of citrus, spice, and yeast. Wheat comes through on the finish.  There is nothing exciting about this beer but it is very refreshing and quite drinkable.
Bottle. Pour was golden with one finger of white head. taste of citrus, with a bit of bitter taste as well.  Lots of wheat, making this a very enjoyable brew.

Light golden body that is slightly translucent.  Nice white fully head.  Strong sour citrus aroma with a nice grassy character and some light grainy notes.  Citrus and some light grass in the flavor, only slightly sour and bitter.  Mouth feel is nice and light with some slight carbonation.  Feels a little watery though.  Finish continues the sour citrus character of this beer.  Overall, quite enjoyable.
A good solid white beer.  Nice flavor..not too much head, but good flavor and good mouthfeel.

lemon is one of the strongest scents - the appearance is a wonderfully pale yellow, a unique hue - taste is quite pleasant; lightly sour, with a sweet finish - palate is a little on the syrupy side - tasty white beer, nuff said.

355 mL bottle.  Hazy orange-gold with a small but sticky white head.  Lots of honey and citrus, and a little spice in the aroma.  Flavour is fairly typical - perhaps sweeter than some.  Could use a little more spice.  Nice body for the style.

Bottled. Cloudy and looks like white grape juice. Aroma is banana, citrus, yeast, and variety of spices. Flavor is the same but add grape. Finish is long and leaves spice on tongue-- mostly coriander. Very carbonated and alive.

bottle.  pours a hazy yellow with an average white head... big citrus, yeast and banana aromas... light to medium body with more citrus up front and a light spice.  very soft and has average carbonation... dry quick finish with yeast and a bit of pepper.... slight bitterness as well.  really nice Belgian White... extremely drinkable and full of flavor.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine in Chesapeake.  Golden pour with a white head.  Belgian yeast, coriander, and light citrus aroma.  Actually a bit of barnyard funkiness as well. Great flavor; upfront wheat with no orange or lemon in the way.  Witbiers are simple so there isnt much to say.  This is one of the best ones I have tried.

Bottle (in NZ). Really good this. Looks nice in the glass, cloudy straw yellow with a pure white head. A great sourness that cuts through any potential sweetness. Peppery and lemony.  Perfect for a post run super...
Hazy yellow orange, with a thin white head.  Aroma is sweet and spicy with phenolics.  Taste is the same, with citrus peel and clove into the finish with a drying phenolic presence.  $2/12oz
20th July 2008. Pale cloudy beer. Dry and spciy. A little wheat beer fruitiness struggles against the dry spice. Palate is a tad dry. Not bad though.
A cloudy golden-white beer with a small head. Has a light grainy scent with some citrus. The taste is very clean & refreshing with a thin watery finish.

From notes: Pours cloudy hazy golden body with white thick head. Aroma has smooth aroma, some spices, vanilla and some wet grass. Flavour has wheat and spices, some citrus. Feels like drinking tahini paste. Somehow this doesn´t feel good even though all the right things are there. Could I have had a bad bottle?

Tried some of this on draft. Pretty good as far as Belgian wheat beers go. A bit more sour/tart than I would like but still good. Pours a pale yellow with a fine white head. Spicy, fruity aroma. Flavor is somewhat yeasty, with notes of pepper and citrus fruits. Light bodied and crisp on the finish.
Bottled and available all over town. Light bodied, very drinkable. Belgian style wit beer. Little bit of banana.
Draught at Walters Foods. Strikingly dry and a little bracing, I like the hips in this. Nice body of wheat malt.

Pours pale golden yellow with a nice white head. The aroma is wheaty, lemony and spicy. The flavor is excellent. Complex spice character with citrus notes in there, but the interesting thing was the unique cream of wheat flavor followed by a dry finish. one of my favorite belgian wits.

Bottle. 12 oz. Pours light golden with a foamy, white head. Aroma of hops, earth, wheat, citurs, hay, and hints os soil. Medium to light bodied with a crisp, tight mouthfeel. Quick, tight finish. Good witbier.

Pours a very cloudy yellow with a medium head and good lace. The aroma is bready and yeasty. The flavor is very dry for the style with plenty of spiciness and some breadiness, this certainly gets bonus points for dryness and originality.
Very similar to Franziskaner!  Head vanishes quickly but the flavor is crisp and the carbo stays.  Nice fruity scents and taste on back palate.  Beer is smooth and goes down easy.

Honey notes, some spice, citrus, the ubiquitous banana / clove, yet still a little bland. Had this after a couple bigger beers and I think I would have liked it a little better with a clean palate. That said, Ive had far worse wits.

Bottle.  Light gold pour, cloudy with a fading white head.  Very saison-feel, almost dont taste the wheatiness.  Nice spiciness and earthy tones...grassy.  Some honey notes, it seems...I want to say perhaps some coriander too?  Very nice, right up there with the best of the style.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2009 Arrowhead Market, Deep Creek, MD - With a perfectly cloudy golden body and a spicy, clovish scent, this White is one of the best. A yeasty, classic Belgian wheat taste permeates the tongue while a well carbonated, yet slightly light body gives way to a sweet and dry finish.

Poured a straw yellow with billowing white head. great lacing. 
Nose was of lavender, lemon, bread. 
Taste was very flavorful, lots of different hop flavors for a white, very clean esthers, slight spiciness, floral, and clean wheat body. Very good american representation.
Bready, with some nice fruit tones.  Light and very smooth with some carbonation.  While tasty and full, it is rather one-dimensional.  Still, it is far from disappointing.

Bright hay-yellow with a moderate bubbly white head, decent lacing. Nose is dominated by wheat, bubblegum, and lemon. Sweet flavor reminiscent of cream of wheat, also some light citrus and grain. Thin body, decent carbonation, short finish. Nothing extraordinary, whether right or wrong.

Pour from 12 oz bottle leaves a thin white head that quickly fades
to a ring and pretty good lacing. Now, I tend to defy the label instructions about swirling the bottle to whiten up the pour. Without the mixed in yeast, the body looks like chamomile tea. Aromas of mandarin oranges and fresh white bread. Lemon, grapes, grapefruit, melon are all there on the tongue, but mellow together. Not very complex, but a decent domestic representative of the style.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm, 10 Sep 2009) Cloudy yellow colour with frothy, white head. Fruity, wheaty nose with lemon peel, apricots and spices. Fruity taste with notes of citrus, apricots, wheat and a spicy finish with coriander and Seville orange. Slightly below medium body, balanced sweetness. Fresh and tasty witbier.

On tap at Red Coat in Royal Oak, MI.  Pours a nice cloudy yellow golden color and a bubbly white head.  There is a large aroma to this beer, big yeast and fruity notes and banana and clove and citrus.  The flavor is smooth and complex.  There is definite citrus flavors to the yeasty bitterness and banana/clove flavor. The palate was bigger than expected and complex throughout.  Very enjoyable.

This bottle was only six dollars and I felt like that is a good deal on a 750 of Belgian style ale. This is a really light yellow and almost white in my snifter with a puffy white head. The smell is spicy and not unlike most witbiers. The taste is very good, easy to drink, nice citrus flavors and some subtle spicy, peppery taste. This is one of the better wits I have had, I really like how subtle the flavor is and how easy to drink it is. There is some phenolic flavor but it does not detract from the beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-12-2007 17:06:45

Bright cloudy yellow golden color.  Nice thick head on this one.  Aroma is is full of yeast and malts with some spices in the background (I believe I can pick up some cloves).   Good body on this brew. Taste is full of yeast and citrus.  Has a little bit of lemon peels in the back end.  Aftertaste has a little bit of a bite.  Im not a fan of this style, but this beer is amazing!
A superb aperetif beer,  bright, fresh, with fruit and light spice complexity.  not thin like many in this category.

Had this several times over the weekend while in Maine. Great session beer. Nice lemon citrus flavor without being in your face. Great drinkable beer and if your looking for a go with anything pint this is your beer. Nice yeast compliment with this grain bill for sure! Good job..Great beer.
Draft pours a hazy light mustard color. Light lemon citrus a faint peppery nose.  Bitter lemon rind comes out in the flavor a Very solid wit but just a little to much lemon for my taste.
This was slightly under a bit in spices, but extremely refreshing, drinkable, and delicious.  One of my favorite whites.

First let me say a witbier is not my best beer but this one was not all that bad. Pours hazy yellow and the aroma is strong but on the sharp side.Flavor has some citrus but is over powered by yeast and grain. It has an average palet.

12oz, tasted at brewery. Pours off yellow, very cloudy.  Theres acid in the aroma, maybe from unmalted wheat?  Theres a slight grain bitterness, not as sweet as I was expecting.  Wonderful full body but not too much.  Yay beer!

From a 12oz bottle into a pint glass.  Pours with lots of white, puffy head.  Smells of lemon, orange and spices.  Taste is very similar with wheat and yeast thrown into the meld.  Nice and refreshing.  Very true to style although a bit expensive compared to other equally as good wits.  Would drink again.

12 ounce bottle purchased at Holiday Wine Cellar.  Pours a hazy pale yellow with moderate white head composed of especially small bubbles.  Aroma of wheat, fresh and under ripe lemon, and a nice spice note.  Much of the same in the flavor with wheat, citrus-y hops, and coriander.  Watery and thin mouthfeel with a slightly dry finish.  Nice and refreshing, but far from exciting.

This is by no means a bad drink, but apparently we (Jenn and I) do not care for Belgian Whites that much.  As far as Belgian Whites go, however, it is a good one (our experience with them is limited).
Draft. Nice and easy to drink belgian white. Smooth, some lemon citrus, yeast and a bit of spice. Refreshing.
Tap at Bonn Lair.  Pretty orange-yellow color with a thick white head.  Slight grassy nose with corriander.  Spicey taste -- heavy corriander -- more than I like, but a full flavor.

12oz bottle.  Poured hazy medium golden with a sticky cap of white head.. lots of sediment suspended in there.  The aroma picked up toasted wheaty notes and spices (coriander and orange zest come to mind) along with what seemed to be oaky character.. more of the citrus as it warmed up.  The flavor had pale, rather non-descript malts at the core with citrus zest and spices surrounding.. dry, grainy, and a little cardboardey.. a tad sour (in a good way) on the rather quick finish.  Light-medium-bodied with moderate carbonation on the palate.. grainy and sour.. man.. this wasnt bad, but it tasted like it was old.

Had this at a beer tasting at Wine World in NA. Really liked it but I dont think as much as I like Hoegaarden. Probably need to drink them side by side, but they are very similar....but Allagash costs more.
Had this many times, finally rating it... a nice light Belgian Wit... crisp with hints of spice

Draft at Internation Beer Garten (Lutz, FL).  Pours a cloudy lemon yellow color with a small white head.  Nice, light aroma of citrus, spices, and yeast.  Good, clean flavor with a slight tartness in the aftertaste.  A decent witbier.
nose is ultra clean, perhaps a splash of sea water. flavor is lemon and light yeast. gritty but passes clean quite quickly. clean...refreshing...thirst quenching...but almost devoid of subtleties.

This was a very poor effort.

I drank this from the tap.  It was a pale cloudy gold with no head.

It has no smell at all!!!!!!!! taste was decent, basically a poor mans blue moon.  A very poor effort.

Maybe I just encountered a bad pour, but this was pretty watery and weak compared to other widely available witbiers (Hoegaarden or St. Bernardus Blanche, for instance). I wouldnt try this one again.

Very nice beer here.  Very user friendly to both geek and newb alike.  Something for everyone with this one.  The aroma is light citrus, clove, banana and wet grains.  Flavor is yeasty, citrusy, lightly herbal and spicy with a strong apple undercurrent.  Body is a cloudy, light yellow/golden color with a very nice thick white head.

The pour was a slightly cloudy golden color with a short, white head.  Spotty lace.  The aroma was Belgian yeast, spice and light citrus.  The flavor was wheat, yeast, spice and some citrus.  The mouthfeel was thin to medium and clean.  Enjoyable.  Easy drinking.
1 liter corked bottle, says "batch #70" on the label.  I enjoy the style and found this to be one of the best examples.
Bottle. Pours a light golden with a lasting white head. Aroma is light with perfume notes as well as some spices. Flavor is sweet, apple notes and some underlying spices. Pleasant.

En fût: Du pain, un peu de gazon, de la banane, de la gomme à mâcher, une femme en bikini et un peu de clou de girofle sont les éléments constitutifs de cette bière en ce qui concerne son appréciation gustative et olfactive. Robe jaune très pâle. Corps très léger.

Taste test with Paulaner, Terrapin Sunray, and Allagash White. Aroma - Wheat, citrus, light clove, banana. Appearance - Dark yellow, hazy, thin white head with little retention but good lacing (best lacing of 3). Flavor - Citrus, wheat, light clove, very light spice. Palate - light body, thin feel, lively. Overall - I taste the most wheat and spice with this of the 3.  Good beer but I can only give this one 2nd in taste and a tie in value with Terrapin.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2009 On tap in Portland, ME. Had a white, good-sized head. Body was hazy with a dark-yellow color. Nice lacing. Aroma was strong with citrus (orange), but not at all overpowering. Nice on the palate, slightly creamy with average carbonation. Great flavor - citrusy, with a medium-lasting finish. A great witbier that was enjoyed on a sunny deck on the waterfront.

I cant believe Id never rated this beer before!  Ive stated that Wittekerke (though poorly thought of on this site) is my favorite witbier, although its status is definitely threatened by this beer.  This is extremely balanced for a witbier, and doesnt seem intended for the Blue Moon/Spotted Cow drinker who craves something extremly sweet.  I thought the flavor was very pleasant but not over-powering.

As stated in other reviews, the color is straw-yellow and cloudy, with a modicum of white head.  Aroma is yeasty, lightly citrus-sweet, with a not-obnoxious amount of cloviness.  Flavor is more of the same but with the addition of a nice maltiness that seems to create balance and doesnt seem at all out of place.  Mouthfeel is adequate.

All-in-all, a very tasty brew.  Recommended.  My Dad brought this over to my house - believe he bought it at the Class VI store at Fort Belvoir, VA.
