12 oz bottle purcahsed at Monaghans. Poured a classic hazy golden/yellow with a large bright white  foamy head. Aroma of wheat, coriander, pepper, grass, lemon and some spicy pepper. Palate was very quaffable with a light medium palate, slight carbonation and an overall smooth feel. Flavor was spicy with nice accent on the coriander but not too much that it distracts from the fresh wheat and grassy flavors. This is a very nice beer for an underappreciated style.

Served on tap in a pint glass. The beer is a light yellow flaxen color that was almost clear. There was a nice white head that laid lightly on top. It smells light, fresh and citrus with a tiny bit of yeast but in no way overpowering.

There is definitely a bit of citrus and sweetness to the beer. It has a perfume like aftertaste that stays in on the tongue. 
The beer goes down very light but with very fine carbonation but as it warms up it seems to expand in the mouth leaving a foam as it dissolves in your mouth. 
It goes down nicely and is light and refreshing but it does expand in the mouth somewhat as it warms up.

Very good White beer.  Very true to style.  Very similar to Hoegarden, but the differences are there to be tasted, in a complimentary way.  I put this on tap on my back porch each summer.  Gone through two sixtels so far and it is only August 18th.

From bottle. Very cloudy sunshine yellow with very thin white head. Aroma is yeasty and some banana. Reminds me of a hefe. Some hoppy bitterness on my tongue when tasting. Very spicy and prickly mouthfeel. Decent citrus (orange/lemon?) flavor in the long savor. Leaves no aftertaste.

Poured a beautiful cloudy yellow with BIG foamy head. This was one of my fav witbiers yet. Spicy, sweet, malty, little hoppy taste in there, yeasty. This had it all going on. Most complex witbier Ive had and this was very, very good. Ill have to try more Allagash offerings.

Batch #31 the bottle says. Pop the cork and pour it into a nice big open mouth chalice. Nice hazy yellow straw color liquid fills the glass and a big thick foamy head covers the top. The foam slowly settles and covers the sides of the glass in a sticky layer of lace. Big sweet wheat malt sweetness breaks through up front and it closely followed by a big kick of yeasty banana filling the nose. Just a touch of lemon and a hint of orange peel round out the aroma. Wonderful. Smooth and slightly sweet wheat malt fills the mouth. Big and juicy it is soon followed by a wonderful yeast note with great banana flavor coating the palate. More juicy sweetness and a bit of lemon come in. Just makes your mouth water. Big of juicy melon even comes into the mix a bit. On the aftertaste theres just a hint of woodsy oak and a bit of dry sweetness. Smooth from start to finish. Wonderfully balanced and amazingly easy to drink. More please.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2008 12oz bottle. Cloudy golden with a large, billowy head. Aroma is sharp wheat, coriander, orange/citrus, light spice, and yeast. Taste is sharp wheat, yeast, spicy and earthy hops, and a bit of coriander and citrus. Finish is mildly sour and/or tart. Nice example, but fairly typical.
A fine Belgian White, if you like Blue Moon and you see this beer, it is a step up. Well done, Allagash
On tap at a pub on mulberry street.  Good.  Very delicious summer beer.  Full flavored and refreshing.
UPDATED: MAY 12, 2008 Light and spicy beer, I wasnt too impressed either time I tried it; there are many other white beers out there that beat this hands down.
big bottle. minimal nose.  cloudy light golden pour.  light frothy with hings of spice.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2008 Been waiting to taste this high percentile witbier, this is one of my favorite styles. I love it when the label has the hypnotizing pour method and directions.  Great appearance in a big clear glass. A little more hay colored than many witbiers. Aroma is a little sour in this short stubby twist off bottle. Initially the smell is a little musty.but once poured  In the glass the aroma clears and is more volatile.  Good creamy  microbubble fizz. Flavor is thoroughly enjoyable. Very little if any bitterness in this brew.  As you drink a mild  impression marks its spot on the back of the throat that I hesitate to call bitter. Perhaps just a little malt bite, I dont know. Good flavor for a witbier above 5% hides the alky well.  Overall, just a plain good example of this enjoyable style, simply great. Certainly one of the better wheatbeers in my repertoire. Certainly as good as Pax and Ommegang. Not quite on par with East End wit and Hoegaarden. Better than sammy adams wit.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: bottle.  nice cloudy pale yellow appearance.  just what you look for in a witbier.  the head faded rather quickly but the clove and coriander aroma is there.  quite a bit of carbonation but it doesnt detract form the taste. the unique element that allagash has added is a mild bitter which i havent come across in the whites that ive tried.  very nice.  it gives it a crisp, refreshing edge that is sometimes lacking in this style.  balances the sweet banana and spice well.  definitely worth picking up.

Poured from bottle...very carbonated...nice white head...color is yellow cream, nice and hazy.  Aroma is of lemon and citrus, very appealing. Very smooth drink.  The carbonation is in the front of this one.  Very drinkable and very tasty.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2007 Hazy pale yellow pour with a huge bright white head. Nose is spicy and lemony. Flavor starts lightly sweet with some citrus and wheat followed by a light fruityness and finishing lightly dry and slightly tart. Light bodied and creamy with fizzy carbonation.

Orange, lemon and corriander.  Dense mouthfeel.  High carbonation is prickly, balancing the mouthfeel.  Not as tart and refreshing as I expect from wheat.  A little of that diaper flavor I get from corriander.  Tasty, well done traditional white, but nothing that excites me.  Good for refreshment on a hot day, or paired with the right meal, but not a standout beer.

12oz bottle, pours a cloudy straw yellow color, great big white head. i guess you can say this is a lot like all the other american belgian witbiers but as others have said this has a great smoothness to it, great mouthfeel, im a big fan of this style.

Its a pretty good beer.  I saw the rating before drinking the beer and expected a little more. The last beer I had before this was Vuuve witbier and I liked that more.  Its smoother than many whites and I would have no problem drinking a 6 of them tonight.  A typical American Belgian White.

I dont get it, I truly dont get.  Why, in the name of all things holy, is this beer rated at 3.5+?  Dont believe the hype, just because this is a microbrew from a radical west coast brewery doesnt make it a great, or even good beer.  I didnt notice any subtle hints of spice.  In fact, the finish was almost non existent and left my palate with a bland, and strange aftertaste.  This is my first Allagash beer, so I am not suggesting that these folks dont have any good beers in their line-up, just not this one.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008 Tap @ Publick House, Brookline, MA.  Pours a hazy yellow color with a frothy white head.  Aroma is a mix of citrus, honey, spice, and other fruit.  Taste is roughly the same, though the flavor is slightly weak and there is a definite acidic quality to the beer.  Not the best offering from Allagash, and there are better witbiers out there.

Bottle. Light notes of straw and basement and a moderate smell of lemon for the hops with hints of pear, honey and clove and other spices. Head is a mostly lasting, frothy white with good lacing. Color is a murky yellow, kinda like Saturday morning pee pee, mmmm good. Flavor is lightly sweet and moderately acetic to start and finishes lightly acidic. Palate is light to medium, between watery and oily with a fizzy carbonation. Im not a fan of witbiers but this ones a bit better than the rest.

Appearance: Pours a clou-- oops, it seems I did not follow the labels explicit instructions of "Pour - Swirl - Pour Yeast". Bottoms up!

Pours a cloudy, light-hearted yellow body with a thin white head.

Smell: Soft aroma of freshly-squeezed citrus fruits, bananas, yeast, coriander, and cloves.

Taste: Smooth, gentle flavor of wheat with hints of bananas, lemons, and yeast. The spicing remains reasonably light. Finishes semi-sweet and citric.

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body. Somewhat oily mouthfeel. Moderate carbonation.

Drinkability: Its fine, but not a beer I can really get excited over. Not that I dont sincerely try to be that Excited About Wits Guy, but Im starting to feel as though thats never going to be the case.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2008 Poured a yellowish orange color with a thin white head. The aroma was of citrus fruits, and some spice. The flavor was similar with a good amount of spice to it. A good mouthfeel that finished clean and crisp. A good refreshing wit, that is great for those hot days.
A cloudy appearance. Aroma is faint spice, flavor is very much the same. A light and smooth spice flavor, and its also thirst quenching. Good for those hot summer days.
a very top notch belg white. very light in color and very cloudy with sediment. very spicy but doesnt attack you it stays very smooth. a little on the expensive side so i usually dont get it

Bu au Lompoc café à Bar harbor, Maine, en fut (20 oz). Jaune très blanchie et brumeuse. Arome doux de blé/banane, malté, quelque petits fruits crèmeux. Goût légé de malte et dépice doux, surtout coriande, des notes de fruits crmeux. Très agréable!

A very good wit. On par with my favorite version from Troegs, Dream Weaver. Had this in tap in the NC Outer Banks at the Outer Banks Brewing Station. This was my favorite of all. Very hazy yellow with huge head. Taste is of spice ( root beer ?) with a bit of sweetness. A great summer beer.

A foggy amber/orange hue with a large creamy white head.  Lots of spices in the nose coupled with a very noticable citrus and wheat aroma.  Very nice carbonation and lacing.  The citrus flavor of orange and lemon came through abundantly.  This is a very nice clean crisp beer to be enjoyed on a hot summer day
poured into tulip.  cloudy pale yellow with frothy thick head, thorough wheat, good and light.

The color was a hazy gold with orange hues.  The head was white and laced.  The aroma was yeasty with some grain.  The flavor was refreshing and yeasty with a little bite to it.  The palat was very nicely carbonated.  The finish was yeasty.

750 ml Bottle - Pours cloudy/hazy yellowish-white, smells citrusy, somewhat spicy, tastes very citrusy - almost lemony - carbonation is perfect given that most Witbiers (in my opinion) have too little.  Head formed nicely, but dissipated quickly.  Drank it with a beer-battered brat - complemented it very well and was nice in the heat.  Good brew.

A very pleasing spicy aroma with strong citrus scents.  Pours a pale yellow colour , cloudy with a good white head.  The body is light but moderately carbonated. Strong citrus with subtle spiced (perhaps...anise, corriander, vanilla) flavours. Excellent hot weather beer, strong citrus makes it very refreshing. I had it with Cambodian/Thai food and it matched very well.

Would drink this one again, but not at the top of my list.  Pours a cloudly, light caramel/gold color.  Large white head that dissipates slowly, leaving a small white head which stays throughout the beer.  Nice amount of lacing.  Aroma has a strong lemony scent.  There was a bit too much carbonation, but overall a nice mouthfeel even though the carbonation gave it a bit of a bite.  There was a citrus taste, a nice orange taste throughout.  There was a bit of a lemon finish.  Pretty good control of the taste, a nice mixture with the spices and all.
Hazy cloudy yellow color with a medium size white head. Citrus and spice aromas and flavors.

Bottled.  A hazy orange coloured beer - the haze appearing at the final pour.  A spicy, lemony aroma with oranges also.  Light in body but there are the citric and spicy flavours I would expect.  Shows more in common with French beers of this style than Belgian.

Rating for this beer are over-rated in my opinion. This smell is lemony and citrusy but with a hnt of a licorice smell.  The flavor also has a hint of a licorice taste. It did have a nice refreshing taste, but the palate left an early aftertase that was not appealing.

Good white appearance and lacing though.
This is the perfect beer for a warm SE Washington day.  Clean, crisp flavor.  Corinander and a slight orange flavor hits your nose as you take in your first sip.  On draft here in SE Washington.

cloudy, yellow appearence.  poured from a 12 oz bottle.  hints of lemon and spices.  beer is decent, but it lacks flavor and just seems to be missing something.  a bit overpriced at 36 dollars a case wholesale.

Bottle. Tullip. Pours a very pretty yellow couldy ale. This beer is very typical of the style. Lemony flavors are also expressed in the aroma. Mildly yeasty and spices of coriander can be perceived. Good.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2008 The first two bottles were absolutely plesant, however, it does not lay down well. Generally a nice and wheaty wit. Generously yeasty, somewhat citrusy as well, graviating towards orange. Pure yellow body, medium wite head (when poured correctly). If I could get this on tap as well, Im sure it would sit well as a session beer. (Bottle Pour 1/15/2007 and 6/23/2007)
Sweet nectar on the nose, thin chewy and yeasty.
(On Tap - Brickskellers Lupulin Reunulin - 05/13/2008)
On tap at Capones. Cloudy straw to yellow color. Gives me the impression of apricot juice; sour and a bit vinous. Tangy citrus/lemon bite. Tangy texture. Spicy/vinous finish.

Not too much of a head with this particular pour.  Looks like a typical wit beer, cloudy/hazy  and lite-golden colored.  Smells citrusy and spicy, lemons and coriander?  Rounded and smooth palate gives way to a crisper finish.  The spice is subtle, pleasant and not overwhelming.  Long finish leaves an almost  drying tartness. I havent been to Maine in a while but this beer would certainly be refreshing on a summer afternoon in vacationland.

Hazy golden pour with white head.  Nice wheat aroma. I have had this many times on tap in my days of living in maine, however ill rate it as the bottle i have just tasted in florida.  I found that the tap had much more flavor.  The flavor of the bottle was rather dissapointing compared to the avery white rascal, alot less spicy.

Has a hazy pale white gold pour with orange and yellow around the edges, a creamy white head,  
wheat, malt and mild coriander fragrances, faint white pepper aroma, has a wheat malt taste with lemon, very light pepper flavor, a balance of sweet and tart, light on the palate, lots of sticky lacing on the glass, tasty Wit, this beer looks like it was made with more pilsner malt compared to other Wits with all of gold in the brew, dry on the palate, I would get this again.

First taste 6/2/07.  Had this with a grilled burger for dinner.  Pour is a cloudy yellow-gold with a small white head.  Aromas and flavors are of orange peel, yeast and spice.  Very similar to a Hoegaarden, but not as heavy on the coriander, or flavor in general.  Slightly better body than the Avery White Rascal, but not as flavorfull.  Overall, I found it to be refreshing on a 90+ degree Florida day, but I was hoping for a little more "punch" of flavor.  Somewhat disappointing in this respect.  Ill put it on the list to give it another try in the future.
Robe blonde paille voilée surmontée dune mousse blanche mince. Arômes de céréales. Saveurs de blé, de céréales et de houblon.

Rated 1/28/07:  Lemon yellow pour with a medium white head and mild lacing, nice and cloudy. Soft aroma with a nice delicate flowery nose coupled with mild spices. Mouthfeel is an odd blend of creamy smooth and fizzy, weird but kind of nice. Flavor seems more delicate than the aroma, nice light citrus flavor of lemon and orange. The spices arent as prevelent but are still noticeable. Extremely quenching and satisfying, but I prefer my Wits to be a little more assertive.

Boring to say the least. Allagashs other brews, the ones they arent extorting us for money on, are excellent. Maybe I am a pureist.  I cant even spell. But this taste like unfiltered sulfur water with some yeast and some flowers. Maybe a twist of lemon but not that enamel eating strength. hmmm..

12oz bottle.  Pours a light cloudy yellow with nice lacing, but head does not last long.  Nice wheaty aroma, if a bit light.  Taste is light and lemony - too light.  Ive always been a big hefeweizen fan and have recently been trying some Belgian witbiers, and generally being a bit disappointed in their lightness.  Ive been doing some reading and am learning that the lightness generally goes along with the style - along with spices, but not much spice was noticeable in this one.  Personally, Id take a decent hefeweizen over this one any day.
A well done wit.  Very carbonated, the sample I had.  Refreshing summer beer with the characteristic orange and coriander flavors.  Perfumy.  One of my favorite styles.

bottle...unfiltered  hazy orange pour good head and lacing . aroma of citrus and corriander . flavor is wheat malt , spice and orange .light bodied and refreshing , finishing dry.. not my favorite style but this is good.
Wheat, sweet, mild spicy citrus. Yellow/Orange unfiltered with small white head. Flavor is mostly wheat, sweet orange corriander flavor. Very smooth and refreshing, but again, not my favorite style.

From a 750ml bottle batch #36 in a pint glass.  Pours hazy pale orange with nice lasting white head and nice lacing.  Light aroma of fresh orange and very mild spice.  Very delicate balance of orange, spice and sweet vanilla flavors.  Medium-light body and medium carbonation make this an incredibly refreshing beer.  An excellent example of the style, one of the best Ive had.
Pours cloudy straw color, white lacy head.  Light spiced citrus aroma.  Crisp spiced lemony flavor, and clean finish, but a bit watery.

Poured a pale hazy yellow. The head is medium, white, creamy, laces well. The aroma is spicy, yeasty, definitely some sweet orange peel, coriander, and slightly sour. The flavor is very sharp and warm, more spicy than the aroma, shows the coriander, and has some sourness. The palate was full and well carbonated. The finish left a spicy tingle at the back of my mouth. Id put this up there with St. Bernardus as far as my favorite wits go.
Cloudy yellow pour. Tastes of Citrus and wheat toast. Dryer than I expected. Good solid wit. I prefer Hoegaarden, but this is better than Blue Moon or other domestic attempts.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2012 Bottle.  Strange yeasty aroma - the spice here reminds me of the spice used to, say, spice a chicken rather than a beer.  Additional, more common notes include coriander, lemon, pepper, and medium-strong vanilla and honey.  Hazy yellow with a short bright white head.  Robust.  Spiced taste,  medium body and very smooth, dry and yeasty aftertaste with a touch of wheat.    More enjoyable than the score implies - a very good summer session, and to its credit, not at all normal. [17 May 2007: (3.3)]Getting back to this 5.5 years later, after having read Stans Brewing with Wheat; previous tasting notes hold, though I note the scratchy coriander in the mouth (to the point of coriander soup) overwhlems the fantastic fresh bread notes. [9 Nov 2012: (3.3)]
UPDATED: JUL 25, 2009 Lemon/orange aroma, Cloudy golden pour with no head. Strange bitter taste at first, turning to grapefuit. Peaches on the finish, but gets a little grainy at the end.

Batch #37. Aroma of light lemon, wheat and some yeast. Hazy golden color with a white head that laces. Medium mouthfeel. Wheat start. Mild lemon and spice. Yeast. Fairly dry finish, and there is some bitter to carry on. Very refreshing.

On tap at a friends house.  Pours a cloudy yellow/orange with a medium foamy white head that left nice lacing.  Aroma of lemon, various citrus, banana, corriander, Wit yeast and spicy.  Flavor of various citrus, wheat, yeast, lemongrass, kind of bready.  Well done Wit.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2007 Cloudy light amber with a big fluffy long lasting white head.  Light bodied silky mouthfeel.  Initial taste of slightly sweet pear and orange giving way to some sourness and finishing with tastes of coriander and cloves.  Clean almost dry finish.  A very drinkable beer.

12oz bottle. Hazy yellow with a thin white head. Aroma of spice, yeast, and citrus. Spicy flavor with notes of yeast, lemongrass, wheat and hops.  Enjoyable and refreshing,  a perfect beer for summertime.

Bottle: Nice white head, white a very pale body.  Aroma is pleasing, not quite as overpowering as many Wits.  Nice mix of citrus, yeasts, and cooking spices.  Starts out tart, with an underlying sweet fruit quality.  Definite banana qualities here in the finish.  Not quite as crisp as I expected.  Apple and yeast noted.  A somewhat restrained version of a Belgian Wit that seemed to have many German Hefe qualities to it.  Only major complaint would be that the bitterness at finish did not work for this beer.  Interesting interpretation of the style though.
This was not a bad white.  I was expecting a little more in the flavor department.  Everything else is cosistent with other beers I have had in this style.

Oh my gosh its Allagash!  This was a refreshing quaff, good sir, but lacking in the oomph department, I do say.  It smelled good and spicy, but I didnt really get much flavor overall.  What was there was smooth, tranquil and decent.  I was hoping for a little more spice than I got.  Decent Wit, nothing to write to grandma about.

Pours a golden color. Aggressive decanting still leaves some yeast in bottom of bottle. Aroma is lemons, peppery spices, and yeast. Taste is dominantly banana with some orange, lemon, and bready yeast. Mouthfeel is on the light side, which I enjoy. Slightly bitter finish is rather unpleasant. Fine beer, but slightly overrated, IMO.

Sampled on draft at Maxs Taphouse in Baltimore.  The color was a light, cloudy gold, which was lighter on top, with a creamy white head.  A fruity malt aroma, with a touch of orange, and plenty of wheat and yeast; perhaps some grainy/grassy hops.  The taste was mostly sweet and fruit, some spice, but a sour finish too.  It had a thicker feel on the palate, without a lot of carbonation or fizz.  A pretty good beer for the style, but not one of my favorite types.

(Bottle) Pours a hazy golden color with a white head. Fruity esters and a little bit of spice in the flavor. In the aroma, the spiciness is not too strong. Good mouthfeel for the style. Dry, refreshing finish. This is one beer I would drink more often...

bottle. Pours a very cloudy light yellow with a creamy, white head. The aroma is full of sweet banana and cloves with Bavarian-type hops. Rich banana character is present in the flavor without much of a sugary flavor. Theres a wheaty, grainy note throughout with some light cloves in the finish. Its very refreshing and reasonably full bodied. I think this is one of the better Witbiers Ive had.

Poured 12oz. bottle into Hoegaarden tumbler.  Pleasant aroma of coriander and cloves.  Crisp flavor with orange and lemon with a zesty spice.  This is spot on for this style.  If you like Hoegaarden then youll like this.

Very pleasant surprise.  The color and cloudiness were appreciated even though the head was absent - good lacing however.  But the taste was right on.  A hint of spice and citrus by not too much.  I will definitely try more of their beers.
12 oz bottle. Pour hazy golden color with small white head which does not last long. Wheat aroma, taste of wheat and spice with a dry finish.
very cloudy lotsa head, very citrusy, sour ,some yeast, big cloves on the nose. slightly sour with lotsa clove and pepper, slightly acidic.
Bottle: Cloudy gold in color with a white head. Aroma, cloves, yeast, some wheat malts. Flavor, light wheat/bready taste, and some yeast, and spice to it. Kinda thin, but a decent beer.
Love the hint of corriander. I agree that Allagash is one of the best at pulling off the Belgian Styles

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2011 On tap at Tylers, Durham. An excellent example of a wit, and as always Allagash is one of the few American brewers who can pull off Belgian styles in a meaningful way. Not the soppy stuff you get most of the time, this one delicately balances the spice and citrus in its golden body. Awesomely refreshing.

750 gusher. Pours hazy yellow with a fluffy white head. Spice, yeast and lemon in the aroma. Medium body and carbonation. Soft, round taste of wheat, spice, lemon. Soft citrus finish. This is tasty stuff!

Draught at Hopleaf. Fairly nondescript aroma; somewhat sweet. Truly white in appearance (as white as a Belgian White gets). They have the style appearance down. Thin, creamy head. Some lace. Very nice flavor. Better than Sam Adams White which I had the previous evening. Not as fruitloopy as the SA; more Belgian. Smooth and easily drinkable. Nice White.
Has a kind of soft, citric acid edge.  A bit like drinking an unsweetened lemon tart or lemon meringue pie.
Draft.  Aroma of bananas and yeast, and oranges.  Good flavor of the same things.  Crisp and good on a warm day.
Slight yeast aroma with strong coriander and moderate banana nose. Cloudy yellow pour. smooth taste with a banana finish. Creamy and fizzy carbonation palate.
Batch #35. 750ml.  Nice golden yellow with creamy head. Aroma and flavor of citrus, flowers, and spices. Thin, oily palate. Although not bad, tripel is more enjoyable.

Pretty simple witbier. Sour yeast on the nose along with lemon rind and other fruits. Pours ultra-pale cloudy yellow with a big ol white head. Some banana coming through on the nose, but mostly sour yeast and tin. Very dry. Not a very enjoyable drink. Poor interpretation of the style by Allagsh on this one.

Draught at Magnetic Field.  Cloudy yellow/gold with a white head.  Bread, banana and yeasty aromas.  Off-sweet bready malt flavor with banana, lemon and mineral notes.  Somewhat grassy finish.  Body thins out after a while. OK domestic wit.
A very nice beer. The aroma and color are fabulous. When poured leaves a very nice head. Had two six packs while in Maine and wanted to bring more home. I highly recommend.

Bottle. Smells very nice, appearance is excellent with a clean golden color.  Unfortunately had a water taste and went down way to quickly.  Pretty disappointment for what I paid at Eulogy Tavern in Philadelphia which is an excellent Belgian Pub
Sufferin allagash Daffy said it then and I am saying it now...thats what this beer is all about (plop)
Sour yeast aroma with some light spices in the background.  Clear pale yellow color.  Thin palate.  Watery taste with light flavors of yeast and citrus.  Not much to enjoy.
pours cloudy golden color with lacy white head. smells very nice and fruity with lemon aroma. spicy full flavor with hint of lemon grass and orange. very good belgian white..very enjoyable
cloudy yellow with a nice foamy head. Very sweet and fruity, a lot of citrus flavors and spices. Slight hops evident. A really good belgian white and would make an awesome summertime beer.
Lemon grass,yeast and a slight sourness in the aroma.Pours a hazy yellow with a large white head.Pretty good amount of sweet malt in the flavor.Thin to medium mouthfeel with a sweet finish.
Had a spicy aroma and a cloudy pour.  A little more lemon came through in the flavor than I thought there would be.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2011 This is about the third belgian whitbier Ive tried, after blue moon and hoegarden. I thought this was nice with a bit more spice than blue moon and hoegarden... nice orange and lemon flavor. ::: Second time, Im sampling allagash white through a 1/6th keg and it is way better than I remember it. I actually like this over hoegarden now.

a nice allagash, havent had a bad one yet. pour was nice, with slightly lemony and spicy aromas, cloudy as you would expect.nice wheat flavors and lemony orangey spices in the end.a very nice example of witbier done right.

The pour reveals a slightly cloudy yellow color wih a medium, creamy, white head. The aroma has a solid presence of wheat with some lemon and mild spices. The flavor is solid, the lemon is more up front than in the aroma, theres still a good wheat presence with some yeast and spices.  The body is full with a creamy texture and mellow carbonation. A very fine witbier.

Bottle.  Musty lemon/peach and clove/cardamom aroma.  Cloudy orange-yellow color with small head.  Musty apple/lemon flavor.  Although this beer is on the light side, really liked the saison-like mustiness.
Quite a thin beer.  Light and spicy.  Great aroma, with the actual flavor just falling short of what the nose expected.  The thing is that the watery consistency works well with what the flavor.
Pours a clear golden blond with a fluffy white head. Aroma of citrus. Hops and citrus fruits are apparent. Thin, but refreshing. Great summer beer.
Pours a nice clear light golden color. Head is medium fizzy white, mostly diminishing. Nice crisp clean beer. Goes very well with food.
Bottle. Pale yellow color with a small, fizzy white head.  Carbonated, citrusy aroma.  Taste is fruity, thin, with oranges and slight hops.  Pretty good but not great.
very nice appearance of a hazy straw colored beer with a solid white head.  taste has a strong wheat character, some complexities but more of a one dimensional beer than i would like
Very pale straw color, short white head. Lightly spicy, orange blossom aroma. Subtle flavors, velvety mouthfeel, very drinkable.

Brickskeller, Russian River / Allagash Lovefest.  Hazy, yellow appearance; brilliant white head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Medium, belgian-white aroma; light coriander and chewy orange.  Medium mouthfeel: creamy; coriander and light tropical fruit; light carbonation.  Light, yeasty and doughy finish.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2012 Draft at Jerrys. Hazy pale yellow with white head / Nose of banana and spice / Light, creamy body with good finish / Flavors of banana with undertones of orange, grass, and coriander with black pepper finish.

Tap @ Hamiltons.  A very solid representation of the style.  Probably as close to a Hoegaarden as you can get.  Cloudy, sweet, fruity and all around great.  This makes me wish it was summer as I could make an afternoon of drinking this.
Bottle.  No head into cloudy orange-yellow body.  Aroma of citrus fruit and spices. Slight bubble gum flavor.  Dry crisp finish.  Good summer time beer, too bad were in the dead of winter.
UPDATED: JUN 27, 2007 On tap @ Pizza Plant Walker. Citrusy wit. Good flavor. refreshing Enjoyable

Bottle Yellow golden pour with no head. Light citrus aroma with a hint of hops and spice. Flavor definatly has some spice and honey sweetness flollowed by more citrus. Smooth mouthfeel, light and refreshing.
Draft at OBriens.  Some banana on the aroma, but mostly just orange/lemon citrus.  Hazy yellow with no head.  Flavors were similar with some spice and orange.  Not too bad, not super exciting.

Hazy straw golden with a nice white foam head. Smells of wheat, lemons,  and spice. Hops also apparent. Taste is dlicious and dry, hops and spices really kicking in initially and tapering off to a nice crisp finish...I really like this beer...more in my future.

Bottle marked Batch #3. The beer pours a hazy straw gold color, topped by 2" of white foam. Good head retention and lace. Mild lemon in the aroma. Wheat and honeymalt flavors, along with some citrus and yeast. Mild spice and more citrus in the finish. Medium body, good carbonation. Very refreshing and drinkable.

beer pours the expected hazy yellow/white, with a lot of bubbles giving it a tall head that laces well. nose is quite nice, with the spice note (coriander) not being overwelmed by medicinal phenols (as often happens with these beers). flavor is crisp and dry, with a grassy malt note supplementing the spices. hops only noted as IBUs. palate is a bit astringent, but the over-all beer is still very good - am excellent summer quencher.

Pours a hazy golden yellow white large bubbly foamy head. Nose is a complex and pleasant blend of many nice aromas: lemon,wheat,green grapes,and some spices. It was a refreshing drink with a nice light taste.

Poured only a slightly cloudy gold in color with a small white head. Aroma of wheat, yeast, maybe a whiff of corriander. Flavor is lightly sweet with a touch of citrus and vinous grape - - fading into a lightly dry finish, almost like a chardonnay at the end.A little sharp and astringent on the palate with a medium body. Not what I expected, but good nonetheless.

bottle.
Cloudy urine color with a thin wehite head. Grains of paradise or coriander or something in the nose with a lavender scent too. Tastes like some flowers smell, only with a bit of paste. Some grape notes in the finish, but the glue flavor is really an ender for me. a definite on the not to buy again list.
3 6 3 2 7

Bottle.  Hazy, grapefruit-blonde in color.  No head and few bubbles or carbonation.  Strong mustard initial scent backed up by notes of lemon, grass.  If I didnt know better Id think I was about to eat a hot dog.  Flavor is yeasty with hints of chili powder.  Pleasant body and follow through to the finish.  Very nice; Ill have another.
Bottle. Hazy light gold with a thin white head. Spicy citrus aroma. Water and a hint of lemon, but overall light on flavor. Still a decent beer. A

I found this beer to be lighter than I expected from a wheat beer. It looked good in a pint glass and it was subtle with its fruit and hops. I thought it would good on tap and close second to the Ommegang Witt in overall terms.

Uggh! I hate wheat beers in general but I know a good or bad wheat beer. This is an average to below average one. Yes, technically its a witbier, but to me wheat = bad. This was not as bad as most. The pour is a blah pee yellow with no head. The aroma is old sugar. The taste is citrus-y and yeast with vinegar in the finish. Almost a drain pour but I had wisdom teeth pulled a few days ago and wanted to dull the pain.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle.   Pours a cloudy pale gold, decent sized rocky white head with not much lacing.   Aroma is of lemon, yeast, and some corriander.   Flavor is bread, some spice, and lemon.   Palate is light bodied, crisp, highly carbonated, lingering lemony, yeasty finish.   A solid white.
A successful belgian style american beer.  While there is not much of a nose to the hazy golden brew, the strong hints of citrus and yeast make the flavor bold and the mouth feel great.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a hazy washed out yellow with thin white head that quickly disappeared. Pleasant aroma of citrus, yeast and spices.  The flavor was just lacking for me.  There were some spices and a bit of lemon, but overall it was quite bland.  Not bad, just blah.

White sludge at bottom of bottle--  I wish it hadnt settled so much because it was nice. Corriander/spices with zesty citrus and yeast note. A bit watery and mineral tasting but I enjoyed it because it wasnt too sweet.

From the bottle. Pours pale gold, cloudy brew, not much lacing, foams dissolves somewhat quickly. Aroma of nutmeg, allspice and juniper berry. Tastes of the same spices with a touch of grapefruit pith. Nice beer.

12oz bottle via my Secret Santa! - thanks - pours cloudy and pale golden with a short white head.  Aromas of lemon, yeast, and some corriander.  Flavor is yeasty upfront with some definite citrus bite and a spice finish.  Light palate with a spritzy mouthfeel.

this is a great white that isnt cluttered by cloves or banana. i love the cloudy appearance. i d like just a bit more citrus but if u want an uncontaminated white this is it. id add a silce of orange or lemon and if i can get a 6 pack , ill experiment. i could drink this for hours and days at a time. great summer or sitting by a fireplace  beer. this is as good or better than hoegaarden and hachor pschorr. had a pint, might not be as good in a bottle, wheats are funny like that.

Slightly hazy gold color with long lasting small white head. The aroma is really faint. I can pick up a bit of sweetness, banana and cloves I think. The first sip was a barrage of flavors and spice. A couple sips in and the flavor smoothes out like a freshly ironed silk shirt. Its almost too smooth to identify the flavors. It starts off rather neutral. Then theres a wheat note followed by some tartness. About midway the spices kick in along with a pinch of sweetness. Very nice smooth tasting beer.
Pours cloudy/hazy yellow with moderate head that dimisnishes to a thin lacing.  Sweet & sour aroma.  Taste of lemon.  Not a bad beer.
Decent brew from the US in the Belgian style.  Nice cloudy golden pour with rich zesty taste.  Great Offering for what it is.
Pours a hazy yellow with a soapy white head that lingers.  Aroma of bread, some spice, and lemon.  Tastes of wheat/bread. lemon, and spice.  Very nice beer!

Pours a beautiful bright gold-yellow (completely opaque and hazy) with a one-finger pure white head, big bubbles, fades to a cap on the beer and laces heavily.  Nose is predominately spice - curacao, cinnamon or nutmeg, as well as some lemon.  My first try gave me some definite pale lager notes...which was weird. Maybe an aberration.  Taste is lingeringly sour, with spice upfront then fading then making a reappearance in the finish, which is very crisp and dry.  Lively carbonation and pleasantly light.

From a bottle poured into a glass. Tried it cause it is compared to Hoegaarden often. First thing that struck me was a strange "celery" / vegetable taste that was persistent the whole way through, which I didnt care for. Color was a hazy yellow. Head didnt last long at all. I dont think I will be trying this again.
Bottle and tap - Pours a pale yellow... Smell is lemon and slight hint of cloves.. Taste is wheat and a slight spicyness... MUCHHH better with a lemon on a summer day..   not bad
second witbier ive tried after blue moon...sooo much more flavor...nice spiciness, nouthfeel, clean finish...looking forward to trying others...redlight redlight
Light golden-cloudy pour.  Aroma of banana-yeast with some spiciness.  Taste is heavy on the wheat and yeast, but hop balance is pleasant.  Not really my style, but a very pleasant brew.

Bottle. Corked 24 oz. Hazy straw colored. Large, white head. Aroma of banana, cloves, yeast. Flavorful wheat beer dominated at first by spices that seem accentuated by high level of carbonation. Mild yeast flavor with bready notes. Very little citrus and hardly any tartness which would have rounded out this decent wit beer.
Light citrusy aroma.  Yellow color, slightly cloudy.  Bitter, light fruity taste.  Slightly astringent and fizzy mouthfeel.  Not bad.

12oz bottle.  Aroma:  Spicy coriander and pepperiness, slight banana, wheaty breadiness, lemon, and a touch of woodiness.  Appearance:  Light yellow in color and hazy.  White head was full and rocky. Head dissipated swiftly into a light film.  Decent lacing.  Flavor:  Spice jumps out first with strong coriander and pepper.  Nice wheat flavor with a good yeast quality.  Lemon and orange citrus.  Palate:  Light bodied.  High carbonation.  Overall:  A good wit and a pleasure to drink.   Only criticism is that the flavor doesnt pop as well as some other witbiers.  Still, a good beer.

Hazy/murky yellow with nice off-white head, fades rather quickly but leaves nice lacing. Aroma has very bready wheat character up front, with some banana and lemon zest in the background. Flavor much the same. Chewy wheat bread with a nice balance of citrus, banana and spice. If aroma and flavor were a tad "bigger" this score would jump significantly. Mouthfeel thins out at times. Overall, well done easy drink, regardless.

Glowing hazy gold with a big aroma of oranges and lemons. Sharp, spicy flavors with some sourness lead to a dry, wheaty finish. Lots of citrus flavor and a sweet yeastiness that seem to balance each other out. Pretty good.

Pale yellow in color. Almost zero head that completely disappeared.  Clove, allspice, some banana.  Expected a little more aroma.  Like many Allagash brews, this one was quite carbonated.  Not like the 10th Anniversary, though.
UPDATED: JUN 19, 2007 Pours an off cloudy yellow. Good head(keeps its retention) The taste is crisps and smells of wheat but I dont like belgians too much. This falls short for me.

Im tasting this side-by-side with the Allagash Grand Cru so that I can do a direct comparison...  The Allagash White is a cloudy pale yellow color.  Mild carbonation with a white crown.   Aroma is doughy with hints of lemon and orange.  Flavor is slighty sweet, wheat, and some subtle spice.  Finishes yeasty and with some bitterness and spice.  Light, smooth, and crisp on the palate.

12 oz bottle, $1.75 from Rivers Bend.
Nice cloudy whet beer color, thin head that goes away quickly.  nice flavor of citrus and other fruit.  A good drinking white beer.
This was decent.  A lot more like Blue Moon than Hoegaarden.  It was more orange-yellow than white, but a nice, subtle citrus flavor.  Would recommend.

Pours cloudy light orange color with thin white billowy head.  Aroma is mild spiciness with a hint of yeastiness.  Mouthfeel is good, since it is not overly thin like many witbiers.  Taste is mildly spicy backed by sweet, and finishes clean.  A good wit because it doesnt taste watered-down.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2007 Luckily have this on tap and a local bar.  I really like this beer.  Light yellow hazy color.  Aroma is of spice and citrus.  Sweet taste, with nice spice too it.  Wheat undertone.  Ending is great.  Drink it frequently.
Solid belgian wheat beer.  Fresh typical doughy aroma from the initial sip.  Smooth but perhaps too sweet with a nice balance of spicies.  Very nice
big fan, rivals belgian offerings but lets u express your patriotism for those who are jealous of your freedom. highly reccomend on a warm summer day watching womens football.
I love this white beer! As you can tell form the bottle it has a spice to it which makes for a great initial taste and nice after taste.

Pours a very light yellowish  brown color with an average white head. Aroma was pretty spicy maybe a little more citrusy than a hoegaarden and also a little sweet. The flavor was sweet and also tart. It had some sour orange and coriander taste. This is a very good white.
Yeasty and spicy aroma.  Nice white frothy head with mod lacing.  medium bodied and well balanced.
Pale gold body with a frothy white head.  Belgian yeasty aroma, somewhat fruity, banana and maybe some apple.  A nice taste, sweet and fruity with some light hops.  Sweet ending, very nice.
Hazy white body with a small creamy white head. Heavily spiced aroma with some orange peel. Sweet spice flavor, some orange peel, a hint of lemon, nd a gentle wheat background.

Corked 750 mL bottle, Batch 28 according to label.  Pours a straw color (second glass pours much cloudier than the first) with a pretty substantial head.  Aroma is unique... pear, coriander, maybe some subdued cloves, a little soap and plenty of dough.  Head is substantial... two or three fingers in a pint glass.  Flavor is very spicey... one of the most heavily spiced beers Ive tried.  Im picking up cloves and coriander leading the charge as the initial surge of smooth wheat sweetness subsides.  A peppery note brings the whole thing to a close.  Lemon is also present as this beer transitions away from what I expected in a wit to that spiciness that I didnt see coming.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: big bottle, nice presentation.  Traditional witbier with a few other complex flavors in there. Maybe  a little more spicy than traditional, but doesnt take away.
One bottle from BOTW.  Poured a small head.  Aroma of wheat and spices.  Flavor of wheat and spicy coriander.  More spicy than other Witbiers Ive had.  Enjoyable.

Very citrussy nose, with a hint of pineapple and spice. Very fresh, lively flavour with a strong sense of coriander and yeast. Slightly sugary residue, some bitterness and plasticity in the finish. Palate is a little thin. Overall a very refreshing and pleasant take on the style.

Typical lemony and wheaty aroma with some yeast and earthy notes in it.  Very subtly spicey, I would have really like some more flavor in this one. It was recommended by the owner as his favorite wheat beer. Not my opinion, but still pretty average.

Pale lemon pour with a creamy, long lasting head.  The bready, yeasty aroma jumps up and out of the tulip.  Notes of dirty, earthy, funky yeast mingle with buttery breads and wet straw.  The body is thick and full - lush carbonation taboot with a great wheat smoothness.    As the initial lushness subsides, notes of wet bread, coriander and caramel remain.  Lighter, citrusy notes emerge in the long, wet finish.  Really great example.
Wow this beer quite honestly smells like ass.  Taste sour and plain compared to a lot of whites.  Nothing special and not that good.
Bottle at ZBF 06. Pours a hazy yellow, with a white head. Aroma is sweet, wheat and coriander. Taste is spicy(coriander mostly) and yeasty.

Hazy golden color with a short lived white head.  Aroma of spices and citrus.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Wheat, citrus, coriander and pepper flavors.  Spicy finish.  A nice white beer, just not one of my favorite styles.

Bottle and draft. What propelled this to above average for me was the creamy palate and full body. The pour was murky golden with a big white head. Aroma of coriander and grain. The flavor, too, was filled with spicy coriander and sweet apple. Slight alcohol finish combined with excellent carbonation provided a refreshing finish. Very nice.

On draft plenty of times at my house. Pours hazy pale golden with a white head. Aroma of spices, citrus, fruit, and sweetness. The flavor is smooth, refreshing, citrus, spices, fruit, and sweet. Great beer.

Thanks to sckressler for having this on tap at his home...
Appears a hazy light gold with a small white cap that slowly fades out into a mild cap and collar. Scattered webs of lace are left around the glass.
Smell is of lemon, clove, orange peel, pils malt, along with some malty sugar.
Taste is of the same aromas that make for a great American version of a witbier.
Mouthfeel is spritzy, sugary, with candy smoothness that starts at the front of the tongue and has nice balance.

Spritzy, slightly tangy, lemony, mild carbonation, a very hazy colouring.  Its a decent white beer in belgium style but its not too discernable or exciting.  Also goes down like water, and the price is usually too much.
Draft - Tellers in Hyde Park.  Alright.  Spicy, a bit of citrus.  One of the prettier bright white heads Ive ever seen.  A bit watery and uneventful.
[bottle] Nice spicy aroma of yeast and lemon. Flavors are initially zesty lemon sweetness with a bit of pear and apple fruits. Finishes complex- spicy and dry.

Cloudy golden yellow color, pretty decent fluffy and rapidly dissipating head.  Nice rich flavors of wheat, yeast, citrus (lemon and orange), spices (coriander, clove, nutmeg).  Crisp, dry mouthfeel and dry finish.  Better than a Hoegaarden, Id say.

The pours is a hazy straw, with beautiful sudsy lace to the glass.  The nose is primarily of yeast, wheat and spices that mix well with sugar (cinammon, ginger, allspice, etc.).  The flavors of wheat, yeast, sour grains, and light citrus mingle nicely with one another.  The finish really got me, as its spot on for Apple Jacks cereal and further spices.  The mouthfeel is very crisp and refreshing.  Good spiced, slightly sweet citrus summer brew!  Very refreshing!

(Champagne Bottle) This is a solid wit, with great citrus notes than can be picked up in the scent and the taste.  Its a little tart which is nice, and is satisfying on a hot day.  Sampled at the Brewery.

This beer gets high marks from me. And that is saying something coming from a guy who is not all that fond of many of the Witbiers hes had. This is definitely a great summer beer and celebration beer at the same time. This is the beer that you want for a gradation party when its 100 degrees out side by the pool, you know...

Appearance: Cloudy yellow color with a big head and lots of lacing.

Smell: Zesty spicy lemon 

Taste & Mouthfeel: The beer is very effervescent from the beginning that really add to the zippy character on the palate as you taste it. There is some depth to this Witbier. The taste of wheat and lemon with orange peel and coriander blend together then the wheat malts become a little more distinct as the lemon also separates as the bitter flavor. All the while spicy zippy and very refreshing.

Drinkability: This is a very drinkable refreshing beer good any time but recommended for when you need a quencher.

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!
we lived in Portland for a year....really liked this one..........................!
Bottle.  Cloudy yellow.  Smallish head.  Lemony, and sweet aroma.  Spice flavors.

Cloudy yellow, small head, low retention, medium carbonation. Aroma is lemon, hints of coriander and some yeast. Flavor is a little sour balanced by a herbal bitterness (I find the bitternees a little strong for a white). Mouthfeel is kind of creamy. Lacks some punch, well balanced but nothing shines; well brewed no flaws but a little dull.

Pours a bubbly yellow with a tall foamy white head, rocky, lasting head, line lacing.  Aroma is orange, citrus, malt (meal, straw), yeast (dough), bananas and spices.  Medium bitterness and acidity, earthy malt and yeast flavor, sweet underneath, straw, cardboard and citrus spices.  Medium bodied and fizzy, refreshing and crisp palate.

$1.99.  The beer pours to a hazy straw colored body with a thin white head.  Spotty lacing.  The aroma is soothingly spicey and floral.  Bananas, cloves, yeast, honey, lavendar, flowers.  I cant believe most people dont rate this beers aroma higher.  The flavor is yeasty with bananas, light bubblegum, coriander, lightly tart wheat, nicely balanced.  I can see why this is one of the best wits.  Its no Southampton Double White Ale or Jolly Pumpkin Calabaza Blanca, however.  Nice smooth mouthfeel that has a good texture.
Bottle. Pours hazy gold with white head. Aroma is malt, spices, chamomile. Flavor is chamomile, malt, corn, and spices.

Pours a very cloudy yellow with a nearly nonexistant white head.  Aroma is sweet, with notes of spice, bubblegum, and bits of banana.  Flavor is sweet, with the coriander and yeast coming through.  Not incredibly complex, but very enjoyable.

Not a bad every day, watching the race kind of beer. Sweet aroma, goes down smooth. Enjoyed this one with Barb at Bon Vivant Goveners Point Virginia. Got stuck in the store during huge hail storm and flash flooding. Darn the luck.

Batch 2:  Poured a hazy pale yellow with a small white head.  Floral aroma with light notes of spice.  The flavor was sweet and yeasty with spiced notes.  Light bodied. (Wow just checked and it looks like I stole the flavor profile from the rating below me.  Oh wiil I didnt)
Pours hazy golden with a fully receding white head. Aroma of orange, fruits, and mint. Taste is sweet and yeasty with notes of wheat and mint. Mouthfeel is light bodied with moderate carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark yellow with an average size white head. Spicy, citrusy aroma with some wheat and corn (thankfully no bananas!). Flavour of wheat, spices and fruit and a light bitter finish. Light to medium bodied. Enjoyable Wheat beer, I liked it.

Aroma is of bannanas almost overpoweringly. Thin white head and a really pale hazy yellow color for the rest of the body. Taste is actually very good and not at all bananas but more citrius and spice with a hint of sweetness. Mouthfeel is a little bit on the watery side but overall a good brew I would buy again.
Pours a cloudy pale yellow.Banana aroma with hint of clove.and lemon.Taste matches aroma.Nice and refreshing and easy to drink.

Pours hazy and very pale, with a small white head. The aroma is corriander and citrus, really well done. The flavor is oranges, lemon, corriander, touch of tartness. Light body with lively carbonation.

12oz bottle: Pours a very cloudy very pale yellow color, medium sized head.  Diminishing.  Aroma of citrus, spices, some alcohol, dry aroma.  Fizzy taste, somewhat watery.  Some taste of spices, citrus.  Not a lot of flavor, I was expecting more, somewhat watery.
pours a nice cloudy orange with a medium head.  good carbonation.  Aroma is tangy citrus, spicy coriander and some wheat.  Taste is about the same, lemon, with a slightly acidic finish.

Aroma gives off all the usual suspects that you could find in a delightful witbier. Coriander, orange peel, and some light grain malt. Appearance is hazed and not easily visible through gold with a white topping of head. Flavor is semi sweet with hints of lemon shavings and dashes of coriander. Impressive white ale.

Pours a hazy gold with a nicley lacing white head that endures.Fresh spicy aroma with some yeasty notes. Light on the palate with some lively effervescence. Citrus and spice flavors lead to a slightly sour and refreshing finish.

smells sweet and citrussy.  murky yellow body with thin white head.  Tastes sweet and citrussy with just a hint of hops and alcohol.   A very decent beer.  A belgian thats accessable and not overwhelming.  I am very impressed.  Of course, I wouldnt expect less from by far one of the best Maine breweries.

Pours a one finger white head that fades quickly no lace.  Cloudy amber color.  Light carbonation and light-medium bodied.  Yeasty nose.  Starts with more yeast than anything, looking for spices - they are subtle, quiet finish needs more crispness. $1.70 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.

12 oz bottle-Poured a cloudy yellow color w/a moderate white head. Yeasty, grassy, doughy, spicey aroma. Spicey up front flavor, citrus/lime, doughy, bread like-its a wheat beer! That flavor is definately there, really no hops to speak of. Long pleasent finish-crisp & clean. Good sample of a Witbier

12 fl oz bottle. Yellowish white and hazy. Medium sized white head that clings to the glass. Light aromas with pepper corns and yeast. Spices are subtle indeed. Soft and really mellow mouthfeel. Medium-bodied. Coriander and just a little lemon. Aftertaste is lightly bitter and dry. This is a great thirst quencher and a great witbier.

750 mL bottle Batch #29
Aroma: Yeasty and wheaty odor wih a hint of citrus.  You definitely knew you were going to be drinking a White beer with this scent.
Appearance: Hazy straw orange in color.  Not as much sedimenation as I expected with the pouring instructions on the label but that was fine.  Head was frothy and rocky white bubbles with some lacing that sustained nicely.
Flavor: Yeasty and wheaty like the odor suggested with the orange peel coming through at the end.  The coriander was very subtly  noted which blended together gave it a bit of a bubble gum taste.
Palate: Thin mouthfeel that did not linger overly long but the different flavors coming through after swallowing was pleasant.
Overall: Quality beer again from Allagash which is a brewery I am growing more fond of with each sampling.

Pours a hazy light yellow color, lots of yeast sediment.  Aroma of citrus and wheat.  Tastes of citrus, coriander, and a bit of wheat.  Mildly carbonated and well balanced.  The aroma, I felt, was quite deceiving as this beer is just full of flavor.  Excellent beer.

On tap in Salem, MA.  A nice brew with citrus aroma and a slight citrus taste.  Cloudy in the glass.  I liked this beer and would order one again, especially if I was sitting on a patio on a sunny afternoon.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy pale golden yellow color with a bubbly white head.  Good bit of carbonation.  Contains a fair amount of yeast in the bottle.  Aroma is  yeasty and wheaty with a touch of sweetness and a bit of citrus. Taste is similar to aroma - wheat, yeast, a little hop bite and some citrus & floral high-lights.  Medium mouthfeel.  A little thin. Finish is dry, fairly crisp and rather refreshing.  Will not necessarily wow you, but is very drinkable.

nice burst if fresh hops.. suprising for  this style,nice cloudy light golden apearance... wow pretty balance of falvor dont know what Im tasting fist.. coriander.. comes in first, citrus mellows out qiuck to a little malty mabe cause of the residual sugar, reminder im not a wheat drinker...clean yet cloying finish... would drink again for sure... this ones bottled.. draft would be nice!!!!

Draught. Pours cloudy yellow with small white head. The aroma is lemon, bread, and a bit of honey. The flavor is zest, Saaz, and crackers, with a slightly spicy finish. There is also a faint sourness in the aftertaste. Solid, but unoriginal.

pours out of the bottle a beautiful sparkling, citrus color.  the colors deepen and darken from the bottom of the glass to the top from a paler, watery yellow to a full lemon hue, to a zesty, tangerine, engulfed in egg-yolk. It appears a bit like soda, clear w/ intense carbonation, except for the nice thin, yet bubbly foam, white head.  There is a modest amount of lacing that dances high along the glass like fireworks. the aroma is fresh revealing spicy hops, grass and onion. The taste is refreshing as well - grass, citrus, sweet cabbage. The palage feels thin at first but fills out in the throat slightly thicker and softer. overall - this is a tenderly light blend of subtle flavors while having compex enough spicy hops to tickle the back of the throat and open the nasal passages. This beer was truly enjoyable and I did just that - I enjoyed it - slow and full of appreciation.

Bottle. Hazy pale yellow body topped with a decent white pillowy head. Fresh hoppy aroma with citrusy, herbal, and yeasty notes. Teste is well balanced and refreshing. It carries many different fruity hints (citrus, pineapple, orange, pear) and leaves a good bittersweet aftertaste. Very good Witbier.

Poured with very little head from the bottle and looked swill yellow, except for some fluorescence to the color. Head was gone after two sips and the lacing minimal. Aroma was spicey and straw-wheat-like. Flavor was spicey with a touch of orange and nicely hopped. Too much straw in the flavor. Allagash seems to be a competent American Belgian brewer, but theyre not great.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2008 The closest thing to Hoegaarden I’ve found, maybe a touch better too.  Lots of coriander, somewhat dry.  Great crisp light refreshing body and carbonation.   One of my favorites.

In my secretive quest to find a witbier that betters Hoegaarden, many have fallen at the knees of the juggernaut that it is. In theory it seems highly plausible as one might call witbiers, as a style, fairly mild and lucid. Yet the balance of these timid brews is the key that unlocks such delicate complexity. Allagashs White is yet another example of a wit that came close, but as Perrault reminds us in Cinderella, simply does not fit. In appearance it is as dainty and ethereal as any other of its genre, but shrouded in a veil that just transpares its unctuous golden mango body. Under the white crown an inconspicuous aroma of pineapple, pear and yeast is loosely laced together. The flavor simply reminds of mineral water touched with lemon and the whisper of fatigued cloves and coriander. Allagashs effort lacks just a soupçon of presence and character - so I ask, who will adorn the glass slipper?
Bottle: Golden-yellowish color, crisp citrus smell, thin moutfee, bitter finish.  Unfortunately I didnt pick up a lot of flavors from this one.  I dont think Ill buy it again.
UPDATED: JUL 30, 2007 my favorite beer in the 750ml corked bottles. also my favorite style and have had most that i can get my hands on.
12oz bottle.  Unfiltered dull golden hue.  White head.  Floral and orange and lemon/lime nose.  Perfumy and yeasty.  Citrus flavors.  Lively and crisp.  This is another great wit!

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2006 Nice witbier.  Big white head, slightly sour, and very cloudy on the pour.  A little sweet on the aftertaste and just a little waterier than a great wit but good and very drinkable.
very citrusy.  normal appearance.  initally off-putting is the sourness, but once you get used to it the flavorfulness of this wit is proudly revealed.
Pours cloudy yellow into a tumbler.  Microbubble head with nice retention.  Citrus aromas.  A little thin with a bitter clove lasting finish.

Batch  #27. Hazy yellow/gold.Huge, dense, white head. Aroma of peach, apricot, corriander, wheat, light citrus and yeast. Same flavors with some crisp hops towards the dry finish. Leaves you wanting more with each drink. Medium/light, balanced body. One of the best witbiers around.

Bottle.  Poured cloudy, oily pale yellow with a thin white head.  Theres light spice and sweet banana/lemon malt, but initially its funky/sour not pleasant herbal hops dominating - it stays funky, but thats the hops?  Ill buy it, lets see about the ... taste: decent generic spicy/fruity and sharp, nice quick finish.  Mouthfeel is watery, very sharp, acidic ... not all that great.
A pretty good beer.  A bit light, but has a hint of clove and cardamon.  A good summer type beer.

Very pale light yellow in color, cloudy, small white bubbly head.  Smells and tastes pretty much exactly the same.  Starts with bananas (maybe too much), and then I taste more of the cloves, lemon, a hint of fruity malt.  Smooth, refreshing.

Pours a uniformly cloudy bright yellow with a minor head.  Odd looking, but not unpleasant looking.  Cloves, banana, and apples assault the nose with that wheat beer sourness.  Average weight on the tongue with decent CO2 levels and just a  touch of viscosity.  Exactly what I smelled is exactly what Im tasting.  Perhaps a bit more sour, though.  Id say its a ctirus sort of sour, reminding me kumquats or tangerines maybe-- very vitamin C.  This sourness lingers on the palate in much the way bitterness lingers after most beers.  This style isnt my cup of tea, but this aint bad.

Pours a typical cloudy gold color with a pure white head.  Aroma is lemon and pepper.  Flavor is similar...a bit of sweetness and maybe bit of malt comes through, which is nice.  A tad bit of sulfur though...which is I guess is a typical problem with yeast strains people use with wits.  Mouthfeel is dry and very refreshing.
Tart, lemony aroma.  Typical witbier cloudy appearance.  Just the right carbonation.  A light sourness without a longlasting aftertaste.  This is a real thirst quencher

First impressions here were good, when as soon as we popped the cork, we got a cloud of white smoke. Impressive intro. It pours with a full, frothy white head that mostly lasts. Hazy body crowned with good lacing. Aroma is a heavy shot of flowery hops. Smells very sweet. Initial taste, as expected, was lightly sweet, and that continues through the finish. Light on the mouth with a watery feel, soft carbonation.

Pours a beautiful hazy yellow with a frothy white head.  Aroma is solt orange peel with a pleasing light sweetness and traces of coriander.  Taste is initially of orange peel and wheat leading up to the coriander on the finish and then a combination of the the flavor that sticks around.  An amazingly tasty beer that is also unobtrusive.  This is easily one of my favorites of the style.
very tasty witbier.  Nice cloudly orange beer with a spicey yet soft flavor.    A nice wheat beer feel to it, but lighter.  I have several, and it stands up as a good season beer too.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2007 Ephemeral food, while adorable, is not what I prefer to eat.  Those pricey restaurants that flock to the commercial and tech business centers cook about $10 worth of food, make it pretty and charge twenty or thirty bucks, leaving the eater with an empty wallet and an even emptier stomach.  I dont care how lovingly garnished the olive appetizer is.  Its a single olive and there is no way its going to compensate for my caloric loss between lunch and dinner.  Fine cuts of steak should look like that came from a fully grown cow.  If I see a tiny sliver of beef that couldnt have come from anything larger than a ruminant fetus, Im going to have to take a quick trip to Chipotle and eat a full sized burrito just to end the night thinking I had a substantial meal.  Luxurious restaurants have their place, but for me that place is few and far between.  And like my food, I dont find satisfaction in lightweight or insubstantial beers.  Those like Allagash White, which I think does a great disservice to the style of Belgian Whites.  I know Belgian Whites can have enough substance to be a clear and present style in the beer world.  Hoegaarden was one of my first quality beers, and Ive loved it since.  But Allagash White is just a spectral version of a good Belgian White, on the verge of fading into obscurity, or as my palate calls it semi-transition into water.  By appearance the Allagash differs little from the standard Wit; the same semi-cloudy yellow body with the cumulous bleached white head, and the familiar smells of a lemon twist, with an added bonus of spices.  But the taste is weak, and the palate even weaker.  Maybe it is the palate I hate the most after all.  Its irritably thin, and feels like working with a delicate art piece.  Should drinking a beer feel like painting a Faberge egg?  Absolutely not!  Should opining over a sturdy and studious masculine beverage be like treading around precariously balanced ice sculptures?  Of course not!  So why drink the Allagash White?  There is a benefit somewhere in its excessively gentility, but what it is I cant find.  Maybe its apropos for the patient recovering from surgery.  A beer light enough to drip onto a 3rd degree burnt tongue, but with enough alcohol to pick the patient up from his drowsy, anaesthetized slumber.
WIth the swirl it pours a cloudy dark yellow with small white head.  Aroma of yeast, malt and lemon citrus.  Flavor is crisp with a strong yeasty lemony zest.  Wheaty finish.

From 12 oz. bottle.  Pours a cloudy yellow with small white head.  Yeasts, coriander, spice and some lemon in the nose.  Flavor is refreshing, with lemon, and spices up front, with a smooth wheat finish.  Nice.
Cloudy yellow colour with a white head. Lemon and cloves in the aroma. Flavor of lemon and some hints of cloves and yeast. Dry finish with some hints of cloves.

On Tap at the Sports Bar, John F Kennedy Airport 28/09/2005
Golden coloured and cloudy in appearance. Lemon aroma. Slightly creamy on the palate with some dryness in the finish.

Poured a nice looking light yellow/white color.  Decent looking white head that lasted the entire beer.  No lacing.  Citrus smell with a slight tobacco hint.  Taste starts off like an American amber and then the typical white spices kick in.  Has an almost Tootsie Roll flavor to the finish.

This beer offers a hearty aroma consisting of wheat, yeast, lemon and citrus fragrances.  It is a cloudy light yellow colored solution with a decent white head and good lacing.  This beer has a sweet taste infused with the flavors of wheat, yeast, and lemon.  The finish is a little dry.
Bottle (Cantillon Open Brewing Day): Suprising american hop flavour and aroma. Lemon gold in colour. Spicy witbier flavour with a grassy, citric hop finish. Refreshing, and different.

Bottled: Yellow coloured. Hazy. White dense head. Wheaty and corianderspiced aroma. Flavour has yeast and fruity characters with some subtle spice notes. Is quite crips, citric and dry, but is a little too bland for my likings. Yet its easy to drink and quite enjoyable.

Bottle poured a cloudy yellow with a large, lasting white head. Aromas of citrus and coriander. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of citrus and criander with a crisp, refreshing finish. Would be a great summer thirst quencher.
Bottle-Poured out a cloudy yellow golden with a nice thin white head.The aroma is citrusy and lemony as well as the taste.Thin body,an ok beer,I guess.

Bottled. Pours a cloudy light yellow color. Aroma is sweet and slightly citric up front. Some grain as well. Sweet and mildly yeasty up front. Some grassy characteristics. Well rounded flavor and very easy sipping.

A hazy yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is extremely lemony - just like squeezing a lemon right under Your nose. The flavor is sweet wheaty - again with loads of lemon - almost like lemonade, leading to a dry spicy end, that reminds me of lemongrass. The body is thin. OK - but too much lemon for me.

the allagash classic. a great brew to drink any time. cloudy golden colour with a nice white head. tastes spicey with a bit of fruity flavors and yeast overtones. like others have said, a great summertime brew but really enjoyable anytime. thats why im drinking it now

had on tap. pours a cloudy pale golden with a thick head.  its a very nice white, a bit sweet with a lemony citrus taste.  this is very easy to drink and imagine it would be unstoppable in the summertime.

Allagah White pours to a hazy, very pale yellow color with a thick white head, and a lively carbonation. The nose on this beer is very inviting with lots of orange aromas paired with some peppery coriander. The palate is lean on the tongue, with tart and refreshing wheat character, paired with some citrus flavors and an under pinning of spice. Allagash White finishes with more citrus and tart wheat notes, then ends with a slight spicy note that lingers on the tongue. 

This is an excellent domestic example of a classic Belgian beer style, and the perfect beer to pair with a number of dishes.

Draught @ 1601 bar.  A solid white, stands up to the classic example set by hoegaarden easily (spoken by a former religious devotee of hoegaarden beer).  Light, sweet, juicy, lemon, wheat, and yeast notes in good balance.  Like tasting a sip of tangy spring dew.  The head is beautiful, a creamy little cloud mountain.
Nice frothy white head.  Very pale light gold and a little cloudy.  Big bubble gum aroma.  Flavor is light and slightly spice and bubble gum.  Texture is velvety and smooth.  Fairly good.

Bottle.  Citrus and spice on the nose.  Smallish head.  Had this on tap in Vermont a couple of years ago and was looking forward to tasting again.  Much flater than the tap.  Flavors of citrus acidity but not as clean and smooth.  Somewhat watery causing the flavors to not be so intense.  Ill have it again when I see it on tap.

Cloudy yellow color, great thick fluffy head, I just love belgian whites so I loved this, awesome spiciness, I would say coriander big time and some lemon zest, and slight orange peel, and very slight banana aftertaste. This was damn good.

Bottle. Pours a pale yellow, cloudy, bubbly body with a foamy bone white head. Thinned out some with some decent lacing. Yeasty, lemon straw, with some background spice scents. Sweet lemon, malty flavor with some nice banana hints. Thin, lightly spiced finish. Nice, tasty beer, but seems to be missing something. I could see myself drinking a few of these.
pale yellow slightly cloudy, hint of spice in the aroma, fairly good stuff, has a clean easy drinking body and taste is of spice, maybe a hint of lemons.
UPDATED: SEP 5, 2009 simply delicous. I love this beer so much and I always think of it right away when I want something to refresh with.
for a witbier, this wasnt nearly as crisp as I would have expected. I found it to be a tad too rounded. It has the right look, decent aroma, but it just falls short for me.

On tap at Bian Barus in Portland. hazy golden color with a nice head. aroma is slightly citrus and a hint of spice. taste has some orange, coriander, some slight peppery, spicy hints. nice and smooth. A very solid beer, not as good as the Triple, but  i would never turn one down.
"Wow surprising this beer is very good. Pours a nice cloudy golden color. Nice amount of head. Along the same lines as Hoegaarden, with with a little less sweetness. Will do this beer again."

12. oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy straw color with a small-mod size white head.  Smells of orange-lemon with the spiciness of coriander, and a little yeast.    Very fruity, though not like a Blue Moon.  Lotta coriander in the taste as well.  No bitterness at all.  I like it.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: The aroma is bananas, cloves, lemon grass, pepper, and of course wheat. The appearance is golden with a white cloudiness. The flavor is nutmeg, coriander, citrus, banana, and malt. The palate is thin but acceptable. This was my first beer for 2006 and a good way to welcome in the new year.

Bright yellow in colour and somewhat hazy. Strong carbonation. Strong lemon aromas, with more subtle hints of grapefruit and black pepper. The coriander comes through much stronger in the mouth, and theres even a bit of grassy hop flavor in there too... along with your typical citrus/banana/bubble gum wit flavors. A bit more bitter and grassy than I would like, and the body is a touch watery, but this is still a solid wit.

Medium yellow, hazy appearance, with a large, frothy head to start that diminished rather quickly.  Very nice spicyness in the aroma.  Both citrusy and spicy in flavor.  Probably not the best time of year to try for the first time, but it was still a pretty good Witbier.

This seems like a warm weather beer, and unfortunately Im tasting it while its cold outside.  Anyway, pours a translucent gold with white, smooth head.  Nose is very lemony.   Taste begins spicy and lemony, fades off into a very nice banana finish.  Very refreshing, although a bit out of place in cold weather.  Mouthfeel is a little on the watery side, but that would probably be welcomed in the hot summer months.  Overall, rivals a good pilsener in terms of refreshing-ness.

Bottle. Pours the greatest hue of orange with a pretty minimal head. Yeasty scents abound with a slight starfruit scent towards the end. Banana flavors with slight nutmeg aftertaste. Sparking mouthfeel. This is the best Belgian white Ive had. Its like spring in a bottle.

Pours a cloudy golden orange with lots of sediment. Head is large and white. Aroma is the typical citrus/coriander taste of a white beer.  Taste is well balanced. Mild taste of citrus and spice with a very dry finish.
The color was dark whiteish yellow.  Very thin head.  No aroma.  Not all that hoppy but it was very smooth.

Aroma of coriander, slight hint of white pepper, mild lemony citrus, notable wit yeast.  Appears a pale straw color with noticeable suspended yeast but with very litle true haze; minimal white head that dissipates.  Flavor is mildly spicy, mildly citrusy, but not particularly bold as a wit goes.  Palate is thin and watery, light even by wit standards.  Overall this beer is somewhat disappointing but still serviceable, and it is slightly less than the sum of its parts.

Has the hot dog water smell I associate with authentic Belgian Witbier. Lemon fruit yellow with a two finger thick white head. Lots of coriander yeasty wheat notes. Mild citrus spritziness in the finish. That finish is also dry and somewhat tart. Decent Witbier.

I drink Allagash when I go to my favorite pizza place in State College. It doesnt amaze me, but its decent. Id rather have Hoegaarden if its available, but if not, I settle for Allagash.  If you want a white, ok, you drink this before Blue Moon (or dont drink Blue Moon at all!)

12 oz bottle. Yellow pour with a slight haze, small white head. Nose is wheat and a touch of coriander. Flavor is weighted more toward the wheat than the coriander. Crisp finish. Best non-Belgian white Ive tasted.
a solid belgian white.  aroma of banana and coriander.  wheaty texture, yeasty and well balanced.
cloudy white with little head.  smells of coriander and banana.  smooth palate with no alcohol hint.  a little wheaty and sour.  small bottle to have active yeast fermantation.

Poured a cloudy, light yellow with a white-brerad looking head that diminished rather quickly. The nose was spicy with coriander, clove, and a touch of citrus and banana. The taste started with a great balance of orange/lemon notes. Coriander and white pepper notes join in the middle, along with some slightly tropical fruit, like banana, and then a little clove. The end brings a mild hop smack and fairly dry champagne like finish. The mouthfeel was medium. The balance was remarkably dead on. An excellent wit that is well rounded in flavor with a nice spicinesse to it. Definately worth a try. A great example of an American Wit!

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2012 (Bottle) Yellow body, clearish but then cloudy w/ addition of swirled yeast from bottom of bottle. Fluffy white head. Good lacing. Nose is wheat malt, spices, hint of sour. Flavorful  - wheaty and spicy with a lemony zing. Mouthfeel clean and refreshing. UPDATE 7/13/13: Having had this beer on draft numerous times, I have to uptick it. Beautifully balanced and spiced, excellent witbier Im lucky to have easy access to. Rating shown represents an average of initial and current number.
Pours cloudy yellow with no lasting head.  Aroma of wheat and spice, tastes a little watery with appropriate citrus and spice notes.  Refreshing but a little unrefined.

On tap.  Not a bad witbier, though I have had better.  It pours a very hazy white, with a small, quickly dissipating head.  There are some nice lemon tones with a yeasty aftertaste.  The problem is an almost unmistakable hint of Pine Sol, which really just dampened the spirit of this beer for me.  Not bad, but not the best.

12 oz bottle.  I tell you what ... this is every bit as good as Hoegaarden.  The aroma might be a little weak when its cold, but when it warms up, it releases copious amounts of citrus, yeast and spice (corriander mostly).  Sweet and fruity mouthfeel.  Wheaty, yeasty and citrus-y flavor.  Excellent beer.

Pours hazy yellow with a mid-sized white head. Coriander, yeast, and wheat in the aroma. The yeast is more noticeable in the flavor than in that of a Hoegaarden. Good, but doesnt beat Hoegaarden on drinkability.
On tap at The Village Tap.  Poured a cloudy yellow.  Had orange and banana aromas. Was a bit thin in the palate. I expected a little more, but all in all a good, easy drinking beer.
Bottle 12 oz. Hazy amber with moderate rocky white head that diminished quickly. Medium wheat aroma with smooth texture. Medium sweet wheat flavor witha small sweet finish.
12oz. bottle. Hazy yellow/golden color with a large white head. Aroma of coriander, citrus and yeast. Flavor was on the sweet side, with a lot of coriander, some lemon and oranges. Not bad.
Franziskaner is better for the price. This is good, just a little overdone (too much orange peel?) for me.

Bottle. Hazy golden straw color, lots of sediment, with big white head. Aromas of orange, lemon, cloves, spiced tea, wet grass, wheat, yeast, and faint pisslike sourness. Flavor delivers on all of these. Medium body, very smooth carbonation, and a fantasticly drawn-out sweet & sour finish. Very enjoyable.... AND, its beer no. 100! Many thanks to Kinz for getting me onto the site. Its all downhill from here; dear god.....

Thanks Kevin!
Tasted at the South Western Ontario Gathering, in London, Ontario. Pours deep hazy yellow, with a huge foamy head. Smells like lemony corriander, wiht some licorice, and all spice.
