Some clove as well. Tastes like a regular wheat, plus tax! Lots of spices and cloves, black pepper too. One of my favourites. Yall know I jadore blanche!

Thanks a lot for sharing Kevin! This is a great wit in my opinion. Pours cloudy yellow, with a huge frothy and creamy looking head. Aromas are orange peel, corriander, some other spices. Taste is fruity, then some spices, almost minty. Very good. Nice balance here. Finish is sweet aftertaste, creamy mouthfeel, medium bodied. Thanks again Mustang3!

750 ml corked bottle, Batch #21. Hazy pale yellow colour with a white frothy head and lots of floating particulate. Lemon, light orange peel, and coriander aroma. Dry lemony citrus and lightly yeasty flavours. Light bodied, creamy but refreshing.

Bottle. Hazy light yellow with big explosive foamy white head & floaties. Initial aroma is hoppy with nutmeg spiciness coming through, and some orange julius. Flavor is hoppy with biscuity malt, some earthiness and a hint of yeast. Very nice

Curiously metallic tasting on the intial taste, this one smooths out to a gentle sweetish sipper.  Spicy! A bit heavier than some wheats, but it is a BELGIAN style wheat so I guess that is to be expected. another fine beer from Allagash.

Bottle poured a hazy yellow with a crisp yeasty aroma. 
Flavor is citrus, yeast, spice with a light spicy finish.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2005 This is a good witbier.  It pours a golden straw color with two fingers of white head and has nice lacing.  It has a strong citrus smell (lemons).  The taste is very good with the citrus and spice complementing each other nicely.  One of my favorite witbiers.

Not the biggest fan of witbiers, but this one was pretty solid. Spices were not overdone. Cloudy golden yellow with huge white head. Aromas were clove, orange, almonds, and vanilla. Yeast was also big. Flavor had a good yeast backbone with a good mix of the previously mentioned spices.
Well done Belgian wheat...with wheat grain/citric aroma.   Fruitiness and new mowed hay flavor components.  Bit of hoppy bite in the finish.   Very strong yeast flavors as well.
Bottle poured yellow with  lots of hazy, and a good yeast nose. Aroma also had some spice.  I do not know if I truly dislike this style, but I did not like this.

Draft.  A great-smelling witbier, with coriander and nutmeg spice, lots of yeast, and lemon citrus accompanying grain and a light caramel malt nose.  On the palate, the beer is long-lasting and fresh-tasting.  Apricot and hopcit, with  a complementary tandem of hop and malt.  Also spice on the tongue, and the "white" flavors of yeast and wheat with a full mouthfeel.  An excellent example -- from America!
very impressive!! this beer is a great drinking beer. very smooth with a nice spicey flavor.  looking forward to more from allagash

Bomber, batch 16:  Sugary and sweet aromas with some spiciness there as well.  Flavor was that of big oudoors, hay fields, sweet citrus abounds.  Smooth and full mouthfeel, finishes with strong citrus.
Batch 16. Pours pale cloudy yellow with a big, frothy white head. Nose is grassy and spicy with pepper and lemons. Taste is light pepper, grassy/hay and some spices. Thin palate.

Poured straw yellow with a thick head with very short retention.  Good carbonation.  Aroma had orange, banana, citrus,lemon and cloves.  Some tangerine as well.  There was quite a bit of tangerine in the flavor.  It was overdone on the lemon and citrus.  Mouthfeel was tart but alright.  Pretty good.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2009 08.19.05  12oz bottle.  The usual pale straw, totally clouded, and a thick white head that almost instantly fades leaving no lace.  Aroma is a bit flat, mostly corriander and other savories, some lighter orange, tangerine.  Flavor is sadly plain with only citrus and spice and not terribly interesting at that...bit too heavy on the spice, it gets oily and cloying with temp.  Too bad, I realy liked it on the first sip.
20090417  bump up... Ive been enjoying this beer more and more over the last couple years and just recently even kicked off the new kegerator with this stuff.  Very nice, sessionable example of a traditional wit.  Nice balance of spice, malt, and body.  Soft and creamy, enough bite to keep it interesting, and lovely to see.  previous score was 5.3.4.2.10 a travesty!  I get wits now.
A yeasty aroma with a heavy fog clarity.  Not your typical white. Yeasty but good. I liked it...unique flavor.

Pale yellow color, medium sized fluffy white head.  Muted vinous notes, slight weizen spice notes, with citrus and coriander.  Wheat malt, coriander, muted yeasty flavors.  Body is light and effervescent.

A hazy yellow pour with a couple yeast chunks at the bottom of the glass. Grassy, floral, slightly spicy aroma, with a nice, light, spicy taste. Went down totally smooth and is a great beer for a hot summer day.

Pours a very light hazy yellow, almost light green color with a very small amount of fizzy white head.  Aroma is clovey, yeast, orange rind, and citrus.  Flavor is sour and lemony then yeasty then finally dry.  Overall, I wasnt too  much of a fan.

Aroma:wheat,sugar,lemon...
Appearance:Hazy yellow,very light head..
Flavor:Wheat,lemon,vanilla...

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2006 Had this on tap at The Federal. Hazy golden yellow color with lasting head. Low to moderate carbonation. Yeasty nose and flavor with orange peel and coriander, of course. Nice smooth finish. Very good.

Hazy yellow strw color, with a shy foamy white head, spicy coriander, curaçao, orange peels, wheat malt aroma follows through on a light-bodied lemon palate, with a fruity, juicy citrus fruits, tangerines, manderins, spicy coriander, wheat malt, curaçao, in a lemony acidic and soft hoopy finish. A very refreshing beer.

Pour is foggy with some yeast and bright yellow with a thin dense white head...smell is spicy with cloves coriander, sausage, vanilla, lemons...taste is a little more mild than I like...subdued spicyness with a little yeast and a fast fizzy finish...
Muddled and offbalance, but bright in character.  Bottle from happy deli, new york.  Points for character.

I hadnt had this beer in quite some time.  A regular at most bars around here, this beer is worth its prevelance.  Wonderfully drinkable and refreshing, but as a real novice in belgian whites, i leave my comments at that.
Pours gold and cloudy with a thin off white bubbly head.  Smells of apples, peaches, and oranges.  Tastes of oranges and grapefruit with a bitter slightly watery finish.

This Belgian White is a truly outstanding beer. Out of the bottle it has a interesting pour. You pour most of the beer out and then swirl the bottom yeast and pour out the rest. It leaves you with a light, murky, yellow color and a fluffy white head. The smell is strongly of yeast, citrus and spice. The taste jumps out at you with citrus, spicey flavor that quickly finishes into a smooth yeast, wheat combination. This is the perfect beer to introduce anyone to microbrews.
Had a spicey aroma to it. Hazy yellow color with no head. Crisp beer while drinking and got a fruit aftertaste after each drink of the beer. Alright.

A great white beer form the State of Maine. I have only had it on tap though so I dont know if the obttled variety matched the taste out of the tap. ANyone know if its available in the metro DC area?
This was very smooth and pleasant, great smell and flavor, a little bitter after taste. This was very good for an american belgian, i would buy it agian, very drinkable.

Wow, very nice!  Had this one on tap in DC at St. X.  It was served with lemon but I chose to drink half without the addititve flavour.  It is a crisp belgian white with a remarkably clear yellow colour; not cloudy like most belgiuns.  Nice spicy citrus going on which is actually very nice with the lemon addition.  It feels like a great beer for thirst quenching on a hot day.  Not bad at all!  Very easy to drink.  A friend of mine who usually just drinks lighter beer enjoyed his taste of mine so much that he ordered his own.  I only wish this bar was a little more affordable.  $7.70 for a glass???
on tap.  a refreshing brew with flavor of yeast and citrus.  slight spice character.  hazy golden color with slight head.  not enough flavor depth in my opinion.

This starts out with an average sized white head over a very pale yellow body. Almost clear.
Light funky citrus aroma with some sourness that follows in the flavor.
This was o.k. but not as good as others Ive had.

First off I have to say that I dont usually flip over whites, but this one was pretty good. Pours out a cloudy light straw color with a nice white fluffy head. The aroma tells of some spice. The taste is very crisp with the typical wheat taste and a decent spice flavor in the finish

Candied sugar aroma followed by wheat malt.  The appearance, aroma and flavor do not reveal much residual yeast.  Alcohol content appears in the flavor, but less so in the palate, which favors orange peel and wheat tartness.  Overall a near miss of the wit style.

I like a Belgian White in the summer. The Allagash is very nice. Classic opaque pale yellow. Modest head. Spicey aroma. The flavor follows with a subtle spiciness, coriander and bitter orange, perhaps. Creamy on the tongue at first, gliding into a slight bite of bitter, finishing with spice, in a long lasting blend of them all. Refreshing. Likely to become a favorite summer cooler

Very pale yellow and quite cloudy at the same time.  Fluffy white head.  Aroma of yeast, light malts or wheat, bananna and spice.  Light feel which is quitkly pushed aside by a nice spicyness and some mild bananna flavor.  Crisp and active on the palate and a nice clean finish.   Fairly complex, nice beer.  One that is very refreshing and also probably a good starter for those new to beer.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2005 Had this for the first time recently on tap, and I really enjoyed it.  Very refreshing citrus flavor with a surprising spice to it (nice balance, though).  Also one of the few beers that I really like to get my nose into.  Allagash has successfully created a Belgian-style white with its own unique character.

Glowing, cloudy pale yellow in color with a small, fizzy white head.  Aroma is lemon zest, orange rind, sour, yeast, cloves and pepper.  Flavor is sour lemons sprinkled with sugar, pepper and clove.  Much like a stale lemon drop.  Very reserved flavor.  Vanilla overrides other taste elements on the backend of each sip.  A little acidic and spicy on the palate.  Smooth - kept seeming like it wanted to elevate its flavor elements but itd plateau too early.  Finish is like a citric cooler sitting in the sun for an hour.  A little thinning and lacking candi sugar.  A nice quaff, but doesnt come full circle.  Thanks for the New England goodie, tpkenned!

Couleur jaunâtre très trouble et brouillé, parsemé dune faible mousse blanche.  Clou, coriandre et autres épices semblent se moquer des bananes bonbon et du citron quils ont aperçu au loin.  Douce et un peu mince en bouche, semblant légèrement manquer de corps.  Les épices demeurent toujours très présente et semble à la limite de labus.  Tout de même très rafraîchissant après une longue journée sur la route.  En fut au Moan And Dove, 21 Mai 2005.

Bottle:  Cirtusy and sweet with a lot of spice.  Pours a slightly hazy pale yellow, almost whitish-yellow with a small white head.  Rather sweet with a pretty big honey character that lingers in the aftertaste.  There are spices but not enough to balance out the sweetness.  Refreshing, but a touch too sweet to be really good.

Batch #1, 750ML Bottle
Very light yellow in color with a slight haze offset by sparkling effervescence. Nice aromas: Champagne grapes, wheaty yeast, clove and a woody oak background. Sour and dry with a well-spiced finish. Very smooth.


<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Forest, IL<font size=-1>

Pours opaque gold with foamy white head. Aroma is yeast with spice, but not terribly strong. Tastes of belgian yeast, spices, and citrus. This is up there with Hoegaarden as best Belgian whites. Yum. Oops, didnt finish rating the numbers....

From a 750ml bottle. Batch 8.

Pours a hazy yellow gold with a frothy ivory head. Smells of citrus and coriander. Some light fruitiness and sweet wheat malt.

Taste is lightly sour and yeasty. Citrus flavors underlying. Tasty wheat malt with a good bit of spiciness. Very light and crisp on the palate. Soft sour aftertaste. A very drinkable beer, easy to finish a 750ml solo. Damn good and its even better as a summer beer.

Draught at d.b.a. New York. 
Cloudy pale golden. Perfectly refreshing with notes of coriander and orange. Light-medium bodied. Smooth body. A well made Wit.

12 oz bottle drawn into a pint glass.  Pours cloudy, bright yellow in color. Nice aroma. Nice head but didnt hold long.  Really nice, crisp palate. A nice  beer with a good bite. This is an above average beer in one of my favorite styles.

750ml corked bottle ( Thanks Sammy). Decanted to the tumbler a light clouded honey-hued ale with a nice puffy white cap. Moderate effervescence. Wonderful nose...spicey tangerines, sweet and musty. Substantial body for a wit. Lovely sweet malt diffusion at the front then the hops and corriander spice the palate and the yeast gives a pleasant succulent fruit pronouncement. Dryish finish.....a very nice and flavorful witbier.

Pours a cloudy, straw color.  Aroma of orange peel, citrus, nutmeg, and cloves.  Nutmeg upfront, touch of sweetness and well integrated hops.  Really nice, crisp palate.   A nice summer beer.  Not my favorite style though.

On tap. Cloudy, bright yellow in color with a thin white head and some big ol bubbles. Heavy citrus aroma with some yeast. Very easy to drink as a result of the great mouthfeel. Obviously not the best belgian style white beer out there but its still a good beer and nice to see on tap instead of Blue Moon.

Citrus lemon/orange, strong coriander and mild vanilla in the sweet, inviting aroma.  Opaque, milky, white-yellow-gold with low white head that persists and plenty of yeast in suspension.  Some minor lacing.  Honey-like sweetness with bitter orange and coriander spiciness that complement.  Tart and dry in the mildly bitter finish.  Medium-light body with moderate carbonation.  Tulip glass, fridge temp.  Bottle (Half Time, Mar. 2005).
very light cloudy yellow.  Leaves some lacing.  Citrus and coriander flavors.  a relatively thin bodied beer.
Bottle: pours a cloudy lemon yellow with yeast particles. Small white head. Yeasty aroma with light banana hints. Flavor is yeasty, but has hints of meat, like bologna. Still a nice drink.

A refreshing, if kind of thin beer. Its body makes is very drinkable, which can be a nice quality for a belgian white on a hot day. Smells of lemons and yeast, cloudy pale gold color. Lots of lemon in the taste.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy yellow with tons of little floaties.  Virtually no head.  What little there is is white.  Smell is yeasty and lemony.  Very refreshing taste.  Spicy and tangy with some staleness however.  On the thin side.  High carbonation gives it some bite.

All the standard witbier characteristics are there - some obvious spice from a pale golden beer with a thin white head. Yeasty and citrusy too. The lemon perhaps more than the orange, and the coriander wasnt as present as it could have been. Overall a nice beer - drinkable but not one that I would clamour to get.
UPDATED: MAY 26, 2006 Usual body, citrusy spicy aroma. Textbook but done well.

Bottle. Batch 10. Pale golden straw with a white head. Yeasty aroma with wheat and some fruity spice. More wheat flavor and less yeast/spice than Id have thought. Crisp, dry some lemon and corriander, but just not enough going on. Still another disapointment from Allagash - its a brewery that I want to like but just cant.
Great white, nice flavour of peppers and wheat with noticeable corriander.  Slightly thin body but the flavour is very thirst quenching.  A beer I could suck back all summer long.

750 ml, corked and caged.  Pale yellow, cloudy with a thick white head.  Aroma is massively spiced with coriander.  A touch of sweet pipe tobacco.  Flavour is quite spicy, coriander, yeasty clove.  Body is a bit thin as well.  A simple beer, but very well made.
Tap.  Opaque and yeasty pour.  Lemons and spices abound on the nose.  LIght and refreshing.  Very good.  Finish is clean.  Makes you want more.

Bottle at Fall Beerfest In Toronto 2004.  Aroma was spicy, with bananas, oranges and lemons.  Flavour was spicy, bready, orange citrus.  Medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes with lingering spices.
Great clouded, murky yellow body under a thick white head with great lacing.  Delicious spiciness, but with a surprisingly light, dry finish.  Interesting.

shaker / before i poured i just sunk my nose into the bottle and left it there so i can inhale a very nice aroma of maltiness, banana, warm and sugary spice much like around Christmas when the gingerbread cookies are fresh out of the oven and some hot cinnamon candle can be wiffed from another room... yum. the body looks traditional: lightly translucent yellow body, but a little sediment makes it a bit nice and cloudy. the head is white, frothy, and diminishes while leaving thick, scattered, and sparkly lace. how about the palate? smooooth and full! the flavor? it mimics the aroma. the fruitiness and citrusness and such hits first then im left with a lingering banana and spice. this is a REALLY good brew!

I have been waiting to get this for a while since its been getting glowing reviews from others.  Finally got it and it will be number 400!  A great white beer.  Very sweet and citrusy.  Easily up there with Hoegarden.  Would love to have this on tap.
A good belgian witbier, citrus, yeasty, with a spicy bite.

This ones getting high marks from me. Great rendition of the style. Since Celis White no longer tastes like Celis White, I now have its replacement. Pours a cloudy lemony color. I added a lemon towards the end to see what kind of difference was made; this one is so good the lemon wasnt necessary. Extremely drinkable & refreshing. Goes into the immediate rotation. Is it summer yet?
On draft in Hampton VA.  Opaque, but bright yellow with a thin fizzy head.  Sweet yeasty aroma here, with a hefe-like banana yeast flavor.

Bottle: Poured a hazy yellowish color ale with a big head that disappeared a tad too quickly. Aroma of coriander is easily detectable with some wheat also noticeable in the background. Taste is quite amazing with a nice mix of coriander, wheat and some orange in the background. Very refreshing but with a strong full body and light carbonation. Probably one of the best north American wit I had the chance to drink.

Batch # 16.  The freshest bottle I could find.  Cloudy yellow/orange in color with a large and thick head of foam.  Exotic aromas of mango and apricots along with a touch of coriander.  A very light example of the style.  Southamptpn Double White really spoiled me because I havent had a white beer that satisfied my desires ever since.  Its a shame really.  This example is fairly simplistic with notes of green apples, passion fruits and coriander combined with a fairly rich and creamy palate.
Pours a hazy yellow with a small bubbled white head. This was a nice crisp wit, lots of citrus and yeasty character. Some fruity esters along with a wheaty taste. Very refreshing and easy drinking.
Batch #10, yellow color, nice white head, minimal lacing, smells of wheat, nice taste of wheat, hence a nice wheat beer.
Tap: Baby chick yellow.  Very small amount of white head.  Slight spicy aroma.  Dry finish.
Poured a cloudy yellow with a small white head.  Rich vinuous and spicy aroma.  Taste is very spicy with a bitter finish... crisp, dry, and refreshing, but overall thin for a Belgian style.

very hazy golden color as thought the liquid soaked half of the light out of the room and allowed it to gently ooze back out through the glass.  Yeasty off white head with good retention.  Aggressive yeasty aroma with a touch of light fruit.  Rich mouthfeel with plenty of well-balanced malt and subtle spice.  Refreshing finish that made me want to back again for sip after sip.  There must be plenty of Belgians in Maine!

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2005 This poured a slightly hazy pale straw color with a respectable frothy head that remained only briefly.  The aroma is grainy with tart citric scents and some spiciness.  This is a neatly spiced, flavorful drink.  Theres a yeasty fruitiness to it, a citric hoppiness, spices, and some grassiness.  Nice dry, spicy finish.  A good interpretation.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Armanetti, Willowbrook, IL<font size=-1>

Color is crystal-clear pale yellow, with a mountainous, lacey, bubbly white head of foam. Nose is dry, sea-foamy fresh, with hibts of citrus, straw, some sly spiciness. Actually quite lovely, the perfect aromatic profile for a wit. 
Later on, the citrus and spice becomes bolder and takes a long ride on the palate. Not a wit for the faint of heart, this has more and more flavor as it unfolds in the mouth and nose. More floral and perfumey aspects show up. Texture is grainy, yeasty, and quite a delicious mouthfull. Hops are high, dazzling, citrus-soaked. Light body, but excellent texture, abundant flavor.
A very tasty and satisfying Belgian-style white ale, mellow and smooth. In 3 words or less: yummy, yum,yum!
Yeast, citrus and some malt in the aroma, hazy golden, pours a nice white head. Soft malt taste, light bodied, refreshing. Very nice.

Orange and corriander flavors are more subdued than in some other Belgian white ales.  Seems to be an Americanized version with slightly more hop flavor, and a darker color (still quite light)  than its Belgian counterparts.  Overall a very easy to drink beer.
Hazy yellow colour. Funky, spicey aroma with a faint whiff of skunk. Typical flavours of citrus and spice. Nice dry finish. [Toronto Christmas Party 04]

Bottle at Dougs, Christmas 2004.  Yellow colour, fairly clear with white head.  Slightly citrusy aroma with some spice.  Taste is a little bland really, what you would expect from the style, but nice enough I guess.  Quaffable.  Everything about this beer seemed fine, I just found it boring.

12oz bottle.  Hazy blonde with a small head and some lacing.  Yeasty, spicy, hoppy aromas give a good indication of the flavors to follow.  Light to medium bodied, with a crisp and refreshing character.  Dry, spicy finish.  I had this after being in heaven with a Trois Pistoles, and it didnt disappoint.  Im wishing I had picked up the 4-pack instead of a single.  Tasty and excellent!

Batch 10. cloudy pale yellow w/ fluffy white head.  Aroma is lightly malty, yeasty, spicy, & citrusy w/ an underlying lemony tartness. Light, somewhat gritty feel. Flavour is  sweet, yeasty & spicy. Finish is dry & appetizing.

Pours Cloudy pale yellow, which a nice white head. Yeast aromas. Taste is dry and crisp, much like a nice brut champagne. I expected the spicy tastes to be more predominent, in this beer I only barely notice them at all. The spices are there, though. Just look for them. All things considered, this is one of the best wheat beers Ive had. Remarkable.
Thanks to whoever brought this to the Toronto Christmas Party 04.  Yeasty wheaty nose.  Sweet lemon wheet flavor.  Hints of clove.  Easy to drink but I almost want something more challenging.
Bottle.  Light yellow color with a little haze.  Yeast and citric aroma.  Fairly delicate beer and harder to rate when surrounded by big beers.  Tart and spicey in taste.  Decent.

750 ml Bottle. Toronto Christmas Party 2004. Light hazy pastel yellow body. Tart yeasty lemon citrus aroma. Flavour has plenty of tart wheat with some notes of lemon throughout. Bit bland, but a decent Wit. Palate was a touch light for a wit but average otherwise. Thanks to whomever brought this, it has been on my wishlist for a while.
Pours a cloudy gold with a lasting head.  Aroma of orange poeel and coriander.  Flavor also has lots of wheat and a little lemon.  Good mouthfeel.  A good beer for the style.
Bottle  at the  Syracuse Holiday Brewfest Dec.04 2004. Hazy white beer with a pleasant banana lemony aroma. Lightly sweet  wheat with sour points. Good and creamy mouthfeel.

This poured out a dull yellow that was quite cloudy and had about a fingers worth of white head. Decent retention as it eventually fell to a bubbly cap it left good lacing about the glass. Aroma is comprised of a slight lemon scent with notes of spice and yeast mingling about as well. Taste is very similar as a wheaty yeasty flavor is supported by a zesty lemon and a bit of spice. This is very effervescent and has a slightly bitter finish. Mouthfeel is good as is the carbonation and it is very drinkable. Overall a good, refreshing example of a witbier.
Cloudy gold color, soft but distinct, wheat banana tart fruit aroma, taste is exactly like the aroma, nicely blended, but this flavor combination doesnt really work for me

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2004 Corriander spice is not my favorite. Bitter finish, with lemon to enhance the weak impression on the palate. Probably good for grilling chicken or fish.  Much better in he bottle, more colour and richer mouthfeel.

Very disappointing.  Aroma of citrus fruit.  Looks really good, cloudy yellow like lemonade.  Flavor of light lemon, like a Stiegl lemon beer.  Sour finish.  No complexity, no sweetness that I have come to expect from this style.
UPDATED: APR 11, 2005 Tap in Ballston, VA. Pours a very cloudy, and quite opaque shade of swirly tan (as I call it) for a witbier. Very nice flavor. I really like this one. Tastes good.

Batch #1, 750 ml bottle. Cloudy gold nice head and retention. Spices in the aroma of pepper and cloves. Taste is similar to Hoegaarden with a bit different yeast. Light, crisp and nicely nalted, this is improved with age.

Confirming my notion that small samples should NOT be rated. I had a taste of this at an in-store tasting and thought very little of it even though I went back and tried it about three times. Having a full pint made a world of difference. The has the character of a Belgian wit that I love: spice, but not so as to mask other elements and a luscious mouthfeel. Delicious.
tap. cloudy cleach blonde... wheaty with a hint of lime... excellent wit.... just like me... haha
Sampled at Charlotte Oktoberfest 04.  A very cloudy golden appearance with a small white head.  The flavor was extremely citrusy with mild spice thrown in.  An excellent wit.

Bottle:  Pours golden in color with a large frothy head that quickly diminishes.  Aroma:  Lemon, yeast, banana, pineapple, orange rind.  Taste:  lemon, bitter banana, yeast, wheat, KFC biscuits towards the end.  Just enough sour & bitter flavors to make it very refreshing and easy to drink.

Cloudy grayish yellow with big fluffy haed, seems very carbonated.  Nose is spicy and lemony.  Yeasty flavor isnt overpwered by the spices (coriander, lemon peel, pepper), biscuity and dry at the finish.
Draft. Cloudy faint gold. Minimal head. Some sort of flowery aroma wafts out. Little bit of twang on the tongue. Easy drinking. Dry finish. Enjoyable in multiples. Decent!
Hazy Honey Coloring. Small Head.  Some Citrus, Wheat and Spices.. Not Very Far off The Beaten Path.
Yellow color with a small head.  Fairly spicy wheat nose.  Taste is kind of the same old wheat and citrus blend you would expect.  Decent enough, but not too special.

Pours a hazy pale yellow with a white head. Aroma is malty and lightly spicy. Taste is of yeast, light malt, lemon, some hops, corriander and orange peel. Mouthfeel is full, round and refreshing. Not my favorite style, but a quality witbier.

Smells strongly of bread yeast with floral and citrus hints. Hazy peach color with little head. Has a sports drink appearance. The body is soft on the tongue but the flavor is sharp and tart with a complex Belgian flavor. Low corriander aroma and flavor. Some bitter orange. Finishes dry and slightly bitter. Very quenching. If it had a bigger head and body it would be exceptional, but is very good nonetheless.

Really a great witbier I think.  Bought this in a 6-pack and convinced my roommate to try one.  Then he drank two more.  He was really impressed, and so was I.  Well-rounded and good on spice and yeast.

Pours a clouded yellow with a white head lacing the top.  Smells of fresh spice.  Refresingly tart flavor that eases into a backdrop of spices.  I would like to taste some orange peel in there.  Not bad.
Foggy And Yellow, Little head.  Lacking in the Spicy flavor area but pretty good yeast flavor.  Not a bad stab at the Wit. Probably one of my favorite attempts to date.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2004 Appearance is cloudy yellowish, no head. Smell is sweet, but nothing overpowering. taste is citrusty, with the yeasty grass flavor mixed in there- but obvious citrus. A good, well-rounded beer.

Pale yellow color, no head, lightly carbonated. Aroma is straw and citrusy, like an orange. Flavor is peppery. Finish is very dry, no aftertaste. A bit bland for a wit, be sure to pour all your yeast in for the most flavor. Nothing special about this beer.

tap at blind tiger. Extremely cloudy pale yellow hue. Classy looking. Highly carbonated, but creamy mouthfeel at the same time. I love the expressive malt in here, cookie-ish and grassy. Lots of lime flavor, smooth witbier that manages to be flavorful and feel as light as can be.

Pours a cloudy light yellow with a good creamy head and great lacing.  Yeasty nose with lots of orange and coriander.  Spicy flavors with pepper and clove notes.   Creamy textrure and a nice lemon finish.

many thanks to reverend baxter for recommending this as a good beer to order with out trivia winningds at the grey lodge. hazy and quite pale, lemon meringue aroma, nice little hint of cream cheese. quite spicy and peppery, some clove and pleasant lemon finish

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2004 I've had two very different experiences with this beer on tap. The first time, I really enjoyed it. The second time, I suggested it to friend who's a big fan of wits and was almost embarrassed by my selection. The second time through, I found it had sort of a buttery, olive oil character which I never noticed before. Also, diacetyl was clearly there and I don't think any amount of it, no matter how subtle, should be in a wit. You can do worse, but really, you can do way better.

 Original Rating: Pale and hazy (what else?), sheet of lace. Excellent. Extremely vibrant, spicy with a strong citrus character. Probably the best wit Ive had.

nice head and a pale yellow, cloudy,  color. nice flavors, spicy and wheaty but fairly clean. doesnt have the wildish and sour flavors of hoegaarden. still very good for and american version of a blanche.
OBF 2004: Nice, fresh wheat aroma. Lightly spiced and really good. Slightly tart and refreshing. Enjoyable beer.

One of the better Belgian wheat beers made in the US, if not the best. Similar to Blue Moon but less distinctive orange/citrus notes. Yeasty smell and a wonderful golden yellow color. Large head. Effervescent. Very smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle. Typical hazy yellow color. Nose is floral and doughy. Has some notes of orange and yeast. There are some notes of wheat and black pepper. The finish is very unpleasant. Going down, it tastes like dirty water with a little bit of sourness. This is a good example of the style, but it is a style that I do not appreciate. If you like Witbier, youll like this.

Thanks to civforprez for sharing this bomber. I have had a fair number of witbiers now and I think I can fairly judge this compared to similar brews. Pours a very cloudy light yellow color. The very pale color put me off a bit. Formed a huge fluffy head in my glass. The aroma is the standard orange zest, ginger and bread. The taste was bready with a zesty orange and a finish like dirt. Also had a little corriander and some pepper spice, but these were too light to add much character. Has a lively carbonated mouthfeel. Pretty good for the style, but there are better ones out there.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2004 Came back and rerated. Overall, after having a few on different days, I conclude that this beer leaves me feeling as though I just ate some butter, bread, and maybe some mild peppers. Definately unique. However, I think this is a little to weird for me.

Served on tap.  Cloudy straw-colored body, thin white head.  Light grain husk aroma plus sweet bubblegum and lemon.  The flavor has wheat bread, stewed apricot, and some leafy hops.  Lemon citrus compliments the flavor as well.  This seems like a heavy-handed wit because the lemon and spice flavors felt like they were tossed on top as an afterthought, not blending well with the basic wheat beer elements.

This was the first Belgian Whilte Ive ever enjoyed and I was extremely impressed.  The color of the beer is very unique light but somewhat cloudy. Its refreshing qualities are perfect for a hot summer day.  If youre lucky enough to enjoy it on tap youll get a much better experiance then the bottle offers.

Bottle into small plastic tasting cup, Humulus Lupus @ Jaks Tap (Chicago).  Pale yellow and hazy.  Smelled of grapefruit and some yeast.  Weakly acidic with interestingly sweet hops.  The finish was a bit disappointing: it was short and was vinegary.  Not great, but not crap.
Very very nice wit.  A little spicy with a smooth, yeasty body.  Crisp and well-balanced.  Looking forward to another.

I really really like this Wit. Clean and crisp and lemony.  Faint spicy undertone.  Very much resembles a German Hefeweizen. Another great beer from Allagash. It appears at this point they know their belgian brews and do a terrific job reproducing them. I enjoyed this one even more than I did the grand cru. Definitely a beer to accumulate.

750 ml - batch 13.  From the aroma thru the fiinish, this was true to style.  I would agree with many raters assesments of the refreshing qualities, but was surprised by the spiciness (in a nice way).  The pur was a light golden color, with a frothy, resilient head.   Nice crisp finish.  There was more character to this Witbier than any Ive had to date.

Hazy pale gold color with a soft velvety head and lacing, and a spicy, citrusy cilantro aroma. Light and tangy on the tongue, with  mellow flavors of wheat, coriander and clove. The finish was short with a light lemon zest bitterness. I thought this one had more of a Belgian touch to it than a couple other U.S. versions Ive tried. Very refreshing.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2011 My limited experience with Allagash products has been a bit hit or miss in my pleasure. I was intrigued by their wit however.+++ Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle the beer poured a hazy pale yellow color with a small white head. The aroma was a pleasant mix of sour, tangy, spicy, and wheat. The flavor was dry spice and wheat with a hint of citrus. Overall a reasonable interpretation of the wit style containing all the elements expected, though not managing to really stand out from the crowd.

This is probably the best Wit Ive had, and its not a style I really love.  Color is dead on for style with a very pale, hazy color and nice full head.  Nice wheaty, citrusy flavor and very refreshing.  Nice to have this back in IL

Bottle pours pale yellow, almost white, somewhat hazy, small fizzly white head,  spotty lacing, with virtually no carbonation.   Aroma of curacao and orange peel, slight american wheat ale aroma.   Forwardly spicey, slight citrus, good wheaty mouthfeel.   Just the right amount of spices in this one to make it well balanced.   Finishes with a slight orange peel flavor.   Probably my favorite Wit next to Vuuve, not overly spicey but yet full of flavor.
On tap. Poured a hazy yellow in color with a small white head. Aromas and tastes of citris, light spices and yeast.
On tap at The Gate.  Poured a cloudy yellowish/white with a yeasty/lemony aroma.  Taste was also yeasty and lemony.  A very light beer, decent but not great.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2005 12 oz bottle.  Zesty wit/white beer true to the style.  Another excellent Allagash product.

Sampled again on draft at the Druids Keep.  This time, I was overwhelmed by the lemony zest.
possibly the best belgian white ive had.  very flavorful.  crisp, refreshing.  spicy, some citrus.  very well balanced.  super cloudy, nice head.  very nice.
Cloudy brew that is a bit yellow. A smooth flavor that is good to enjoy.  Lemon maybe in the taste

Judging by the rating, this beer hasn't gotten any better with age.  The first raters were full of praise and now it's lucky to see better than 14 overall. This wasnt half as good as other whites Ive had.  The aroma was decent and the flavor wasnt bad, but it wasnt anything special.

750ml batch #7 - Pours a hazy golden with orange hues. The head is a quickly collapsing foamy white affair. Lemon aroma predominates, also a fair amount of spices and yeast. Surprisingly bitter, hops play a bigger part int his Wit than I am used to. Lemon is subdues bitterness is realitively high. Crisp medium-light body. A nice Wit, I like the bitterness.
To me this beer smelled and tasted very soapy. A very light beer that goes down easy, but just tastes not so good.
White head, medium retention. Body is clear, yellow. Aroma is slightly belgian, pale malt? Medium body on the lighter side. Light taste of wheat, not much belgian flavor. A little bit of a let down.
A pretty generic white, mild smooth flavor, very drinkable. Very carbonated, a little spice, a little bite but not what I had hoped for.
user_location: New York, east village, New York, USA

text: With a so-so aroma and lackluster appearance, the flavor is left to carry this beer. And it does an OK job, with its moderately bitter finish and spices up front.

A mild in flavor white. Nothing too remarkable about this, but it is enjoyable. Looks beautiful and is full of carbonation.  Head dissipates quickly. Delivers a typical belgian white flavor. Lightly spiced, a little sugar, and some citrus. A little too watery for me. Overall not bad.
Little smell.  Dull yellow color with fizzy head with no lacing.  Light flat taste with not much to talk about.

(Bottle) Corn yellow in color with apparent haziness and with a nice white head. More carbonation than I normally like.  I am not usually a fan of Witbiers, but this one was not too bad.  A decent drinkable beer.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2004 Mild, lightly sweet, corn-flavored maltiness is unexpected but welcomed in this balanced wit beer; Mildly spicy flavor is very much in balance early on, but tends to pick up steam in the finish as the maltiness subsides; Light bitterness in the finish as well; The aroma is sweet and lightly malty, kind of like corn as well, but really with very little spiciness; Expansive mouthfeel from carbonation, and fairly clean; Yellowish golden color and slightly cloudy; White head is surprisingly small considering the carbonated mouthfeel, dissipates very quickly and leaves no lacing whatsoever

UPDATED: APR 18, 2004 Light, dull, hazy yellow color with lots of tiny floating sediment and bubbles; good-sized white head with lacing down the entire glass.  Aroma of spice and citrus.  Flavor is definitely spicy, with hints of citrus and banana.  Mouthfeel is reasonably clean and pleasant.
Smells clean, pours great with thick head.  Very refreshing and not as yeasty as one might expect from the somewhat cloudy appearence in the glass.

Pours slightly turbid, very pale yellow, with great head and lacing.  Huge aromas of yeast, citrus, fruit, and hops.  Tastes citrusy, yeasty, with hints of chardonnay and coriander.  Finishes dry, crisp, slightly bitter with yeast at the end.

I have always liked belgian whites, and this is one of the better that I have had. But, it still does not even come close to hoegaarden white, which is hands down my favorite belgian white. This beer is certainly still worth a try. A nice refreshing and easy to drink beer.
(Bottle)  Pours a murky maze color with a thin white (quickly diminishing) head.  Has a wheat and spicy herbs aroma.  Flavor of banana, wheat, and nutmeg.
has a smell of bananas and a yellow pour.  sweet tasting, nice looking and smelling white.  im just not a big fan of this type, but the more types i drink the more i buy.  not bad

Pours a bright cloudy yellow.  Gives the aroma of cloves and banana. Looking at this beer you know you are in for a treat. Flavor is lemon grass with a nice balance of the wheat.  Very tasty! Nice pouring instructions on the bottle make this a very nice white.

Nice thick yellow color, with not much head.  Lemon pepper aroma, which is damn fine.  Taste is quite similar to the aroma, sweeter to begin with, but ends with a nice sharper finish.  One of my favorite belgian white's I've encounter.
hazy yellow, fluffy white had.  yeasty, peppery spice and citrus aroma.  nice citrus flavour with an interesting lemongrassy note.  quite refeshing.

POurs slightly hazy light light blonde color with very little head--dissapointment.  Aroma is musty yeast and some spices.  Mild aroma.  Starts thin and finishes a little watery.  Cloves and other spices in the middle.  Just doesnt do it for me.  Not enough aroma, body, and needs SOME head.
Pours a cloudy yellow with a thick white head. Aroma is very citrusy, with some yeast. Lemon, orange, and clove on the tongue. Nice creamy mouthfeel. This was a very nice witbier. The best I've had.
Hazy pale yellow with a small white head. Not much aroma not much taste either. Maybe it is just the style. I just don't get it. No real flavor at all, boring and flat.

Cloudy yellow without a lot of head.  Spicy nose with a little sweet maltiness.  Tartness jumps out first, followed by citrus and clove and corriander.  Yeast present throughout. 
Pretty creamy body.  Dry finish with doughy hints. Another winner from Allagash.

Small white head, dissapates quickly. Hazy gold with a white hue. Malt nose with citrus and cloves. Light/medium body, creamy mouthfeel. Spicey, malty flavors, some breadyness and more citrus flavors also. Finish is medium dry. Nice Wit!

12 oz. brown stubbie bottle. No freshness date seen anywhere. Poured out a golden yellow color. Cloudy from the yeast. Thin, white, fast-fading head. It left a thin ring of bubbles around the edge of the glass. Aromas are phenolic, lactic wheat, corriander, some malts, and of course, yeast. Tastes medicinal, too much phenol for my liking. Spices make up the bulk of the flavors, with dominate corriander spice profile. Finished crisp and dry. Not my favorite wheat beer.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2004 The instructions on the bottle say to swirl the bottled yeast and add it to the glass.  Before I did that, the beer was not cloudy like a wit, after it was 'perfect' looking.  Nice pale yellow gold.  Very nice sweet and spicy aroma.  Mild carbonation - good mouthfeel.  Overall a very good belgian style Wit from Maine, USA!
A bit clearer in appearance than Hoegaarden, but just about as good.  Nice lemon grass flavor with coriander as well.
Very foggy light brown color with a small white head.  Citrus and spicy nose.  Really good.  Creamy orange/banana taste with a smooth finish.
Pours a cloudy yellow, pretty vigourous white head. Slightly spicy aroma, also some citrus. Light bodied, nice rendition of a Belgian Witbier.
Bottle.  A pretty straightforward Belgian wit.  Cloudy-yellow, white head that clings to the glass.  Wheaty, crisp, banana-clove, spiciness.  Nice calm and somewhat dry finish.  Solid stuff.

Color was golden yellow with light bubbles floating throughout the whole thing. Small diminishing head.  Slightly foggy aroma of peanuts and vanilla.  Very carbonated and light but has a certain spicy wheaty complexity.

Decent appearing brew, pours cloudy yellow with medium egg white head that is retained.  Aroma is pretty compelling.  Notes of yeast, lots of spice, orange peel and coriandere.  Flavor is a step down from the aroma.  Flavor is nicely spicy, a bit light bodied.  This one will go down very nicely on an August day in Texas.  Not too heavy with some decent flavor.

1/27/04.  Poured out of 12 oz. bottle, obtained in a trade with igneous1 on RateBeer 1/21/04.  Pours a hazy pale golden yellow color with very little head, quite a bit of carbonation on it.  Thin and spotty but still pretty nice-looking lacing.  Looks pretty thin too.  Aroma is quite impressive for the appearance-- pretty bold and powerful, yeasty and wheaty with a delicate sweetness, a subtle peppery underscent, and a hint of banana.  Taste is of a wheat beer with candi sugar added, a bit of vegetable (broccoli?), a little hop bite, and even some subtle hints of heavier malt notes.  Medium-thin, smooth and buttery body, very nice mouthfeel.  Finish is dry and plump, then falls to a strange lemony sourness after awhile.  Can't say I enjoy the long flavor on the finish, but the rest of the characteristics of the beer are quite nice.
Unfiltered straw color with a very small head.  Faint spicy aroma with a hint of lemon.  Lots of carbonation mixing it up with the fruits and spices in the taste.  Dry, tart finish.
Pale yellow body with white head.  Aroma of spices and citrus.  Flavor was sweet and acidic.  Nothing to write home about.

Although I prefer dark beers, I had to try this one. I've never had a beer that came with instructions before. You have to pour half of it, swirl the bottle, then pour the rest because the yeast settles to the bottom. In a clear glass, it looks like aged apple cider; very creamy light amber. Not overly hoppy. I had been drinking a Pepsi and this beer still had a crisp sweetness I don't find in most beers. This is a notable beer

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2004 Light greenish gold with plenty of yeast sediment. Thin white head clings nicely to the glass. Aroma was not nearly as fruity as I expected. Mildly spicy with some grapefruit. Good body for a white beer. Well carbonated. Light and dry flavor finishes clean and refreshing. A very drinkable beer, but not the best white.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2005 bottle-sheffields in Chicago-12/31/03-pours a nice cloudy yellow appearance.  smell of ripe bananas, lemon, and spice.  palate is medium with nice tingle on the tongue.  very strong witbier.  
ReRate-bottle-pours a nice cloudy yellow orange hue with a small white head.  a great looking belgian wit.  phenalic aroma full of lemon, corriander, ginger, sour grapes, and yeast esters.  robust palate for a belgian wit.  flavors of belgian yeast, noble hops, lemon zest, green apple skins.  the finish has notes of cough surup unfortnately.  A very strong Belgian wit.
Light yellow color, with hints of green. Little head. Orange and lemon nose - big nose, but very thin taste, weak orange and lemon.

Wonderful citrusy nose - very nice. Hazy yellow color and white sticky head. Light lemony malt body turning to a spicy dry finish. Thin and weak taste, but refreshing. I wanted more body and more spice. Drinkable though.

Head formed very nicely and stayed around for awhile.  Hazy straw  color with small bubbles clinging to the side of the glass. Beer had hint of spices. Finish was smooth.  This is a very drinkable beer but not remarkable.

Hazy blond appearance, no head or lacing. Aroma is delicious with spicey notes along with banana & clove esters. Citrusy and zesty. Flavor is well balanced and smooth to drink, best wit bier ever for me. I really enjoyed this one. The mouthfeel lightly sour.

Pale gold pour with little head that is compised of rather large bubbles that stuck around longer than I expected. Wheat aroma comes out pretty strong, reminding me a bit of oatmeal. Small fruit, a bit sour as well.  Hops come out a bit more in the flavor. Fruit, citrus mainly. The wheat is still about, but seems to be a bit more muted. A wet (don't know if that makes much sense) feeling palate, and a mellow hop finish. Nice beer. Thanks BierBauch!
Golden color with orange citrus aroma.Yeasty fruit flavor with some hops.Smooth overall taste.Finishes rather sour with a bread feel in the mouth.Not bad.

WOW~~ had this in a nice corked bottle, Batch No. 5.  Poured to a beautiful golden straw color with a perfect white frothy head.  the citrus, clove and banana undertones were balanced perfectly.  I like this better without dumping the yeast into it -- more like a krystal klar.  A tiny bit too carbonated, but it didn't detract too much. Very good overall -- can't wait to have it again
user_location: Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Florida, USA

text: Cloudy straw-yellow with a soft, clean white head that faded to a flat placid surface. Classic aroma of orange citrus, a hint of coriander, fruit peel bitter nose, yeast, and banana/bubble gum. Flavor is full, distinctly spicy, crisp, and tart. Some slight soapiness detracts. But a good wit overall.

Batch #3 Corked 750ml. Average pure white head on piss gold ale. Suspension of yeast.  Thin white head lingers whole glass with equally thin lacing. Was unimpressed upon first tasting.  Now I'm convinced this is a damn good beer (maybe due to more yeast in end of bottle?).  Very slight aromas of fermentation, champagne, aswell as orange.  Taste is sweet at first followed by a hard smack of spice and citrus. There is a slight "doughy" taste (prob. due to all the yeast) closer to the end of the glass. This beer is thrist quenching at first, but becomes rougher towards end of glass.  Overall a very complex beer, very different.  Worth trying again.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2004 Poured a pale golden color with a small white head and alittle lacing.  Aroma of spice, coriander, and orange peel.  Orange, some hops and an herb like taste, maybe even alittle ginger as well... Very smooth and refreshing, bubbly mouthfeel.

a mysteriously hazed tangerine-colored bubbling lake..a full snow-white covering lifts the clove-touched banana aromas from the glass..coriander dances with belgian yeast fumes...citrus splendors whisper softly...flavors of soft tangerine mist, farmhouse straw, and sprinkles of spice...citrus acidity says goodbye...refreshingly soft, and almost relaxingly invigorating.

A slight cloudy, light golden color pours from the bottle. A frothy white head  with a nice citrusy aroma. Slight hops in the flavor, along with yeast and a slight sour taste as well. Overally not too bad. Purchased this bottle at Total Wine in Manassas, VA.
Cloudy pale yellow body beneath a small white head. Aroma is of yeast and corriander. Yeasty, flavor with a touch of citrus. Small dose of hops, finish is slight sour wheaty flavor.
Cloudy, bright yellow in appearance with a thin white head. Smells and tastes like a typical Belgian wheat beer but not as alcoholly as most. Also slightly fruity and spiced.
Very cloudy with lots of sediment.  A little more spicy than Hoegaarden, but lacks a little something in comparison. Still, the best american-brewed witbier I've had.

12 oz bottle. Spicy aroma. Opaque pale yellow color. Lots of yeast floating around. Smooth in the mouth. Not much carbonation. Citrus flavors with spicy overtones. Overall a refreshing beer. I usually don't drink Belgian Whites but I would have another one of these anytime.

Its refreshing to come back top one of my favorite styles after some time.  Cloudy golden haze with mucho yeast in suspension. Great aroma and mouthfeel.  Typical citrus overtones present tempered by the phenoelic characteristics found in some belgians.  Definately a thirst quencher.
UPDATED: MAR 25, 2004 Bottle. Spice and citrus aroma. Hazy golden color with small white head. Very crisp and fruity with light yeast. Excellent if you are thirsty.

Bottle from batch #9.  A slightly hazy yellow color with a white head.  While I found champagne, yeast, perfume, and coriander in the aroma, it was not a robust aroma.  Light bodied with a dry spice and citrus flavor.
a light-bodied beer.  Poured a hazy yellow color, with a thin light head.  Taste was sublte with notes citus and pepper.

Thanks for Darkover for this one. Pours a hazy dark yellow color with a thin off-white head. Very little lacing. Aroma is very spicy with pepper, coriander and some citrus. Light-bodied and crisp with a spicy and fruity character, with yeast flavor as well. The finish is sweet, fruity and clean. This is a solid Wit.
Hint of banana to the nose, lemon zest to the palate, very smooth finish.  Very refreshing beer and I'm liking it!
Lots of coriander with a touch of smoky black pepper and lemon in the aroma. White pepper/hoppy flavors abound. Consistent rim of fluffy head. Not mouth-filling but very refreshing.

Wonderful aroma of banana, citrus, and spicy coriander. The appearance is a lovely cloudy golden yellow. Flavor is dominated by a sweet citrusy start, a spicy coriander middle followed by a clove-like finish and aftertaste. Mouthfeel is average. A great wit.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2012 Slightly murky yellow.  Big nose of cloves, coriander, bananas and lemons.  Very crisp and stinging as the bubbles race across the tongue.  Citrus, lemon, sprite soda all come to mind.  A bit bland in the finish, but smooth after it explodes on the tongue.  What a nice wit.

A sharp smell of corriander, the appearance is excellent, opaque yellow. Very citrus, floral, orange and corriander. very flavorful, a slight flat (for lack of a better word) taste that I cant quite identify.

(draught) Pale yellow, slight white head, lacey. Nose is citrussy, fresh orange flowers, some coriandre. Taste gives a bitter cookie-like flavour (mannah), mixed with the more classical witbier tastes. No overdose of coriandre or curaçao - OK. Light bodied - not thin. In the aftertaste, a mild sweetness appears. A better than average wit. I like the bitterish starting taint.

A cloudy straw yellow beer that pours with a white head with decent retention. Leaves a nice ring of lace at the top of the glass. The aroma is of yeast and malt, with a straw component in the background. The taste is heavy with coriander and yeast, with some wheat flavors and a subtle sweetness. The finish still seems to have some noticable hops as well.

Although I can now get Allagash here in Florida, but only in 750’s, this particular White Beer was acquired in a trade with Jeremy, the Main Pimp of Rochester, jgb9348! Damn this Allagash White is as pale as the old moonlight; oh and “hey Batman, You ever dance with the devil in the pale moon light?”  This one pours a pale glowing golden color with a frothy white head. The aroma is of wheat, yeast, and lemon. The flavor is obviously wheaty and spicy, again more lemon, oily palate, snappish, crisp finish; wow this is quit good but I don’t have much to say as far as a description goes.
Hazy yellowish orange, snow white head. Cirusy nose. Fairly wheaty with some spice. Nice witbier.
Fairly fruity in the nose and taste. Citris and lemon in the nose, cloudy white colour, and tangy flavor kind of wheaty. Not bad, overall.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2010 Quite nice. The color is a "glowing" orange with plenty of cloudiness. The bitter flavors of the orange peel are quite apparent. The texture is quite complex, especially for a "lighter" beer. Definately on my "shopping" list now!
UPDATED: SEP 23, 2003 Hazy yellow color with a small white head. Aroma of yeast and spices. Flavor of spices with a little sourness. The carbonation is a little too strong.

Dayton, OH AleFest:This beer's appearance was a small sized white head with fine sized bubbles that quickly diminished.The body was cloudy and the hue was pale yellow.The nose was fruity, citrusy and spicy.It had a light bitter flavor to it and the mouthfeel was smooth.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2005 Rerate 2005 bottling: Seems much more of a witBIER this year, you can taste some herbal hops and a bit of bready malts under those spices and wheat. Quite a refreshing Summer quencher. Improving flavor score and overall scores.  Hazy yellow hue with no head to speak of. Aroma hints of orange, corriander, lemongrass, herbs, hay field, and leather. Very spicy and orangy taste up front with a dry and papery finish. What this beer is missing is just that, beer. No hints of malt or hops in the flavor. That said, this is still a tasty "version" of the Witbier, just dont expect to much.

An aroma of orange, coriander and an herbal citrus nose.  This beer is a pale gold color that is nicely cloudy (thus the white).  Lightly refreshing and well carbonated as well.  Tastes nicely spiced, with fruity notes, citrusy and a bit of coriander in the finish.  Ends with a bit of sharp acidity on the tongue.  A good well balanced, and easy drinking wit.

Hey this is good. I had a bad batch once and it put me off. Either they changed it completely in 2 years or my batch was skunked first time around. Anyways in the tradition of its style this is a fruity sweet beer with lots of complex flavor. I wish I had it with an orange or lemon as that is how I usally drink this style. The only thing I can thing of negitive is that it is slightly more sour( the bad batch very sour) than Blue Moon or Hoegarrden which to me is not a good thing. However it may be the lack of fresh fruit that is making me think this. I recomend this highly but the price is a bit steep.

A tad darker than the Hoe, lacking the greenish tinge.  Pretty white head fades away almost completely over the glass.  Aroma is of coriander, oranges, cloves, and spice.  The palate is a hair rough.  The flavor is great, grainy wheat balanced out by an interplay of spice, yeast, and fruits.  A favorite.
Very nice vanilla, lemon hop aroma, with plenty of dough and some flowers.  Spicy palate with some cloves, orange flesh and a creamy finish.  Very satisfying.

Aroma: nice fragrance of wheaty malts and ester overtones
Palate: dry and a bit empty. 
Appearance: Dark orange-yellow with little lacing, though good cloudiness. Flavor: good mellow spice, dry, but missing character. Overall: interesting in it's own unique way: full of spice but not much "beer" flavor. I could easily guzzle this brew. In fact, if it were in a can I would most certainly shotgun it.

Pours a cloudy pale golden color, big white head, good lace, and a lot of clingy bubbles in the body.  Aroma is lemon zest, other citrus, slightly tart, and some mild spices.  Flavor is lemon & citric, some hints of banana (especially as it warmed), light spice, some biscuit, and some bubblegum was detected at the very end.  Body is medium-full, lot's of different flavors and things happening as it warmed.

When i first smelled it i was like "Fruit Loops!  this smells like fruit loops!"  then i took a longer, deeper smell and it reminded me _exactly_ of some vomitous-orangy-yeasty-yucky medicine i had to take when i was like 9 and deathly sick. oh yuk.  i think i had some awful psychosomatic reaction to the smell and the taste of this because i started gagging violently and almost whoopsed my cookies, just from a small sip. after a minute of calming down i took another sip and i actually started running to the bathroom.  the combination of the spices in this is so perfectly like that medicine that made me sick when i was sick...i'm sorry that i rated it badly, but everything about this makes me feel like i'm going to get ill.  i'm sure it's a great beer, but there's something in the taste that i can't handle.  i ended up dumping it out.

750ml #7. Pours a beautiful hazy honey color. Cloves are ever present in the nose. Semi-sweet delectible flavor. The spices shine through, delicate yet bold. The aftertaste leaves a peppery dry flavor. Excellent as an aperitif or a lazy summer beer.  Big and beautiful. I'm happy to make this my 100th ratebeer.
Lots of cloves.  Fairly smooth and light.  A friend claimed it numbed his tongue.  Crisp and clean.  Good for a summer night.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2003 Second Sampling:  Everything holds true.  More spice, white pepper in the nose and taste than I noticed during my first tasting of this beer.  Original: 750 ml Batch #5:  Pleasantly smooth and light.  Golden, apricot type of glowing haze color.  Semi-expectant head.  Very tarty.  Maybe there's some orange in here, but mostly a type of appled spice with a good nose.  A good balance between nose and taste in the front end.  Not really wheaty, or at least dominantly so.  Highly drinkable and fastly so.  Very solid.

Decent head and carbonation though does not last long.  Aroma of wheat and some spice.  Color is a light gold color with the typical wheat cloudyness.  Flavor is quite nice but diffenrent that what I expected.  I can taste a rather stong flavor of lime which is making the flavor bitter along with the wheat and yeast.  Finish has a lingering bitter/sour aftertaste with more lime present.  Not what I expected but a different and decent witbier that may not sit all that well in the stomach.

Pours a cloudy (yeasty) orange with a thick white head.  Darker than most witbiers I've tried.  Aroma is spice and light citrus.  The flavor was somewhat surprising, with spices dominating the palate.  Surprisingly little citrus was noted, and a bit heavily carbonated.  An interesting take on a witbier, though I prefer smoother, more citrusy examples.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2003 Yellow/chardonnay look with golden highlights. Very thin, quickly disapating head. Trace sediments floating in glass, and healthy bubbling.  Smells of wine, cheese and cream.  Has a drying taste in the mouth: yeast, soda water, cloves. Pretty hard to pick up much else on the tongue. Yeasty aftertaste that doesn't linger too long. I expected much more from this beer and came away disappointed.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2004 2003 draft.  Cloudy very light straw yellow color.  Lighter than most whites I have seen.  Smells faintly of spices, and a little bit of yeast.
Small head.
Begins understated and light, but body comes out somewhat and there is a very delicate coriander and lemon flavor.  Yeast flavor comes out as it warms and is very light though distinct.  A nutty undertone emerges as well.  Very little alcohol taste throughout.  Medium body and leaves a fresh lemony flavor on the palate.  This was a nice change from the almost cloying Hoegarden, but perhaps takes too much out of the beer and leaves it a little bit light/watery.
2004 bottle.  The description from above is surprisingly spot on for the bottle.  Maybe a bit less wateriness, as expected.  I'm upping the color a point as it is light and very pale, but still bottle conditioned and shimmering.

A very good, smooth Belgian white.  Pours a lightly-clouded golden with a soft pillowy head.  Not watered down and well balanced with coriander and citrus.  Good malty undertones.  One of the best wits I've had.
Tap, Hop Leaf Chicago.  Strong aromatic aroma, both floral yeast and spicy coriander.  Substantial body.  Refreshing, quite nice.

Dark yellow color, thick soapy head. Smell: an enticing combination of apricots and peaches. After the smell the taste was a bit of a letdown;  stale peaches and Earl Grey tea.
No malt, no hops, not even a hint of citrus, which I did kind of expect since this is an American version of a light German wheat. Disappointing.
Lots of nutty coriander flavors, some lemony citrus bouncing of yeasty flavors in a medium full aroma. Only lightly cloudy. Delicious but not comparable to this brewer's bigger, better beers.
White wheat, some banana. Slightly earthy and yeasty. Good Wit but did not show anything more than most average beers of such kind.
Light yellow. Scent is spicy, but there is something off about the scent that I can't quite place. Has the spicy citrus flavor that others have described. Just doesn't do it for me.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2003 This brew pours a head of fine white bubbles that left an excellent lacing and a straw yellow body.  I smelled no discernable aroma from it.  It had a tingly mouthfeel and a mild bread flavor.  Nothing much here.

Original rating of:
3-4-5-3-10

Re-Rate:
The first sample came from the Dayton Ale fest.  Later when we came home, we found a bottle of this in the beer stash.  Hence the re-rate.  From the bottle, the aroma was more discernable as a mild floral malty one.  The head was much larger and the body was much more hazy due to the yeast in the bottle we poured.  The mouthfeel was more bubbly and finished more smoothly.  Thflavor was also more noticeable with elements of malt and coriander appearing.  All-in-all, I gave it a 5-3-6-4-13 at home.  Combining this rating with the other I bumped up the aroma from3 to 4, flavor from 5 to 6 and overall fom 10 to 12.  Thus proving what we already know to be true that a bottle is better than a sample!

Body is literally medium: not too thin, not too big. Head is nice, white, and persistent. Color is, as far as I know, right on style. Nice balance of body and spiciness on the whole that seems fairly complex. Maybe too sweet, though.

By the way, visited the brewery for what may have been the absolute WORST tour I've ever been on. Way too quick, way too many unanswered questions, way too little beer geek comeraderie, and way too little sampling. Very disappointing.

Color was light, cloudy yellow with a huge white fluffy,head that retained throughout the glass as I drank it and had patchy tight lace. Aroma of strong lemony, orange, with a bit of spice.
Taste is good, could have a little more body though, but its a good wheat style belgian, lightly lemony, a bit of spice and a very clean wheat backing. Pretty darn good. Its a bit empty on the feel, goes right into the lemony spice and just ends, no real finishing qualities. It's a lighter bodied ale, fresh, lemony, with a slightly dry citrus twinge.

Juicy orange and yeast in the nose, some coriander.  Cloudy, light golden in color with lots of suspended particles and a very slight head.  Flavor is initially tart, lightly malty and citric, becoming much sweeter and fruitier, with the yeast and spices added in towards the finish.  Very "wet" palate, with a smoothly effervescent mouthfeel.  Medium-full bodied, unusual for this style.  I think I expected a little more from the #1 Witbier in the world (according to current Ratebeer stats).  It's a little too sweet and the spices are a little too prominent for me to enjoy this highly.

On tap - definately yeasty but the flavors come thru
and don't seem like they were sprinkled in as additives at the end.  Cloudly with limited but persistant carbonation.
Definately on the heavier side of the Belgian Whites that I have sampled.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2003 I think there's too much yeast in this beer, and it really affects the flavor & palate. The yeast interferes with the flavors of the spices in this beer and makes it taste kind of bland, with a soapy texture. re-rate: It's grown on me. The flavors come out more as it warms. A good brew, and the first wheat beer that I've really enjoyed.

Pours cloudy with pale yellow color, small white head.  Sweet yeasty aroma.  Very filling.  Mild fruity/yeasty flavor(tastes best when allowed to warm) with a crisp yet delicate fruity aftertaste that lingers.

Batch #7. Yellow color. Medium head. Aroma is spicy and citrusy with a touch of coriander. A medium bodied whit. Orange coriander and other spices. Somewhat sweet and balanced by its spiciness. Very tasty and extremely drinkable. Just gonna sit back and enjoy this one. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet and a touch spicy.
Almost clear yellow.  Citrus, coraiander and cloves aroma.  Very spicy (too much?) flavor, lots of coriander, a bit soapy.  Maybe too much carbonated.  Not my favorite wit.

Pours a banana juice (?) color with a quickly diminishing white head. The aroma and flavor contained significant coriander along with lemon, vanilla pudding, and bready tones. Very effervescent feel...nice.

Cloudy golden color with white head. Light aroma of yeast and lemon. Clean, smooth, and mild flavor is slightly spicy.
Flavor is mostly bread/yeast and mild citrus (lemon) with the spice becoming more apparent in the finish. Palate is extremely smooth and perhaps slightly undercarbonated.
(Bottle) Golden appearance, highly carbonated with white head. Lemony, perfume nose. Lemon, grapefruit, tart, pasty, dry. Finishes bitter.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2003 Pours out a hazy solid golden.Bubbles  stick to the edge of the glass.Smells like a light belgian stlye(orange/spice)I love this beer.Allagash "covers" these beers great.Lighter,perfected,Highly drinkable(addictive at times).Nice beer to start w/ from these cats.And i'm not a huge belgian style fan regaurdless of what my choice of style says.I will be seeing more of these...

Cloudy light yellow with a small white head.  A spicy/orange aroma.  A wheat taste with a little too much winter spice for me to consider this a summer beer, more of a fall beer.  The spices also get old quickly.  I did not find this that refreshing.
a very nice white beer. Color was far from being white and maybe the darkest white I´ve seen. A bitter fruity taste, not the most refreshing white I´ve had but nevertheless a very nice beer

I sampled this one head to head with Hoegaarden white and Blanche de namur. It is quite dark for a Weizze and it is also a bit heavy smelling. The taste was also a bit on the heavy side and there was not really much going on there, but I could taste some spices. I just wasnt really impressed.

Draught.  Yeasty, sicey aromas.  Strong coriander?  Slightly sour aroma.  Thin white head, cloudy golden hue to appearance.  Bitterness noted at first--more from a citrousy acid flavor than from hops.  Yeasty-ness not very strong in flavor.  Addition of orange definitely helps the flavor out some.  Bitterness softens after a few sips.  Above average.
A good white beer.  This is quite a new favorite among the local import drinkers.
On draft. Nice aroma- spicy but not sweet. Golden orange in color with a slight cloudiness. Sharp citrus flavor, then a nice smooth ride to a slightly yeasty finish. Very nice wit.

Pours hazy blondish white. Decent off-white head. Strong aroma of spices, yeast and wheat. Possibly coriander or nutmeg. Strong spritz on the palate and finishes with a pleasant wheaty aftertaste. Much better than the Grand Cru.
Cloudy golden body, small fizzy head.  Flavor is very good, spicy and citrusy.  Good example of the style.
Heavenly fruity peach apricot aroma.Cloudy blond appearance.Spritzy carbonation.Dry fruity honey flavors with a dry clean finish.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2010 This is a great example of a Belgian spiced white ale. I actually believe that this one is even better than Hoegaarden on draught. It pours beautifully, an orangy golden cloudy work of art. It feels like an ultra smooth wheat ale and the flavor is a generous presence of orange and corriander. This one seems to taste better as you drink it and the best mouthful was the last one from the bottle. Rerate 11/10 Not what it was a few years ago. The aroma of orange and spices not nearly as fragrant and overall a bit less attractive to me Bruerys Orchid White now the go to Wit for me
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Not as sweet as I was expecting.  However, I think I may have purchased a bottle gone bad.  It tasted like day old Keystone Light.  I was fairly disappointed because the other brews I've had from this brewery have been very good.  I'll have to try another bottle and rerate.

Not as deep of color as you would expect of the style, nor as cloudy.  Still o.k. with a decent white head.  Effervescent ginger ale aroma, the body was a bit thin, actually.  And I hate to dwell on the negatives today, but this was not as broadly spicy as you would hope either.  Nice as a beer, but not brill for its style, to my taste. (on tap, Clark Street Ale House, Chicago, IL)
Has a clouded light yellow color with a lemon/spice smell.  Taste is also citrusy and finishes with a smooth yeast/wheat flavor.  Overall this is a very good and refreshing beer.

Very crisp and dry...I suspect that this will be particularly good when the warm weather rolls around.  Highly flavored with citrus, especially lemons.  Thick, foamy stark white head on a pale, cloudy yellow body.

750ml bottle marked "batch 3" - Golden cloudy appearance a good belgian white should have, with a short-lived head, but very impressive lacing.  Smells like lemons and spices.  High carbonation mellows after sitting for just a short while.  Very complex little belgian white..probably the best of the style I've had.  Very citrusy, spicy - orange peel - you can really taste the coriander suggested on the label - slight yeasty undertones and some malt presence hanging out in the back, which lingers on after the rest of the party has left.  An excellent, refreshing witbier.
Definitely reminded me of Hoegaarden.  Great aroma and appearance.  Tastes fruity and spicy and is an extremely refreshing beer.  I like the color a bit more than Hoegaarden.
Draft: wonderfully spicy and citrus with orange and a little lemon. Very refreshing. And yes, just slightly better than Hoegaarden on tap.
Big white head, citrus grape jam aroma. Maybe some clover, and of course coriander in the flavor, but also a spicy/peppery flavor. Very interesting beer. Batch #3
Straw colored and slightly cloudy, this beer had a nice foam stand. The bitter orange and coriander really jumps at you. Refreshing!

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2003 An absolutely marvelous beer, both as a representative of the style, as well as among all beers!  A dark, cloudy yellowish orange color and a very large white head start off this excellent brew.  Nose is spicy and spectacular.  Flavor also features a wealth of spiciness, along with a crisp bite that is really very nice.  A very delicious beer, and perfect as a less heavy beer for summer, though I find it enjoyable at all times!

Very murky pale yellow color.  The little bits of yeast are easily discernible when one looks at the beer.  Nice  coriander and citrusy aroma, but the yeast was there too.  Something I don't think I'll ever be able to like is the aroma of yeast in beer.   Anyways, the flavor is just tremendous with hints again to the spices...I could swear I tasted rosemary.  There is also an underlying aspect that reminds me of pine trees and dark fir trees, although I don't know what those exactly taste like.  The body is thin, by way of the style, and that makes it so refreshing and crisp.  Finished dry with hints back to the spices and a slight hop presence, perhaps cascades?  Overall, one of the more refreshing beers I've had.

Batch #3: This one pours a light, cloudy, yellow color with a medium sized, lingering white head. It has an aroma of spices, orange, yeast, and wheaty fruitiness. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, the flavor is full of coriander, yeast, and citus tones with a slight orange taste in the finish. Smooth and quite delicious, a great Belgian white. I may like this one more than Hoegaarden.

Very wheatish nose of pepper and a hint of bubblegum.  The brew pours a cloudy pale golden.  The small frothy head is white, and diminishes quickly with fair lacing.  The very spicy flavor has a high level of acidity and finishes with a peppery bite.  It's been a while since I've tasted something like this.  The medium body is dry and fizzy, and feels very astringent at the finish.  I can admire this brewer's effort though I really don't care for the style.
This one has a nice spicy nose.  The orange peel and coriander both assert themselves in nose and in flavor.  It's got a light body and fruity taste that make it a perfect summer beer.

Pale yellow in color with non-existant head, rather cloudy. Aroma was yeasty with some citrus. Flavor was yeasty and sweet, with a bit of malt. Maybe I'm just not crazy about this style, but I wasn't impressed with this one.
definite fruity/ citrus aroma like most whites.  yeast still in suspension gives this beer a nice spicy flavor. didn't pour with much of a head, but still a solid beer
(draft):  Minimum head, medium yellow, opaque.  Aroma is sweet, yeasty, and lightly lemony.  Taste has medium sweetness, yeasty, some mild lemon.  Very Belgian White.

A cloudy pale yellow colour with absolutely no head. Very spicy smell, but that of a typical white. A flavourful and pleasant taste. Noticable spices and somewhat fruity with a good mesh of hops and malt. One of the best white's i've ever had!

Very pale yellow colour. Wonderful citrusy aroma with coriander and hops too. Flavour is very pleasant and refreshing; lightly fruity and hoppy with nice spicy palate. Fine Belgian Wit style beer, although I prefer them a bit fruitier.

Excellent Witbier - great find at the local liquor store.  Clean citrusy aroma - fluffy - mustache sticking lacing head that does not go away.  Spicy flavor that stays strong thoughout.  Looking forward to more from this brewer - rare find for north Florida.

I declare, seems the Yanks and Canucks do Belgian better than the Belgians do.  Between Allagash, Unibroue and Ommegang the pricepoint this side of the Atlantic isn't even a trade-off for quality.  This has a nice spicey/fruity/vanilla/butterscotch aroma.  Nice label (though bordering on the 'clip-arty') and Belgian 750 ml bottle, pear-gold beer with slightly off-white, pithy head.  Light sediment.  Absolutely delicious -- the elements in the aroma are matched by the flavour.  Orange flavours and a not-unpleasant smidge of diacetyl.  Batch # 4 whatever that means. Not terribly fizzy, but adequately bottle-carbonated with a thin but silky wheat palate.  This really has me looking forward to the Allagash Tripel.
one of the better belgium beers brewed here in the good old usa

Slight re-rate: Corked bottle. Light,hazy,golden color with a thick,long lasting,bone-white head. One of the freshest and most inviting aromas Ive ever experienced. Inviting,wheat,spice,fruit-yeasty aromas,little hoppiness as well.Palate is just slightly watery.Flavors are similar to aromas and are subtle.Yeast pour added more content to the experience. Overall,darn good.

Im partial to Belgian Whites, but its a good offering nonetheless from Allagash.  Weak head, but solid color.  Citrus taste hints towards the banana fermentation you might find in some saisons.  The yeast is pleasingly mellowed compared to some others Ive tried.
A sparkling wit but quite dull looking.  This is basically a poor relation to Hoegaarden and Celis White.  This is a bit soda-watery.

Happy to finally try an allagash offering. Unimpressive in appearanec, as wits generally are, with a nice head and a whitened bronzish body. Light pinyness in the aroma with stank beer notes intermingled to give a rather refreshing aroma esp. suited for summer. White cheese notes and coriander with an oily pininess that could be come rather sickening to the stomach after a couple. A refreshing brew I could certainly turn to in hot weather.
Nice color, great head.  Citrus, spiciness I LOVE.  Great with chocolate while stuffing stockings.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: After their dubble and triple I have to admit that I was terribly let down by this beer. Light hazy yellow color with a foamy white head. Excellent aroma, herbs and some yeasty kick. I didnt enjoy the flavor however. It had that same herb and yeast which to me made it taste unfinished and unbalanced.

Had this on tap as part of a sampler at Willimantic Brewpub in CT.  It was the second best out of the six beers.  (I enjoyed an octoberfest we had more)  The beer is a pale cloudy gold, with a somewhat disappointing thin head.  The beer itself is light to medium bodied, with an interesting spiced flavor Im not too familiar with.  It tastes a bit like orange, but a little tangier and sharper.
